Perhaps trying to improve upon the slightly depressing tone of the first film, Sex and the City 2 tries to be more funny, more flashy and more colorful. It holds on for dear life to this notion that these women's happy endings must not be disturbed. Their relationships, their success and their life stories seem to be etched in stone now, making any attempt to create some sort of conflict in the actual plot of the film seem contrived, unnecessary and mostly foolish. The characters are reduced to self-indulgent, materialistic bitches that fail to be satisfied by absolutely everything - since they have it all: the money, the clothes, the husbands. At some point in the film you go from loving these characters to just hating their rich behinds. I presume the makers of this farcical sequel thought they'd try to take our minds off from our sad little recession-hit lives by taking us on an all expenses paid trip with the girls to Abu Dhabi. What they seem to have completely lost is their storytelling ability and a way to reach out to the audience. (not to mention that the title of the series is Sex and the City, the city being New York City, but what can we do - it's an all expenses paid trip after all) While the makers of the film focus on delivering ridiculous puns and changing the ladies' outfits in every consecutive scene, no one seems to have been the slightest bit concerned that not only has the film lost the plot, it's lost touch with reality. Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte are no longer every woman. They are Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte, the rich bigoted American feminists who have it all. They have become...celebrities. Are we supposed to be happy for them? For the sake of the show, yes. But do you really want to watch them rub it in your face along with awful puns and Liza Minnelli singing "Single Ladies" by Beyonce? No. I wish I hadn't.

I took a break yesterday to see SETC2, and I have to say, the reviews have it totally wrong. I thought this movie was great fun, and I actually think it was much more true to the spirit of the series than the first movie. I thought the script was classically well crafted. There were dashes of politics mixed with a Carrie-esquire look at the challenges that arise in maturing relationships, and the whole thing was wrapped in the high-fashion confection we've come to expect from the show. I felt the characters, who had wandered off to weird places in the first movie, were back in fine form--especially Samantha. There are cornball turns of phrases, insider jokes, and winks and nods, but again, this is all very much in keeping with the original HBO series. If you're expecting Fellini, then this ain't the flick for you. But you should have already had 10+ years to figure that out. If you want an eye-popping 2-1/2 hour joy ride with some old friends, then go plunk your money down worry free.

reviews.review_title: This movie has one thing going for it....
reviews.content: it was better than the first film, which was truly awful. I found this sequel to be more entertaining and it had its moments. Samantha is into hormones. Miranda has quit her job to find something better. Charolette has a hot nanny and crying kids. Carrie is trying to do everything possible to keep her marriage from becoming boring. So in the beginning, we get some funny scenes with Charolett's braless nanny and a gay wedding with Liza Mannali. Even Jerrod Smith gets thrown in.Samantha gets in invite with a rich Arab to go to Abi Dabi for a week so brings along her girlfriends. You just know something will happen with her when it comes to inappropriate public behavior. Carrie meets Adian there which I thought was the worse thing in the movie. That's too much of a coincidence. We get some nice visuals with their 5 star hotel room and butlers, especially "paula". Some drama at the end and of course it wraps up with Samantha getting her guy and Carrie with Big.FINAL VERDICT: If you liked the TV show, it's worth checking out. Much better than the first film.

Carrie starts a big fight with her husband because he doesn't feel like going out to a stupid party after working into the evening. Miranda has a new boss who doesn't like her very much. Samantha is old and needs to take hormones for menopause. From an artistic standpoint, there were some plot elements and character developments I didn't think were totally needed. They do however drive the story, which seemed to be their purpose, so I can accept them. Heartfelt and riveting from the first frame to the last. Great performances help to enhance this amazing story of a friendship. The kind of film that proves that a small story can be much more meaningful than a larger one.

I got to thinking, why is this movie hated so much? Universally panned and overlooked, but I thought it stays true to the series and the core of the characters. Problematic UAE issues aside, it was fun to go on a better than first class trip with the girls, at such a lavish resort ironically filmed in Morocco. Makes me want to fly again.

Im a HUGE Sex and the City fan.. and been awaiting this movie since the first one finished. As it was released Friday I caught on that it was getting bad reviews, I decided not to read any of them and go in with my own clear head and to decide myself, growing up with watching the girls, and loving to re-watch episodes out of the box set I was not disappointed.I laughed a lot through satc2 with highs and lows and many girlie giggles I enjoyed the whole thing. It reminds you of the good times and how important friends are..I'm still a massive fan of satc I am proud to say :)

reviews.review_title: Calm down it's just eye candy
reviews.content:
I don't know why everyone in this comment section is so mad: this movie is clearly and unabashedly just eye candy. The setting, the plot, the dresses... everything is accurately built just to show you some luxury stuff.
The plot and most of the characters are incredibly stupid but that's the point: you can focus on the visual and that's that.

This movie was seriously terrible, and the reason for that was simple: the characters we see in this movie are not the characters we know.Usually what made this show great was that you could, at some point in your life, identify with one of the four characters. But simply hearing Carrie say to Big when he gives her a TV for their anniversary that "hmm, jewelry would have been nice" made me cringe. At least his present was from the heart, since the story behind it was that he enjoyed watching an old movie with her the other day. To be honest, Big is usually not the kind of character I would ever see settling down and being "controlled" by a woman, so to me, he did an awesome job. I mean, after a long day at work he decides to make Carrie happy and go with her to a movie premiere. I mean, c'mon, this guy is doing everything to make her happy. And what does she do? Complains all the time and then cheats on him with Aidan in a foreign country. This movie made me hate Carrie, the whole time I kept thinking she was acting like a spoiled 16 year old. At no point did she stop to think. I mean,even though she was never perfect in the series, she was someone who would stop and ask herself rhetorical questions every five minutes. For someone with so much experience in relationships, she was so stupid. The other characters were also equally dumb, Miranda was maybe the only one that was still half normal.All in all, I just wish the producers of this film would have stayed true to the characters and focused on what really mattered instead of trying to impress us with a bunch of superficial things, which in the end, made everything in the movie look shallow.

From the television to the big screen, the girls of Sex and the City are back. Filled with fashion, shoes and lots of sex, the girls realize life's realities of keeping the magic alive. As an escape of the daily grind the girls travel Abu Dabi to rediscover the good life and be renewed. The packed screening has jeers and cheers that these herorines fight throw the issues of the modern woman. The highlight of the film was Liza Minnelia making a cameo playing her self performing "All the Single Ladies" from the Beyonce chart winning number one hit. Catch up to what is happening from the dynamic four cool cats from the big apple.

I really don't get it why this film has bad reviews. I LOVED IT! The clothes, music, the story, ... I think this movie is better then the 1st one. I also have the complete series on DVD and this film has more the soul of the series then the first movie. I really REALLY want a 3rd movie. Those 4 women on the big screen are just like magic! Samantha was in this movie my favorite! She was so funny... Loved it When the girls did the karaoke was just great! Me and my friends said: we should do that to! A Few days later we did :p Trust me, if you wanna have a great time with you're friends, boyfriend or girlfriend go and see this movie! You will love it!

I've read all the reviews posted and just want to add, - "HELLO, its a movie!!" It was a great escape and if you're looking for facts rather than fiction, go see a documentary. My best-friend and I went to see it today, and we thought it was great! LMAO! OK, some of the fashion was over the top, Samantha was extreme (but isn't she always), and Miranda, was well, Miranda...I loved her male chauvinist boss, which I hadn't noticed that anyone else recognized! The only character I thought didn't make the grade was Carrie. I just failed to see how she was so unhappy in her perfect little world. I also would have liked to have seen more of Smith and Aiden, both of which were incredibly HOT.Bottom line, if you've been a SATC since the beginning sit down, kick back, and enjoy the fantasy. It is after all, Hollywood and not rocket science!

When I heard they had made a Sex In The City film..I thought.."cool"..even though I wasn't an avid fan of the show. I caught a few episodes now and then..and usually enjoyed them. Of course...some of the story lines were slightly lame and after a while..it was easy to get tired of the characters. Sno why did they think it was necessary to make a sequel to the first one? Sure...I know there are major fans out there who want to BE Carrie Bradshaw and company...the lifestyles seem amazing!! But come on...do intelligent,accomplished career women actually act like these women? I would hope not. What firm or business would tolerate them being around...imagine the rumors. The insecurities of each of them were too extreme as well...none seemed capable of meeting a decent guy or establishing a lasting relationship. Mr. Big...who we all know is Carries' man...never seemed to care he was leading her on...and well...she let him..dropping everything whenever he showed up. What a pig...despite his money and good looks. Does being a career woman...a successful one mean you also drink too much worry about designer clothes and shoes? Sounds unappealing to me. Sending a message to women that is you are successful you will have to be like one of these ladies is ridiculous. I hope there is not a 3rd sequel planned..that would be a waste of time.

More Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone than Sex in the City. Thanks to unflattering lighting, costuming and time the "girls" now resemble crypt-keepers. With dismal photography, flat, undistinguished direction and annoyingly narcissistic, self-involved characters, the whole enterprise has a dreary, depressing feel which certainly wasn't the intent. Nor, was it intended for the audience to dislike these characters and to pity the poor Muslims who have to deal with them. Gratuitous product placement takes the place of writing, and an elaborate and pointless musical number featuring Liza Minnelli derails the film from the start. For die-hard fans who can't get enough of SATC, this film may be the cure. A barely animated Chris Noth is "Mr. Big Nothing" and the rest of the men are either ciphers, sex objects, sugar daddies or gay. The first film was a disappointment, but at least it had some bounce; SATCII sags.

reviews.review_title: Wow, biggest SATC fan and I am so disappointed
reviews.content: I just got back from the 12:01 a.m. screening of the movie. I could not wait to see my girls back. I thought we would get deeper into Samantha relationship problems, I thought we would see Charlotte, Miranda and there loves and how there relationship has grown, and I THOUGHT the Aiden kiss was going to be more then 10 minutes of problems but none of these things happened. It was a funny, good jokes (Charloote drunk was great, camel-toe was funny, and some other good jokes)but it did not feel like the last movie or the show I loved. Not many Carrie voice-overs about how she feels which I loved from the T.V. show. No drama really, Big being mad lasted 10 minutes and they could have made it more interesting how they solve their problems. I feel like I just got robbed, not for the $10.50 I paid but the chance to develop the relationships between the girls and their relationships with their husbands. I am so sick, so disappointed, and can not believe that the movie was so lame. If your a fan, go see the early show to save some money. And for the people that are intested and want to see the movie, DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY! Wait for the DVD. I hope the Sex and The City 3 gets back to the shows roots and what we all want, not some vacation movie that has almost no plot.This review is coming from a fan that has the entire DVD set of all 6 seasons and the Blu-Ray of Sex and The City:1. I can not believe they messed this up this bad.

Honestly, I don't get the bad reviews.It is "Sex and the City" so you shouldn't expect a big story line. You are there to see the shoes,the cloth and man. The wardrobe budget was in the range of $10-million so it's worth seeing!!! Just for that it is 10/10! Abu Dhabi scenes were filmed in Moroccowas because they were denied the shooting permits based on moral objections to the movie's name -- "Sex and the City. And lots of people have a moral objections with the script hence the reviewsWe go to the movies to escape reality not to hear about the recession. Its a pure pleasure not a documentary on National Geographic for goodness sake! The show was so popular in first place as pure escapism. So just watch and enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: See it for yourself and decide
reviews.content: I was really hesitant to go see this because I lived in the Middle East for a number of years, and to think of the SATC ladies visiting there was a complete "what the F?" for me. The first SATC film wasn't even able to be shown in the Middle East, so why go there as the film setting? Now that I've seen the film, I can say that the set-up for that was handled perfectly. Their experience is just as it should have been given who they are.There were some laugh out loud moments, some interesting insight, and the 2.5 hours flew by quickly. The characters and their relationships/experiences have moved on since the last film, and some of the discoveries they make are ones that seem inevitable as one ages. Definitely a popcorn movie, and it's just so good to see the SATC team back at it!

reviews.review_title: definitely not a happy hour (or 2 and 1/2!)
reviews.content: I have never written a review of a film before on this site, but watching this film has made me so angry and disappointed that i felt i had to say something.I am 23 and like most girls have loved the sex and the city TV series and the first film, so was very much looking forward to this second instalment I went to see this with my mum and a friend and her mum, we are all different ages, and not one of us had a good time, or could say anything positive about this film when we left the cinema.It has little story line, and the 4 girls who i loved watching in the first film, now seem just shallow and completely devoid of normal human reactions/emotions and behaviour.The way the women act in Abu Dhabi is embarrassing and completely disrespectful to the countries culture.Basically don't waste your money on this hyped up piece of fluff, the outfits may be nice to look at, but there is no substance at all.

reviews.review_title: Sex and the City might be going out of fashion now
reviews.content: Sex and the City 2 isn't the best of films and is over long with it's 2 and a half hour run time but it is still enjoyable for sadly a one off thing now. The story seemed to be a story what would have happened off screen on the TV-show because the TV-show had enjoyable episodes. The only main good things in the movie is the acting, production design and music. For the storyline is seems like it should be nominated for Worst Screenplay and Worst Sequel and win both Razzies. It might be time to end the Sex and the City universe and the 40-something foursome unless they can get back on track with Sex and the City 3 and hopefully be as enjoyable as the TV-show and the first movie. If not then I would have lost all faith in good characters that get ruined in some future sequel. In some parts of the movie I was totally bored while in others I was quite happy because of some brief spirit back from the Sex and the City TV show. In my personal opinion this movie sequel is just an excuse to bring the brilliant foursome back along with great costumes and beautiful scenery, if only there could have been a proper script then it could have been just a long special episode like the first film

I almost don't have anything more to add up to this looong list of complaints and negative reviews. This is a shame on everyone who ever created this amazingly unique show, and not to talk about the actresses (haven't they earned enough to walk away with pride?? and just say NOO?). I just don't understand it. Usually they do trial screenings, nobody ever told them, that PLEASE, for God's sake, stopp this disaster??YES: It is a shameful image of "Europeans-Americans-Civilized" people leaving their comfy cultural boundaries. And the whole Abadilibadu setting is disturbingly childishly nightmareishly idiotic - not like the blood and flesh NYC streets... YES: characters are stupid, and shallow and YES: I will definitely buy a ticket to L.A. and demonstrate naked if they ever start thinking about a 3rd part...and finally NO: you cannot laugh at any of the jokes - simply because they are not funny (don't even dream about the witty and sharp dialogues we got so used to). And come onnnn, I'm a nanny, but when finally Charlotte has 2 kids, and has a full-time nanny, and she doesn't even work, and gets a nervous breakdown, crying in the closet???!! Huh.Think it over. 2,5 hours. And I thought that the first was bad...p.s.: Will always love the serials....no matter what...but please, no moreee

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the 1st movie but still alright
reviews.content: Summary: Good not great. If you miss the ladies, you'll want to see it regardless.The 1st sex and the city movie was a gem to me. I loved it, I thought it was bright and all us SATC fans were dying to catch up with the characters and where they'd been since the series. There were also surprises in it Steve cheating!, the way Carrie gets left at the alter, Charlotte pregnant.SATC2 had none of that in my opinion.NO SURPRISES: I really wasn't surprised about anything. Aidan is back (OK we all knew that), Charlotte gets a nanny, Miranda quits her job, nothing really earth shattering here.WHY: I had heard about Penelope Cruz being in this movie for a while now and that she would be a potential other love interest for BIG. While I don't care much for her I thought, hmm OK, interesting twist, I can see a good complication there for Carrie. Nope. She was there for 1 scene -maybe 5 mins and poof no more Penelope. I ask myself, really? Why was she even in the movie? They could have hired any good looking woman with decent acting skills to play that role. I kept thinking she would pop up again later (possibly BIG cheating on Carrie with Penelope after hearing her Aidan news) but it never happened. Pointless.SMITH: Why tease the audience with Smith reconnecting with Samantha if he wasn't going to even be a real part of this story? Other than him helping Sam connect with the guy wanting to build hotels he wasn't really in this movie. Again, huh? Pointless deux.A PLUS: SATC2 does have something going for it that the original did not. The characters were more themselves this time around--or rather more in line with the personalities seen on the series were. I always felt the 1st movie was great but the characters were a wee bit different, almost too evolved. I missed these girls more--they were funnier.The Clothes: I'm not sure why I've seen repeated reviews about the clothes sucking in this movie because I have to disagree. I thought they were great. Fashion is ever evolving and I happen to think Pat Fields did a great job keeping these girls looking great but all with their distinct personal style. Great to see Miranda not looking 100 percent perfect all the time and having some casual attire moments. She was way way too dressy in the 1st one (although stylishly so). And Carrie back to wearing see thru dresses with visible panties, tacky but that was the Carrie I remember, glad to see that part of her still exists!BIG and Carrie: Loved seeing them together more and their domestic issues. I think the best part of their scenes came when he picked her up at her old place. There was a collective awww in the crowd. Loved it. Though I think BIG forgave her too fast for the kiss, but whatever. And is it me or is Chris Noth looking 50 million times better than the 1st movie. He lost weight and is looking great!General Plot: A bit all over the place in my opinion. I think they were trying to do too much at once and I don't think it always worked. I also think that most of the fans, love the New York of SATC and would have preferred to spend most of the time there versus abu dhabi. I would have also loved to see Carrie writing more. Did we really see her writing much at all in this movie? Blink and you missed it.Lastly: Was anyone else wondering why those Liza Minelli scenes lasted so long? And was anyone else as disturbed as I was? No offense to the Liza fans but eh...I think we could have done without most of it. Just like the girls singing. It was cute, but did it need to go on so long?In Short: Don't get me wrong, I didn't hate the movie but I'm not sure it lived up to my expectation of what I had hoped it would be. The ladies themselves were in fine form though. Personally better than they were the 1st go round. They may want to take more time creating a better script (as with the 1st one) if they decide to do a SATC3.

reviews.review_title: Not much of a movie, a simple story for Sex in the City fans, nothing else.
reviews.content: I am not a Sex in the City fan, I have never watched an episode of the TV series, but I do like SJ Parker (and her husband, Ferris Buehler).In this nominal sequel to the first Sex-City movie, Sarah Jessica Parker is back as the main character of Carrie Preston. Half of the story here is her marriage to Mr Big, now that they have settled into a routine she becomes disappointed that the excitement seems to be gone from their relationship. He clearly loves her, and is faithful to her, but he is mainly content with eating in and watching old movies on the TV in their bedroom. She missed the excitement of courtship.A second theme involves Samantha getting invited by an old boyfriend to Abu Dhabi for a week, all-expenses paid. She agrees under one circumstance, that she can take her three best friends with her. So much of the movie has them enjoying themselves there, including some shopping, and a few mishaps.In the end Carrie and Mr Big come to a better understanding of what each needs and they are destined to live happily ever after.Kim Cattrall is Samantha Jones, Kristin Davis is Charlotte York Goldenblatt, and Cynthia Nixon is Miranda Hobbes.Not much of a movie, for Sex-City fans only.

This movie is really stupid. Looks like they just wanted to wreck the reputation of the original series. I don't know who wrote the script. The ladies are just typical stupid ignorant American women being oblivious to other country's tradition and custom. Just pure stupid.

What can one say about SATC2? There were some fun fashion moments, and a few genuine attempts at irony. The overall storyline was banal. Most of the one-liners were tiresome to terrible. I've made a List Ridiculous of ten of the worst moments:1. CARRIE: "York? What happened to Goldenblatt?"CHARLOTTE: "It's the Middle East."CARRIE: "It's the new Middle East."CHARLOTTE: "It's the Middle East."2. CARRIE: "You knew when you married me I'm more Coco Chanel than coq au vin!"3. The whole big fat gay wedding. Really.4. CHARLOTTE wears off-white vintage Valentino while baking cupcakes with 2- and 5- year-olds. I say fair game on the hand prints. In fact, she was practically begging for it.5. SAMANTHA's behavior throughout. Especially in Abu Dhabi. Enough said.6. That SAMANTHA's assistant didn't up and walk after witnessing her boss shove hormones up her @$%& and, to add insult to unsanitary injury, use a touch screen. Seriously. 7. "Interfriention"? That's so bad I'm afraid to contemplate it.8. That these spoiled women freak out about a $22,000/night charge on a first-class hotel suite without for a minute considering that one day's wardrobe for each of them costs more than that.9. A five-carat black diamond? "Because you are not like anyone else"? After cheating with her former fiancÃ©? This is no only ridiculous, it's ludicrous. These people deserve each other. Thank God they are not like anyone else. The world would collapse from greed, childishness and stupidity. 10. SAMANTHA: This $&^*%#! economy. We need to go somewhere rich!I wanted to like this film. Or at least not hate it. My favorite thing about SATC 2: Carrie's opening outfit. But that's a long 2 1/2 hours for all the other rubbish. MIRANDA gets some kudos for attempting class, but loses points for shouting "Abu Dhabi Doo" out of a limousine. If you like the SATC franchise, you may give it 4 out of 10... at the most.

reviews.review_title: The Talking Horse & her creepy pals
reviews.content: The four gals who think that they are the hottest chics on earth hit the streets again to give it away to anyone that can sniff them out. Not much story, just style. If you liked the old Mr. Ed TV series, you will love this.

Wow so many bad reviews! I love the acting and I love Sarah Jessican Parker, she is so beautiful and has such a nice personality in the movie. She always looks so glamorous throughout the movie as do the other woman. All the characters are unique and different but all friends and it is so interesting to see all of their personalities blend together. This was better than the first and better than the TV show! I loved seeing them in another countries interacting with the other cultures. Many thought they were being prejudice and that Americans don't always respect other cultures. There is some truth to that in that Americans tend to think they are superior and that they were visiting another country and just mocking them for wearing burqa (is that what they call the coverings?)but they later made friends with them and learned something about them.While I am not for woman covering themselves (and perhaps many women in that country are not either) I do not feel it would be my place to visit a country and point and mock their culture, but I think they were taught that these housewives had personalities and opinions and refuting any stereotypes they might have. I can honestly say I have never even heard of that country they visited, but it was awesome to see it. I loved the part at the end when Carry gave the butler money to visit his wife. There were some faults of the movie, like they never really explained what happened to Aidan. (By the way he changed; I thought it was a different actor until I heard his voice). They were vague about why Davis resolved her feelings about the nanny; I thought they were implying she was a lesbian, but I was not clear. Also when the one (I forgot her name) but you will know what I mean, went to jail, they never explained where her boyfriend went and why he was not helping her out, like if he was in jail it would not be his fault But he was back with her at the end. Also, some of the scenarios make you unsympathetic of the characters but they are comical, and make you laugh. Like when Davis got the kids painted hands on her skirt cause she wanted her mother to give her more attention, I was laughing. I know how stressful kids could be, but its hard to be sympathetic to a woman who's biggest problem is a ruined skirt (who wears a designer skirt around the home, and that did not seem like her personality in the show or other movie) but yes I know she was really stressed about caring for a baby and it was nice that they showed her like a real mom, I liked how she was not so perfect like she seemed in the first movie. And as far as sympathy goes, she was a stay at home mom with a nanny. Staying home with kids is stressful, but she has hired help. And there whining over having to ride coach was a little annoying, oh my coach, the one who did most of the whining used to be a bar tender, but she is above riding coach? Now it just sounds like I bashed the movie, and most of these things are what made the movie funny. Still all in all it was an interesting movie with great acting.

I have such high regard for Carrie. I just recently started watching the series and it certainly has grown on me. However, this movie was torture. It was simply horrendous. I have been to the middle east and trust me, no one over there is as extreme as they portray them to be in the movie. Of course, if you go around behaving like Samantha, i mean, that's enough to make anyone go a little crazy. The movie starts with no promise and constantly drops in quality from there on. The screenplay and story line was atrocious. The characters, don't get me started. I understand that movies are all about exaggeration and drama queens but this was a tad over the top even for fiction.I cant believe i wasted 2 hours of my day sitting through the entire thing. I seriously hope there isn't a 3rd part.

There is point in the history of a franchise when it is best to hang it up and sadly, that point may have come with this latest outing by the girls of Sex in the City. Naturally, they have all aged. Samantha Jones, now of a grandmotherly age, is like a gay man fighting ruthlessly to hang on to any semblance of sexual attraction, which on screen, is just embarrassing. Carrie Bradshaw, always an acquired taste, has become even more equine looking. Miranda look s like Miranda only slightly feeble and Charlotte York has managed to remain quite the boring character. It is the dialogue though that makes one cringe. Beginning with every gay cliché known to gay man, including a visitation from Liza Minnelli, you would swear this was written from a straight man's version of what gay life must be like. Not worry, it gets deeply, deeply heterosexual as move into the Middle East, where Samantha, who is revealed as a sex addict, gets into trouble because, she is in Muslim country. The fact that these American women seem to be dressing for Anna Wintour not tourism in a country where they could actually get hurt seems besides the point. There are a lot of sub-layers to this film: women's rights, motherhood, relationships, even a passing glance at the difference in cultures throughout the world, but like everything Sex in the City its light, light, light. And sometimes, it's hard to discern light from stupid and so much of this film felt stupid.

The movie was GREAT even better than the first one we went with 10 girls and all love it (our ages are from 20 to 30- so as you can tell our ages are the most suitable for the movie) To be honest I don't know where to begin with.. all these negative comments are just horrible i am sure that any of you who said the movie sucked, never been a truly SATC fan, or to be precise never watched an episode! Guys this is SEX AND THE CITY. It is self- explanatory. How come go to a movie like than and expect cheap clothes or crying over emotional sadness are you out of your minds? This is a fiction if your looking for something more profound go and see the little children! The movie has always been superficial in a way. ALWAYS BEEN SINCE 1998. Its about sex its about fashion and it about women. It is not about reality or situations that we are in. Our only common point is that we are all women and we have the same problems ( children, boring job, marriage issue) and this movie express these issues with a sense of humour. How can you expect Samantha Jones to be serious and crying, of course if you ever watched and episode, and in your case its clear you did not! Definitely go and see the movie, it is better than the first one. It made me laugh so many times and I was almost crying even. It has every value in the movie. It leaves you with a thought and a shopping urge. I highly recommend the movie. PS: I did not even have an account.I just got it to write this comment because the negative comments made me so angry. I can watch it over and over again.

I'm a SAC fan more of obsessed, and loved the 1st movie and also this one is so hilarious, two of my friend were watching it with me and they didn't even watch the show lol it was their first time , and after this movie they watched the whole show and became fans yay lol
So I really don't get the bad reviews!!!! Like seriously
It was a really good fun movie and i watched it over n over n over again

reviews.review_title: Sad soap opera about Peter pan women
reviews.content: I am really grateful I did not go to the theaters to see this. On the other hand, watching it on Blu-ray was painful. The movie was recorded on high-def cameras so you can see everything in amazing realism, and believe me, that's not Carrie and her friends wanted you to see. First of all, women in her mid-fifties (Samantha is 52, the actress portraying her is 54 in 2010) acting like girls in her early twenties. The blu-ray painfully shows the wrinkles, the flaccid skin, etc. Very sad.... Second, the movie locations. While some scenes were actually filmed in Morocco (not Abu Dhabi for sure), many of them were recorded in the studio and you can easily tell that was all fake stuff. It just did not feel real, just like a bad soap opera. Third, the countless bad jokes (not one single laugh!). Very different from the TV show and even the first movie. And by jokes I mean the little gags Samantha throws at men, and some of the ridiculous behaviors in the movie that just denigrate women and gay in general. Fourth, a terrible plot, no story, no character development. The whole thing just felt like a bad Abu Dhabi advertisement, including unnecessary offenses to Muslim religion. Finally, the worst: the ending leaves the story open. I just pray that Sex and the City 3 does not come along. For the sake of a good TV show that had its time, I hope S&C2 did not turn a good profit. Time to move on Carrie! Like a New Yorker critic wrote about her book in the movie, time to go for the silence vow...

This movie got dreadful reviews, so I was curious to judge for myself. I am assuming that nobody would go and watch "Sex & the City" expecting any serious sort of entertainment. Consequently, I was surprised to read the poisonous review of film critics who suddenly realized that Carrie & co. are selfish, spoiled and hedonistically interested only in themselves. This should come as no surprised to anybody familiar with SATC. Anyway, back to the movie: it offers a couple of hours of entertainment without any pretense of being taken seriously. That is, apart from the product placement – I am sure somebody is expecting you to invest big cash in shoes and handbags. However, if you are not easily lured into spending big bucks, it is a relatively safe experience. For me, it was like one of those fantasy movies of the 30's, with Carole Lombard as a millionaire heiress and William Powell as her butler. It is an escapist fantasy for people living during hard times and Willing to spend a couple of hours without worrying about the future – just like during the Depression. Hundreds of such escapist movies were churned out during the Depression and nowadays they are considered classic.I do not want to imply that SATC2 is in any way a classic, but neither is the horrendous movie described by critics. My guess is they were so negative because they would like to live like Carrie & co., but cannot afford it. In fact, not many of us can, but some of us can at least be so sincere as to admit that living like them looks more fun than being a missionary in a rundown village without electricity or running water. Sainthood is not for everyoneI also understand the choice of Middle East as an area relatively untouched by the world economic crisis and as a good location for a luxury fantasy. Having written this I must add that indeed the product placement, the fashion and the greed of the ladies are OTT and feel a bit nauseating. I will not even tackle the subject of disrespect and the Muslim traditions, because it truly does not make any sense in this context.Conclusion: Many critics love violent, dark movies such as the Batman franchise and other action movies. Apparently there is never too much blood, too many car chase scenes or too many bullets flying around. Brutality is always easier to tolerate than frivolity..I do wonder why..

reviews.review_title: Just wait it gets way worse
reviews.content: If you're watching this movie, the 2nd movie based on the original tv show, and you think this one is bad??Just wait!They find all new ways to destroy these amazing characters and change everything we love about the original series snd first movie Just Like That!So much so, you'll be back here re-watching the original series and BOTH movies begging for the original again.....

reviews.review_title: This movie is worse than Hitler
reviews.content: This steaming pile of crap is premiering in high definition where I am, so this is the first time I'm seeing it. I know it's been out for some months now and I knew it was bad, but I had no idea. I feel I must warn the world about its existence. It is like a 2 hour-long infomercial with product placements for any brand dumb enough to be tricked into financing this disgusting heap of vile tripe. It is a celebration of all the superficiality of American consumerism, indeed of everything that is wrong with the world today. Stay away from this bomb, it will declare a ruthlessly efficient blitzkrieg on every one of your brain cells.

Other reviewers warned us all but I figured I could handle the crap on a night I need to turn my mind off. Oh, boy.Carrie was always really annoying, and Big should have done himself a favor and stayed away from her, but she actually manages to get even more annoying in this movie. I just want to reach through the screen and punch her in the face, then reach in her purse for Big's balls and hand them back to him. Trouble is, women like her exist in this world and I see them all the time - that's the saddest and maybe most angering thing about this movie, that such self-absorbed, self-entitled women do exist.Carrie shows utter disappointment when Big gets them state-of-art flat screen TV for their bedroom as an anniversary present. Instead of "thank you" she tells him - tells him! - that "a piece of jewelry would have been nice." The reason he got them the darn TV was that he had found it nice to lie in bed with her in a hotel room and watch old movies *she* likes together.The women just look aged and they try to remain young, which is sad. Just - geez...

I really don't understand people, especially fans which didn't enjoy it! I am not a "fan", I just love the series, have enjoyed the 1st movie and went to this one just to have a good time and see the girls again, like old friends. I have read many bad reviews just before seeing the movie so I was prepared to see nothing special, just fashion, no story line etc...But yesterday... what a surprise I had! I was in the screen during all the movie. I forgot everything: my life, my problems, me...I was with them, completely! And at the end I thought to myself that people didn't understand actually that movie. For example : the gay wedding is too much. OK, but...THEY KNOW IT; they are aware and they're joking about that, about themselves, about everything. The movie is funny, funny, funny, they are not serious. At the same time the movie is not superficial. It's not ABOUT fashion, ABOUT, shoes (not enough shoes by the way ;-) ) It's also about life, friendship, love, passion, etc etc etc...and we have a GREAT TIME!!! It's just a question of understanding! Don't take it too seriously!

****** SOME SPOILERS *******My wife and I were almost in tears of laugher last year as we read a review for this movie In the NY Post that tore it to shred's like it was Steve Buscemi at the end of Fargo. Then we forgot about it until tonight when it appeared on HBO. As we watched the end of The Shawshank Redemption on AMC I noticed that she had a movie recording on the DVR. Once she told me she was recorded this abomination I knew we had to watch it confirm just how bad it truly was.It was worse than Maya Angelou or Robert Frost could possibly describe. Seeing as I do not have their command of the English language let me just say that my wife (who is the biggest SATC fan I know) said "oh my God this is awful" before the movie was half over and every 10 minutes thereafter. It was superficial, materialistic and full of lame dialogue. When my wife asked me if the girls were even pretty I couldn't even answer in the affirmative.Our favorite line was when Samantha fawned over some guy she just met and used the term "Lawrence of my labia". Then the girls fell over in laughter. Charlotte got upset because her daughter ruined a vintage skirt. Why was she wearing it while making cupcakes is the real question. Miranda is such a complainer I'm sure she has trouble getting ass in real life just because her character is so annoying. And the opening scene was a 20 minute gay wedding. The Godfather it was not.Bottom line: there are no redeeming qualities to this movie. Neither woman nor man, young nor old, liberal nor conservative will find anything to like about it. Unless you just like laughing at horrible filmmaking. In that case maybe this does stand up to The Godfather.

Sex and the City 2 (2010): Dir: Michael Patrick King / Cast: Sarah Jessica Parker, Kim Cattrall, Cynthia Nixon, Kristin Davis, Chris Noth: Followup to the successful phenomenon of the first Sex and the City film. Opens at a gay wedding where Carrie is a best man. After the celebration is over Carrie struggles to get her husband to move off the coach. She focuses on writing and agrees to some time apart. When Samantha receives opportunity to travel to an Arabian country she invites the others along. Director Michael Patrick King made the first film as well as being involved in the successful TV show. The girls all go through many wardrobe changes from glittery and glamour to the outright forbidden. Sarah Jessica Parker leads the cast as Carrie, who knows fashion and success but becomes trapped in possible infidelity when an ex appears on the same vacation. Her handling of this is one of the film's honor moments. Kim Cattrall spits out the sexual dialogue at every moment until her outrageous behaviour gains her unwanted attention from authorities. This is an interesting reference to culture and specific laws but unfortunately Samantha's last scene features her beneath a naked male atop a jeep in erotica. Cynthia Nixon leaves a cruel job and takes charge of trip activities. Kristin Davis worries about her gorgeous young nanny and the attention she spurns but the handling of this is a cheap contrivance. Chris Noth plays Carrie's husband and they are on the verge of the next step in their relationship. Not as good as the original but it does ask questions regarding the sequel of marriage vows. Score: 7 / 10

I am a HUGE fan of the series and the first movie. Thanks to all of the "fans" horrible reviews I was scared to go see the sequel...I went to see it tonight and I Abso-f***ing-lutely LOVED it!!!The movie was funny. It isn't meant to be taken super seriously and neither was the series. It is light and fun. To everyone saying that the movie is about nothing...it is about friendship and where these four women are in their relationships. Keeping the spark in your relationship, taking care of children and balancing work and home life are REAL problems and concerns that all women deal with. Bottom line if you are a true fan of Sex and the City please don't let the bad reviews stop you from seeing the girls in this wonderful movie!

reviews.review_title: Indulgent. Don't think about it too much and you'll like it.
reviews.content: While I can't say this was a good movie, I'll say it was an enjoyable one. I laughed, and I even cried during a surprisingly heartfelt scene between Charlotte and Miranda. But I'll qualify that by adding that I made a decision before watching it that I wasn't going to think about the film too much. As someone who regularly studies issues of feminism, gay rights, race & ethnicity, etc., movies are easily ruined for me, so I decided to put all that aside for just one night.That being done, the movie was a spectacle, and it was fun. It oscillated between some more serious issues (e.g., Charlotte getting frustrated with her kids but feeling as though she's not allowed to complain about it because it'll make her a bad mother; or Carrie worrying that she and Big are becoming a boring married couple) and indulgent arrays of couture, luxury resorts, male eye candy, and snarky one-liners.Many reviewers have noted that the film is offensive in its portrayal of the UAE. I would have to amend this statement by saying Samantha is offensive to the UAE. Miranda tries very hard to be the good American tourist and does obsessive research in advance, learns about the words and customs, and tries (about 20 times throughout the movie) to keep Samantha covered. Charlotte and Carrie try to follow her example. Samantha not so much. You don't get a lot of glimpses of the city beyond the hotel, and hotels in Abu Dhabi and Dubai are often more tailored toward what tourists want to see than actual representations of the culture. Yes there were servants and belly dancers and lots of Orientalism, but from what I've seen of luxury resorts in the Middle East (and in other countries), that's how you lure wealthy American tourists. I did get uncomfortable, at times, with Samantha's behavior. I loved her in the first movie, when they finally developed her into a 3-dimensional character. Now we're back to the Samantha of the TV show, pre-final season.I also have to say, I like that there is a film out there that takes women in their 40s and 50s and shows them still living life beyond the husband. By that I mean so many films featuring female characters end with the girl getting the guy. It's nice to see someone at least attempt to explore what happens beyond that. It may be someone obsessing over her marriage, or someone being afraid she's selling out if she takes a break from work, or someone still trying to live the fabulous single life when she's past menopause (which, aside from Blanche Devereaux, we haven't seen that much of), and this film may not be the most valiant effort, but at least it's something.Final thoughts on this film: if you loved the show not for any in-depth feminist questions it raised, but to see girls having fun, wearing great clothes, and living exciting lives, you'll probably like the film a lot. If you loved the show at all, you'll probably at least enjoy the film.If you can set aside the fact that a group of four women going on a camel ride through the desert need one set of outfits for the limo ride to the camels, one set for riding the camels (all couture), and one set for lunch under a tent during a camel-ride break, and just roll with it, then nothing should stop you from seeing this film.

reviews.review_title: Don't hate if it's not your genre!!!!!
reviews.content: A lot of bad reviewers are just haters, SAVE VOTING FOR PEOPLE WHO ENJOY THE GENRE!! I don't get why people have to hate on movies if they don't like the genre, just don't watch it in the first place because then you're biased. This movie is enjoyable and funny!!!!!!! You just have to watch it with friends and you'll have stuff to talk about and things to recognize within your own relationships/life. It takes you out of this world into a glamorous/rich world for a while which is nice. I found some of the outfits really over the top, who would wear some of those in real life? But that's why it is a movie, to entertain and take us to another place. Don't think about it too much, just enjoy!!

reviews.review_title: The only thing good about this movie was the outfits
reviews.content: This movie was not good. The storyline was boring. It started off good with the wedding but just went downhill from there...I would have enjoyed a back story on Stanford and his husband. The entire trip was boring/bad acting and kind of in poor taste. This was not like the first movie and not at all like the show. It looks like they spent a lot of money on the glam of the movie without thinking of the actual plot.

Where do you start? The first movie was just okay, even if I did enjoy Carrie beating the crap out of Mr. Big with her wedding bouquet.
But the second movie? Let's see, we have 4 ladies, not aging very well, whining about their rich lady lives. Charlotte is worried about her Irish nanny's looks. So fire her and hire an older lady. Carrie is bored with her rich, wealthy, charming husband that she chased for 10 years before he finally put a ring on her finger. The guy works all day? He's not allowed to come home and hang out on the couch? Sorry Carrie. That's what people do. They don't walk around in designer clothes and high heels and hit a party every night. And they don't put on bad eyeliner and hit on their married ex-boyfriends. Miranda, now that she has her husband back, is annoyed about her 6 figure job. You're a lawyer. Get a new job.
And then we come to Samantha. Are we supposed to believe that a high powered public relations company owner is dropping her panties in her office to do her hormone cream? Doesn't she have a bathroom? And people are supposed to believe that a professional woman with her money smarts would be all out of control over a random man in the Middle East and risk getting herself arrested? And that she wouldn't research first what she could and couldn't bring into a foreign country?
And I REALLY hated their stupid "I am woman" karoake moment. My God, was that ever cringeworthy and annoying.
I loved the TV show. I tolerated the first movie. With the second movie, it's time to retire the girls. I'm glad Kim Cattrall and Sarah Jessica Parker hate each other so much that one won't be made.

Dreadful kibosh about a quartet of middle-aged U.S. scrubbers with too much money and time on their hands travelling to the Middle East to get laid. I took my 'Mamma Mia' loving wife along and even she was bored. Racial stereotyping abounds, not what we expect in a 21st century movie. You wait ages for the 'sex' to get going and then its about as thrilling as watching afternoon repeats of 'Murder She Wrote'. What I found really offensive is that women have for years whined incessantly about being stereotyped in major motion pictures as brainless sex objects, yet here they are being featured that way all over again and they don't seem to mind. I was reminded of the 1977 feature film of 'Are You Being Served'. You know the sort of thing: "hey, we're in a movie! Let's go abroad!", but at least that flick had the gorgeous ( and alas deceased ) Wendy Richard as compensation. 'S.A.T.C. 2' has nothing. It is a tedious, flatly-directed shambles of a movie, not even bad enough to laugh at. 'Valley Of The Dolls' ( 1967 ) was 'Citizen Kane' by comparison. Avoid. 'S.A.T.C. 3'? Forget it!

reviews.review_title: What a horrible piece of celluloid or digital capture
reviews.content: I should have copied and pasted this review from somebody else who bashed it, because I already wrote too many reviews today and to write one for another crap movie just made it all the harder.I believe that I watched 3 TV shows of this and they had really offered little to no entertainment to me and this did even less.To see this on silkscreen is like watching a 2 hour tampon commercial shot in New York City and in Dubai with a larger cast and a larger budget.It's boring, bland and just dreadful to see this on a large screen when I can watch a 30 second commercial of a tampon commercial or makeup cosmetic commercial and have it over much more quickly.Blahhhhhhhhh....Yukkkkkkkkkkkk...crap extended and what makes this worse is that I even sat through it instead of going back home and going to sleep.

reviews.review_title: It's a film called Sex and the City NOT War and Peace
reviews.content: This is the first time I have written a review and what better a start than after all the scathing reviews (the one's I have read have been mainly by Men by the way). I loved the series and also the first film too and was itching to see the 2nd movie. Well I saw it Sunday with my best friend and Mother in Law and we Loved it, it was funny, great to look at and we liked the fact they travelled to another country for the second half of the movie. Liza Minelli was hilarious and the gay wedding was like a movie set with swans et all. I do think the clothes in the first movie were better and more memorable but Patricia Field still did a great job in dressing the girls for each occasion. My favourite Carrie outfit was the one she wore when she dined with Aiden. This is a movie NOT real life, so many haters on here, I beg the question, why did you go to see it if you didn't like the series/first film etc!!I do hope they make no 3, I will be a fan for life and it is only a fairytale when its on screen so people don't take it too seriously, lifes too short.

reviews.review_title: Time to hang up the Manolo's?
reviews.content: I love the Sex in the City girls and it's great to spend time with them now and again. The first film outing of the TV series was okay, but not great, so a 2nd? Well, yes I paid money to see this at the cinema and really it could have waited for DVD-it's perfect fodder for a Sunday afternoon- but I'm not sure whether they should have bothered.Times have changed, the girls are older, more settled and I'm not sure I like them like that. I think I prefer them younger and more frivolous. It didn't seem right to see Carrie fretting about furniture. At 2 and half hours this is way too long and whilst the budget is bigger, the story is light and not very exciting. In fact nothing really happens and what does is overly predictable and some a little cheesy - the girls singing 'I am Woman' at karaoke made me cringe, as did the 'gag' of the girls wearing burka's at the end.There are some things to enjoy: there are still some amazing clothes (although, some of the outfits they wore whilst visiting Abu Dhabi, seemed stupidly over the top: the outfit Carrie wears to the souk was outrageous). There is plenty of gayness: in fact Liza Minelli singing and dancing to Beyonce's 'Single Ladies' at a gay wedding that also has a gay mens chorus and white swans may be the gayest thing ever on film. But despite this there is something lacking. It feels flat and rather flaccid compared to the TV series. The sex talk has gone, the sex scenes and flesh are very tame and there isn't the cracking one liners (it is Samantha who has the best declaring a new man will be her 'Lawrence of her labia'). But there isn't as much fun in it and some of it bordered on cheap gags-the nanny and her bouncing bossum for instance, it's not Benny Hill...this and much else seemed way beyond something Sex would have done in it's original format.It's also a shame that they felt they had to drag all the characters into this, Aiden being in Abu Dhabi as well, just seemed too convenient, but then if that had happened, there really wouldn't have been much else to the story. I'm not sure they should hang their Manolo's up, but they should certainly consider changing into something a little more comfortable.More of my reviews at my site: iheartfilms.weebly.com

Like many other reviewers, I was a BIG fan of the series, and although the first movie wasn't great, and despite the mediocre (being nice) initial reviews, I decided to give this a go. So I settled in with two girlfriends, and all it took was the first setting of Stanford and Anthony's wedding to know this wasn't going to be anything like the series and I'm amazed this was actually by the same people. As Carrie said later in the movie "I don't think we're in Kansas anymore". My friends and I watch disbelieving as Liza Minelli "performed" Beyonce, and a couple of strangers told Carrie and Big they were basically doomed to be lonely or bad people just for not wanting children. We were shocked, and I have to say, embarrassed. The high point was the re-emergence of Smith. A high point which lasted all of 4, 5 minutes?! Then pretty inexplicably we're off to UAE, and Miranda was treating us to Abu Dhabi for Dummies for most of the remainder of the film. Aidan's re-appearance felt completely contrived, against character and un-needed, and he disappeared again just as non-sensically. Samantha managed to insult an entire culture, and apparently get away with it - and I'm sorry, the character was never stupid, nor that dismissive of culture and beliefs. It felt completely pointless and against all previous laws of SATC. The best part, and I did genuinely laugh, was Charlotte being drunk. And if that's the best part, then we're in trouble. So Carrie loses her passport, and miraculously it's still in the market, so endeth another 2 minute plot. And the girls escape an angry mob by yet again insulting the culture before the end of the movie which again seemed to come from nowhere and dis-count the previous 2 hours... All in all, a very big disappointment, against the series and characters, non-sensical and pointless plots, embarrassing and uncomfortable at times. At its height SATC was never about full on comedy, it was real life drama that we could relate to. My friend turned to me at the end and said "I didn't know we were watching a Carry On film", and I couldn't have put it better myself.

reviews.review_title: What the critics are not going to understand
reviews.content: I have never written a movie review before, but I am honestly too frazzled with the extraordinary ignorance of "critics." I will be the first to admit that the execution of this movie could have been better; I would have liked to to see greater development on Miranda and Carrie's story lines (they missed a great opportunity there.) I do not believe the movie built an adequate momentum to support its very promising premise. Additionally, I think they should have fleshed out how Big stepped-in to quell Carrie's concerns. This movie speaks to the very old axiom about the cathartic nature of reaching life-long goals, the accompanying fears and writing the rules for your own relationship. Personally, I have been in many relationships that have defied convention, the approval of my friends/family, and even sometimes, my own beliefs. This is part of the learning process. (Men typically will not understand this as they expect women to conform to their man's expectations, thus they don't think anything of the difficulties women endure in "shrinking to fit.") Everyone has been disappointed by an achievement or milestone not delivering the happiness it foretold. Honestly, it is so easy for everyone to hop on a "bandwagon," following "critics" more concerned with how their insulting barbs enhance their own reputations, as opposed to critically evaluating intent and execution. With regards to the "racist" nature of the movie, the fact of the matter is that what was portrayed was accurate in terms of Middle-Eastern Culture- women are REQUIRED to dawn those garbs, and Samantha commits an infraction that MANY Americans make by attempting to impose her American culture over the customs of a foreign country. The accusation of racism was made by persons pertaining to that faith and culture, because it is portrayed pejoratively when juxtaposed with American standards. This movie is a Valentine to anyone who has ever feared life's many transitions, not being able to meet new challenges, and/or loosing themselves in the process.

The charm of the original 'Sex and the City' series is that women can relate to each of the awkward, ditsy, clumsy, sex crazed working gal. SATC2 bombed! It took all the charm away and presented a bunch of over the hill photoshopped perfect New Yorkers on a glamorous all expense holiday? I don't want to see that! It was detached from reality and completely over the top. The girls are all well groomed in their perfect little lives with their perfect apartments, loving husbands and massive wardrobe. Yet still find pointless sh*t to complain about, now you're just being a difficult rich b*tch. And then there's Samantha (Cattrall) who's now an overly successful 52 year old child. It makes me cringe.The first scene started on the wrong foot, with cheap gimmicks seen at an exaggerated gay wedding with an ice palace, swans, choir singers and Liza Minnelli. Who looked like she was about to drop dead after her 'single ladies' performance *cringe again*. Followed by eye-rolling, gag worthy and head shaking scenes one after the other. No interesting controversial topics were brought up. No clever cute humour. All in all, a lame over the top exaggeration about nothing.http://musingsandmorsels.weebly.com/

SEX AND THE CITY 2, at its core, has a fairly good story and script by Michael Patrick King (with bows to Candace Bushnell and Darren Star who created the original HBO series) - issues that face older girls post marriage and menopause. But those tidbits get buried in the embarrassingly extravagant production that reeks of misspent funds attempting to make the show a crowd pleaser. It didn't work in the theaters and it doesn't seem to work on DVD. It is especially sad to watch this self-indulgent film because there are some really fine actors involved. Not only is the original quartet of high flying comediennes intact - Sarah Jessica Parker, Cynthia Nixon, Kim Cattrall. Kristin Davis - but the leftover men - David Eigenberg, Evan Handler, Jason Lewis, Chris Noth, John Corbett - are also pulled into the redux, each appearing a bit tired of the attempt to update what had been a good show. There is no real story: after an insulting wedding of tow gay men, Samantha is invited to Abu Dhabi for a PR swing and of course she takes her girlfriends along, each of whom is having conflicts in their marriage or mothering status. The trip simply allows for the constant costume changes that are appallingly grotesque to be shown in contrast to the social mores of the Arab Emirates (burka wearing women contrasting with the flamboyant quartet) and many lessons on how to identify the old 'ugly American' tourist. But of course, the trip's influence on the ladies makes them appreciate what their lives are truly like in New York...la la la. There are very brief appearances by Liza Minnelli, Penélope Cruz, Miley Cyrus, Tim Gunn etc that only seem to underscore the expensive budget of this Redux. If the viewer is able to get past these obstacles and hear the tiny bits of advice for women a la Carrie Bradshaw Preston's journalism, this can be an entertaining evening. It is just not worth the final tab. Grady Harp

reviews.review_title: Great movie, a true full feature film version of the series
reviews.content: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, it was fast paced and truly funny. I must confess that I didn't always like the series, I only really started enjoying it from season 4 onwards and then when the first movie came out I was a little disappointed. I didn't dislike it and even enjoyed it in some parts, but it missed the fun spark that the series had. I mostly put this down to it being too difficult to make a 20 minute comedy/dramady series engaging enough for the big screen. But, with the sequel they had oodles of spark, one of the few times I actually enjoyed the sequel more than the original. Or could it be, that because the series came first, then the movie and then the sequel, that this actually falls under the "the 3rd installment is almost always (nearly) as good as the original and waaay better than sequel" rule?

reviews.review_title: This sequel is what the first movie should have been!
reviews.content: I went into this movie with little hopes, after hearing the critical mauling it had received I thought to myself "oh please.. one of my favourite shows of all time.. don't be a big old mess". So I had lowered my expectations and took the movie for what it was.. an all new extra long episode, that I used to look forward to on a Friday night back in the day. I have to admit seeing the first movie I was extremely let down, but after repeated viewings I now appreciate the story it had to tell, our girls are all older now and have new chapters in their lives. And I must admit I was hooked, it had all the same sparkle the show had when It first aired, the cast all accounted for done an amazing job with what they had to work with. Samantha again stole the show with her nympho quips and one liners, Charlotte played up her "pookeepsied herself" joke with an all new set of embarrassments, Miranda had lightened up and of course Carrie, is still our Carrie, only she is married and pondering so. You'll laugh, you cheer, you'll cry... Sex and the City.. how i have missed you! Don't believe the negative reviews and critic bashing.. go with an open mind. BIG THUMBS UP!!

reviews.review_title: Superficial pandering to all women that was just disgusting
reviews.content: It's two years later, I've become much more cynical about "Sex and the City", and each of the 4 girls is having problems in their shallow, designed life. The quality of the writing is decreasing rapidly. These are barely even characters anymore, just stick-figures to hang dresses on and caricatures of their audience. The film-makers are just pandering to women between the ages of 30 and 60 and finding superficial things in the characters for them to relate to. I was disgusted by their constant ass-kissing of their target audience. It was very unnatural, but then again at least they know their target audience, somewhat.Of course the depiction of Abu Dhabi was superficial, but that was to be expected. The entire point of this film was for women to feel empowered and to want to buy expensive clothes. For those of us who see through the disgusting glam, that point is hanging on a very thin understanding of women.Despite the poor writing and embarrassing attempt to please all women, the actors were still able to connect me to these characters and keep me emotionally invested throughout. I was watching because I knew Aidan (John Corbett) was back. They gave me most of the things I wanted to hear but the Aidan-Carrie storyline wasn't exactly what I wanted. And the entire point of the movie was to give us what we wanted! But with a two and a half hour run time, I can guarantee that "Sex and the City 2" will give you some of what you wanted, and a lot of stuff that you don't want.

reviews.review_title: A Commercial Video About Rich Bitches Going To The New Middle East
reviews.content: After the highly overrated TV series, disastrous first movie comes the downright desperate and advertisement called 'Sex and the City 2'. Filled with clichés and caricatures with whiny bitches in the key roles, branded products competing with one another as they flutter for attention on screen even if it's just for a few seconds, miserable writing and ignorance towards culture among many many other things, this movie is plain crap. But I knew that anyway and I watched it with friends in order to laugh our asses off at the crappiness of this commercial garbage. 'Sex and the City' was always a sexist show and of course the films don't deviate from that. As badly as the characters are written, Samantha has been an exception if one can ignore the first movie and Kim Cattrall manages to entertain as well as Cynthia Nixon whose role here is almost nothing. 'Sex and the City 2' mainly focuses on one of the most annoying characters on TV (and now in movies), Carrie Burtshaw. Sarah Jessica Parker just whines and wears so-called-expensive clothes that look quite hideous. She has no sense of fashion nor can she act. One of the most unintentionally funniest sequences were that of the 'New Middle East'. In order to go against stereotype, 'Sex and the City 2' reaches new heights of stupidity.

Sex and The City 2It is very important for a woman to have girlfriends that are not only caring and compassionate but also wear the same size as her.Fortunately, besides being fluent in fashion, the four females in this franchise follow-up are also interminable conservationists.When Samantha (Kim Cattrall), Charlotte (Kristin Davis), Miranda (Cynthia Nixon) and Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker) are invited to Abu Dhabi, their Western ways, PDA and abhorrence of Muslim culture lands them in hot water with the locals.What's more, an old beau causes Carrie to question her marriage to Mr. Big (Chris Noth).A scant improvement over its 2008 predecessor, S&TC2 finds the characters returning to their crude confabs; unfortunately, those rude roundtables are interspersed with condemnations on how Muslim women dress.I mean, come on, how would we feel if four Muslim women came here and started complaining about how we let our daughters dress like sluts? (Red Light)

I was a fan of the show. The first movie, not as good as the show. Not as funny as the show. But it was entertaining.The 2nd film was made with the sole purpose of cashing in some money and I wonder if they actually did... Carrie, Charlotte, Samantha and Miranda are... how do I put it... too OLD.I could not concentrate on the movie because I kept looking at those bad bad BAAAD botox injections trying to be hidden by lavish hairstyles, lots of make-up and flashy clothes. These women are well past their prime. The show as on top about 12, 13 years ago!! It is no longer fun to still portray Samantha as a whore when she is over 50, the arghile scene was let's say, humiliating at best. Charlotte complaining while her face couldn't move and Miranda looking 200... They looked like a complete parody of their former selves.There is a reason this show was a hit... Sexy, professional adult women in the big city.This Abu Dhabi film made it looked like retired, desperate women looking to have sex or complaining about their husbands and flashing clothes and their lifestyle and etc.. Sort of like "Real Housewives of UAE".BTW.. it hurts like hell to say this.. but the guys in the film -in real life- would never ever hit on a woman like Samantha.. not like the one in the film. She looked 70.

I was really looking forward to Sex and the City 2 but didn't expect it to be as good as it was. The first movie was good but a little long winded! This was slinky and chic and I loved it so much i've seen it twice and I want to see it again!! I was entertained from beginning to end! There has been a wide range of opinions on the movie and lots of people were disappointed but I must of been watching the movie without tinted glasses, because it was fantastic It lived up to the glam,fashion and fabulousness of series...Brilliant!! However, the Arab situations in the movie might of been offending to some people and I understand it, but I didn't and it did not ruin the film for me at all! So no worries there!! I personally love this movie and was ten times better than the first one, and I would totally recommend Sex and the City 2 for people who love fashion, glam, humour,the Sex and the City series and even people who are willing tohave fun and people who don't get easily offended!! Also don't listen to the critics because they ruin the experience! 10/10 for me...and i now want to go and watch it!!!

reviews.review_title: Everything you thought it would be - and more
reviews.content: I guess it was obvious from the very beginning that the sequel to Sex and the City wouldn't become critics' favorite; but it's not that type of movie that yearns their acceptance. It's not as much about deeper meanings, as it is about having fun, letting your imagination go wild, along with your inhibitions.And as far as the fun part is concerned, SATC2 is a blast. It's pretty much SATC, but bigger, better, louder and shinier.Not that it doesn't have flaws. The product placement is, as always, very annoying. The storyline is a bit too much sometimes, and it seems like the story gets out of hand more than once or twice. Carrie's inner monologues have lost their wit and smarts, even though she still delivers great lines when faced with other people. Samantha is her usual self, the one that she's always been. But it's Miranda's and Charlotte's characters that steal the show. Miranda was finally given a chance to sparkle, be fun and brave, something that's been missing in the first part. Davis' performance is extraordinary, and it really shows when York is facing real emotional problems with her family.Overall, it's a gay fantasy - it's bold, sparkling and bigger than life. It's not a cinematographic masterpiece, but it's a whole lot of fun.

reviews.review_title: Ruined the legacy of the series.
reviews.content: Should have left well enough alone, but the greed got to them. This movie is absolutely pointless and downright embarrassing, let alone as a sequel to the series. Just stop.

reviews.review_title: This is Sex and the City 2010
reviews.content: For all of you who rated 1 star or thought it was a bad movie: what did you expected to see? These ladies are not on their 30's anymore. They have families, husbands, houses to take care of, and hormonal problems too. Time goes by young girls, and we'll all go through these stuff. I think it was a great movie, funny, glamorous, and it was letting us know that there is another part of the world which we just don't know and it is also great, different but great too. It shows that we are all different but we have all the same rights on each of our culture. I think this movie was clever, funny, glamorous and Sex and the City as I expected to be for this 2010.

If you watched/loved the series go ahead and watch/re-watch. It's not meant to be life changing just some simple viewing. I re-watched after watching the series over in lockdown and based on the shocking reviews I read her incase I missed something and loved it again. If anything avoid the first film, that was depressing.

Well your either going to love this film or hate it. I must admit I aren't sure I loved it, but i really did like it. Its not as bad as the rough write up's make it out to be thats for sure. Its definitely not Sex In The City as you all know it to be. I certainly don't think its as good as the first film either. The girls all take a trip away and most of the film is based around that. Its also a story around taking Carrie's relationship to the next level now she is a married woman, shows motherhood in a relatively true light and Samantha is still Samantha, she doesn't change, which means she is still trying to have sex with anything remotely good looking, has no respect for anything, especially the residents of where she goes on holiday and has to try and come to terms with the fact that maybe she is going through menopause. In the end there is a price to pay for how she has behaved although she certainly doesn't change her ways, she is still Samantha. It all makes for good fun and an interesting storyline. But if you're wanting something more to the original Sex And The City - then this might not be for you, as you don't see much City! Sex And The City aside I gave the film a 7 not as a sequel or an accompaniment to a series,but as a film.

The opening credits of the film had my heart believing that I had not wasted my time and money, but I was unfortunately mistaken! Great choices of music throughout the movie, I am sure I'll buy the soundtrack when it is released. Some incredible outfits that the ladies wore too, they were fun to look at. Some guest appearances which seemed a bit pointless.... The characters which we loved from the series and the 1st movie are non existent in this movie. It seems they have become caricatures of their former selves. Wait till it comes on T.V. and don't waste your hard earned money at the theater!!

Me and my girlfriends are huge SATC fans and have been waiting for this movie to come out for an extremely long time and have been so excited. Having read all of the terribly bad reviews I was sad at the thought that I might not enjoy the movie, but it was fantastic!!!!!!I thought the first film was great but if anything this second film was better. Yes the first film was more gritty and emotional but that also made it a bit of a somber experience, whereas this second film had really lightened up and was fun from start to finish. I know a lot of people were disappointed that the girls didn't stay in New York and have complained that there was no storyline, but of course there was! We had already seen the girls in the first film fall in love with their husbands and realise they were the men that they wanted to be with and as they grow older their stresses in their lives move away from having to find the right man, now they need to worry about...... trying to keep the spark alive in a marriage where the husband wants to watch TV.... trying to take care of young children.... having bad bosses at work and feeling unappreciated. This story was about the girls getting away from it all together miles away from home so they were able to unwind, have fun and go back to their lives and families with fresh eyes and appreciate what they have got. Why should the fact that Carrie kissed Aidan turn into a 3 hour problem? Why can't it be solved in 10 minutes by 2 adults who have been together for a zillion years who clearly love each other? Sometimes I think people want drama where it isn't needed and instead should be content with having a giggle and seeing their favourite characters back on the big screen.I went to see this film with 7 of my girlfriends and we all really enjoyed ourselves and had a lovely night out. If you are a SATC fan you will be going to see this movie regardless of the reviews so I hope that you all enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Michael Patrick King what have you done?
reviews.content: I have loved Sex in the City since the show first came out. It was ground breaking and trend setting. Although the characters at time made you want to shake them and scream "Grow up" in the end they all had redeemable qualities. While the first movie failed to fully capture the magic of the show it was still enjoyable. Not so with the sequel. It starts off with the marriage of Stanford and Anthony.
