The wedding really serves no purpose but introduce an extremely nosy couple who make Carrie who was happy before start to question her marriage to Big. The question she has isn't, are we truly happy, or did I marry the right guy. Her question is does the fact that she and Big are not going out every night mean they're are a boring old couple with no social life? So instead of sitting down and talking with her husband like a grown up she runs off to her old apartment to hide for a few days. Miranda mean time is having issues with her boss she quits her job, and thats pretty much Miranda's whole storyline for the rest of the movie, done in the first 20 min. Charlotte finds motherhood to stressful and demanding on her despite the fact that she is a stay at home mom with a live in nanny. When Samantha makes a comment about the always bra less nanny Charlotte starts to worry that her wonderful devoted husband will have an affair. Samantha spends the entire movie trying to keep her sex drive up during menopause. When Samantha is invited by a rich sheik to visit his property in Abu Dabi and possibly do PR for him, something which any smart business woman would have seen as the opportunity of a lifetime, the girls decide to run away from their problems and go with her. Once they are in Abu Dabi the film gets even worse. The sheik is wonderfully generous flying them in first class, giving them the best suite in the hotel, each their own private butler, and every other comfort they could want. Samantha, who is supposed to be a successful business woman, should be treating this trip as a business trip but instead can only think of sex, and thumbing her nose at middle eastern culture. Charlotte is a bumbling idiot the entire trip. Miranda spends the trip trying to keep Samantha from getting thrown in jail for lewd behavior and trying to get the others to have some fun. Carrie mean while is still pondering her marriage. As she was leaving for the trip Big admitted to her he kind of liked the two days off when she left before and thinks they should do that every week. Carrie who started the whole thing by running off in the first place, worries about what this means for their marriage. While in Abu Dabi Carrie runs into Aiden her ex-fiancé, who she broke up with because he liked to stay in, eat KFC and watch baseball, and Carrie decides he might be the perfect replacement for Big who she's mad at because he likes to stay in, eat Japanese take out, and watch old movies and Deadliest Catch. Their time in Abu Dabi ends with them being asked to leave the hotel because Samantha can not control behavior. While leaving Carrie realizes that she left her passport back in the market place so all four go back for it. Charlotte in the mean time is acting like an idiot again and while being run out of town can only think of getting souvenirs for Harry and the girls. This leads to a scene with Samantha being accused of stealing a purse while her year supply of condoms comes spilling out for all to see. What does Samantha do? Does she do the classy thing and scoop her possession quietly. No she makes a scene and enrages a crowd of angry men. By this time in the movie I was routing for the mob of angry men to kick all but Miranda's ass. The movie then wraps up quickly and neatly with a bunch of voice overs, a quick crappy end to a crappy movie. I once loved Sex in the City. It used to have the best one liners ("oh my God she's fashion roadkill" and "I've been shoe shamed" were two of my favs) However in this movie we were treated to lame one liners like "Abu Dabi do" and "he's Lawrence of my labia". I actually cringed in embarrassment when I heard those lines. We also got the totally classy scenes of Samantha in her office with her panties around her ankles rubbing hormone cream on her female parts and later deep throating a pipe in a bar. And don't even get me started in the fashion. This show used to be trend setting with that, but every time Carrie and Samantha came out in a new outfit I heard other women the theater mumble how ugly it was. The writers, producers, and stars of this movie need to stop milking this franchise and let us remember these ladies fondly not as the shrews they've turned them into. If I could rate this lower then a 1 I would. I think Michael Patrick King and Sarah Jessica Parker should have to give everyone who wasted their movie on the movie a refund and an apology.

reviews.review_title: I want my wasted time back ( uncivilized movie )
reviews.content: What type of movie was that? No respect to any other cultures, no respect for your own American culture!!As middle-eastern(Egyptian) I'm not surprised to see how you viewed the Arabic world, but I never thought that you'll view YOURSELF like this! I know a lot of American people who're self-respectful and respect others views and cultures, not like the so-called Samantha and her deeds in the market!Americans should be shy for this, If they have some blood and common sense..Please make a better movie next time Hollywood, don't just go for some money!

reviews.review_title: One of the worse films ever made.
reviews.content: To say this film is bad, would be like saying the sun is a small ball of gas; a HUGE understatement.The whole film is a self indulgent, egotistical fashion show all based around what Sarah Jessica Parker wants. I loathed her 'look at how great I am' and all the slow motion shots of her after changing yet another outfit...Possibly the worse movie script I've ever had to sit through, which was such a huge shame as the S & TC 1 wasn't all bad. I gave it 2*'s just because my Missus liked some of the dresses and some of the long shots.I've got 1000 words to write on how bad it is, but I'll save it to one sentence;Awful & avoid at all costs, not even on DVD or download!!

I was thrilled to have a chance to be at the NYC premiere screening. It was so exciting. We got to see the whole cast and lotsa celebs. Was amazing.But imo the best thing about the night was the actual movie. I did NOT go in expecting to like this movie at all! I just honestly wanted to gawk at some stars. The movie far surpassed the first one (which I thought was very good too, but not nearly as good as the 2nd). This movie was total campy fun. Gorgeous men, great story lines, hilarious jokes. We literally laughed throughout almost the entire thing. I had thought the trip to Abu Dahbi (sp?) would be silly, ala any t.v. show when they take a trip somewhere always strikes me as hokey and desperate, but this was just a total blast and great juxtaposition of how THEIR American/New York lifestyle compared with a whole other world of culture and traditions, namely modesty.The movie again dealt with some serious themes however it was told with humor and entertainment. The whole Samantha "menapause" thing was just hysterically funny without giving anything away.I won't say much more as it's not necessary. If you've followed the show and the series you know what you're in for. If you are at all a fan and even if you're not I feel women AND men would find this movie to be wildly entertaining and a ton of fun.

I guess I should explain why I rated it as 10. Well, I have seen all of SATC from the series up to the first movie. and this one, for this matter. Well, it was both technical and social flop. But well, it's sex and the city. You should not expect something really that sensible from a movie which was rooted to a series that was, well, more focused about sex and having fun. It actually looked like a real midlife crisis for all the characters. I know all of you would have the same problems or worst if you reached the characters' age. When people get old, they become sensitive and insecure about things. You couldn't blame anyone from being paranoid because of marriage. What more for these women who were used to living as the life of the party and all glamorous and top-rated professionals in their own field, right. Give it a break! It wouldn't hurt to just appreciate a little piece of reality shown in this film. If they're making SATC3, I hope they give Samantha a lifetime partner, too.

After re-watching SATC, SATC The Movie and SATC The Movie 2 I decided to leave a review.I was a huge fan of the series, however the more I re-watched the series, the more I hated Carrie. The older I got, the more I saw how selfish and bratty she is.Besides that, I really wished they didn't make the movies. The series were really good, and with most things: it's good to quit at your peak. Now, SATC The Movie 2 was even more disappointing than the first movie. Overall it was really bad acting, no funny jokes, and not needed scenes in the Middle East, where especially the scene with Samantha getting all loco on the streets didn't do any justice for her character. I feel sorry for Kim Cattrall she had to play that.I couldn't relate to any of the women anymore. Actually, I felt rather annoyed watching them whine like some spoiled upper class brats. And Carrie is in her 40s here, but still thinks and acts like she's in her 20s. Come on...Now they're making a follow-up series of 10 eps, and I give props to Kim Cattrall for saying NO. You're damn right, girl.

You loved the series, you'll love this movies, a wonderful comedy with the same characteristics of the series. nice, modern, an escape from reality. The clothes are great, spectacular place and.....love and their problems. Four friends, four girls, four woman's, but four deferents personality's, I can't waiting for the DVD, i see again the movies in my house. Sex and this city is a nice movie, if you do not like fashion, forget your problems, to see life from other points of view, do not go see, it even if you did not like the series........do not you do in the movies. This girls will live forever in my heart, the film leaves you happy and wanting more, is a refreshing film, friendship, woman, mother, girlfriend, men, adventure.....but above all love.

This story is about 4 women who probably have grand daughters stuffed inside their closet and try to pass off as being as old as them. This is achieved by borrowing their clothes and an airbrushing budget that could have supported several world economies.They are reeling under the pressures (other than that of the liposuction pump) of raising kids, being satisfied in a Manhattan penthouse with a millionaire architect husband and menopause hampering the ability to romp with one washboard cardboard after another. In the process they will also end up endorsing Wonderbra as the fundamental law of existence to women across the world.And so they fly off to Dubai (Actually Morocco but its all the same really). You know, one of those little crumbs they cant spot on the world (Read, Manhattan) map. Where they'll make bold feminist statements by sporting costumes that make you at least grateful that these hags have gotten their regular bikini waxes. Parker's character (assassinate please) coos "I was more Coco Chanel than Coq Au Vin". More like coq-a-bull than coquettish in my opinion. And then there is Kim 'I'll screw a flag pole scented with testosterone" Catrall. A 'Yo mama so botoxed, they use a bulldog as her 'BEFORE' picture' joke. The layers belonging to the script have been usurped by the make up that'll need hose jobs to come off. Liza Minelli channels Michael Jackson (cosmetologically, not vocally) in a guest role at a gay wedding sequence that is about as pretty as Adam Sandler in a tutu. I'll watch Sex and the City 3. Provided a certain Jason Vorhees makes an appearance.

reviews.review_title: Maybe I was in a good mood that day?
reviews.content: I read the horrible reviews before I saw the movie, but I was still hyped about going to see it with my friend. We saw it, we laughed, we ooed and awed at the scenery, the extravagance, etc. and we accepted it for what it was. In my opinion, this movie was consistent with both the series and the first movie. These are not exercises in Oscar nods or deep, dramatic story lines. The whole crux of this book/series is lighthearted exploration of relationship and fashion. That's what this movie offered. And as someone who was wondering how the writers would broach this movie given that the main storyline of the series and first movie--Carrie chasing Big--was pretty much sowed up, how would the married Carrie be a relatable protagonist for the single-girl audience? I think they pulled it off pretty well. The dissension between Carrie and Big was real and relatable. As was the frustration of Charlotte being a new mother. So again, for what it is, the genre it is, it is a decent offering. I really don't understand why someone who enjoyed the series would not enjoy this movie. In my opinion, it's virtually the same.Virtually.I will concede that the plot in this movie was lacking, was not fleshed through well. The Carrie-Aiden moment was just dropped off clip with no real resolution. And none of the others really faced dilemmas. It was light--maybe too light. It could have used a little bit of real drama, like the first movie. It could have used just a tad bit more seriousness. That I will concede.But again, if you are a fan of the series and the original movie, you should at least semi-enjoy this movie because it's not really that far off. It is just like a prolonged episode of the series. Maybe not the best episode, but one that at least entertains for a spell.See it if you liked the series. Skip it if you are "above" this genre of film. 6.5/10P.S. The only thing that I will add as maybe a negative (or not) is that the extravagance is way over-the-top, to the point that you find yourself alternating between longing for that kind of life and shaking your head at the unrealistic-ness of it all.

Well as many other fans of the show I thought I could ignore the poor reviews and go and give this film a chance. Should have listened to the critics! Where to start, the gay wedding, Carries crown, and Liza made me cringe in my seat- it was OTT even for this show.The problems with Big and Carrie were hyped and then ignored, seriously why have Aiden in it at all?! The girls in the middle east were disrespectful to an entire culture- I thought for a minute they were trying to highlight the issue of women in some of these cultures, alas they merely mocked and ridiculed them, (Miranda had shown hope but in the end was as bad as the other three).I did laugh at some parts, however most of it was aimed at the actors for allowing this film to go ahead after fighting so hard to have a worthy first film as they didn't want to disappoint the fans. The producers, director and writers should be ashamed that this was pushed just to make more money rather than give a plot, and something for the fans to love.Overall it was too long, too full of celebrities just trying to show they were cool by making a cameo, strange clothing choices even for Carrie,and no point in my mind whatsoever.Lets just pretend this film wasn't made and that our journey with the girls ended with Carrie and Big getting married at the end of the first film, that is what I'm going to do anyway.

With all due respect, I am very appalled and surprised about all the previous reviews stating disappointments over this second Sex and The City Movie sequel. I understand like most, that the idea of being filmed outside New York seemed absurd at first.But after watching the movie today, I am glad that it did provide a refreshing and visually stimulating location and worked to benefit the plot of the movie.The first movie was about catching up on what these four women have been up to after the series ended and this movie reflects the substance of what REAL Sex and The City fans look after: unconditional friendship, love, with all the drama,frivolous wit and sense of humor spruced up with the latest of fashion.I feel that each character was portrayed in its essence. I am glad that the message of Sex and The City is still intact: an ode to women that feel to live life with irreverence, defying society rules with power, strength, independence and freedom!

i loved the original series and even liked first movie. the second movie, however, i felt is a total waste of time, film, etc. I got the impression that the actors were phoning it in, along with the writers etc.Carrie is bored with marriage, something she fought for a long time. Charlotte is a stressed mom of two kids under the age of five. Samantha is dealing with menopause while dressing like a teenager. Miranda is a working mom and quits her high powered job at a law firm.The travel to the Middle East was a silly plot line. To have them go to a foreign country and behave badly makes Americans look bad. Not all Americans are stupid, insipid travelers who just care about frivolity. We actually look to experience real culture and learn about the world.

reviews.review_title: Great movie, and no matter what other people say!
reviews.content: Loved it. People keep complaining that it wasn't at all like the series and so what? Who said that movie should be exactly like series? It has a charm on it's own. Others say that problems that were portrayed in the film were just to simple. Well, hello? Maybe just those who said it are just to shallow. It is not easy to bring up kids even with a nanny, it is complicated if you meet an old flame, because even when we part with someone we loved, still there's something left deep in our heart that can easily come to the surface when we meet them. And if a woman goes into menopause it is also very difficult to come to terms with it, as for a woman it means that basically her youth and beauty faded away, and does any woman wants to realize that??? And also, what exactly did you expect from that genre??? Aids, cancer, teenage pregnancy and homicide??? Other people comment that Carrie looks 10 years older. If you'd know the dates from first-last series, you'd realize that it's been 12 years from the first episode and 8 years from the last one. There are moments that probably shouldn't be there but generally I can not say that it is a bad movie and yes, I will watch it again. There is a huge problem at present day and it's not with movies but with people who watch them. Every time they watch a movie they want something new, something more and more exciting, something that they haven't seen yet. Well, we live in the 21 century, and I'm pretty sure that if we haven't seen it all yet, then definitely most of it.People set to high expectations for films, they expect not to be entertained but simply to see miracles. And when that doesn't happen they get disappointed and leave bad reviews. How "great" is that!So you can complain all you want, analyze what they are wearing, what they were saying, how they were acting etc and be disappointed at the end or you can just lay back, relax, watch it and enjoy it as it is and be in a great mood. The choice is yours.

The backlash against Sex and the City has begun! Now with accusations of racism. I guarantee most of people who have rated the film poorly or wrote negative comments haven't seen the film or the TV show. Its a knee jerk reaction to a successful women centric film. God forbid Hollywood make a film geared toward adult women. The nerve of Hollywood not gearing 100% of its films to teen age boys or men who still think they are teen age boys. Sex and the City is a fantasy film for women, but keeps its feet on the ground. Instead of super powers or explosions, women get to explore a fantasy world of designer clothing and fabulous locations. Yet the issues faced by each main character is rooted in reality. Miranda struggling with sexism at work, while trying to juggle work and family life. Charlotte dealing with the stress of being a mother. Samantha tackling menopause. Carrie adjusting to the reality that she will never have kids and how to keep the "sparkle" in her young marriage going. All of these issues are played out in comical and sometimes moving ways. These are real issues that women are confronted with that men will never have to contemplate. This gets to the heart of the negative comments and bad reviews. If you're a guy who didn't like the film, that's too bad. The film wasn't made for you. Men will never know what its like to be a woman, not even gay men.The accusations of racism are also ridiculous. Its a reality in the Middle East that views on sexuality and women are way more conservative. Each character responded to that reality in different ways. The more conservative Miranda was the most keen on honoring the traditions of the area and continued to remind the other characters to keep their Western ways in check. Meanwhile the most sexually liberated character Samantha struggled with those differences and eventually lost her cool. The Middle Eastern characters were never portrayed as "bad guys". Abu Dhabi was portrayed as a community struggling to deal with its traditions and modernism. That was a metaphor for the struggles of the main characters as well.

reviews.review_title: I don't know why everyone took this movie so personally!!!
reviews.content: People need to calm down, especially about going to the Middle East. I actually love this movie and enjoyed it a lot. I watched it many times and just love the different aspects of the film. Starting with the wedding for Stanford and Anthony! It's like I was watching the tv show. I love that Carrie is terrified because her and big aren't having kids and people are making them feel bad about it. That she's scared they will be a boring couple, especially how he just wants to sit home and watch tv every night. Every women has had that fear, even if you finally got the man you always wanted. Charlotte is annoying but she always annoyed me. I still like her story line about her nanny being hot and husband cheating. Because that's what rich men do a lot of the times and end up sleeping with nanny. So she knows she has it easier than most women who have kids. She just has a typical rich women problem that many celebrities went through. Miranda has always tried to have a great career and she's finally having problems with it. That was always the one thing she could control in her life, that she was a successful lawyer and now she can't anymore. And Samantha with the hormones, she's in her 50s and in menopause. It's a typical thing women go through. Despite all their problems they still decide to take a vacation, which I thought was great because we never really saw them go away. Except on Carrie's Mexico honeymoon. So this was a good touch to put in the film. I love watching all the luxuries they get with this vacation, all the food, the airplane ride and clothes! I thought it was amazing. Also seeing the Middle East and their culture and how women are very limited. When New Yorkers go, Its like shell shock! Carrie sewing Aiden was great too because now she's with big and afraid the marriage will end up boring and lonely. She could see if Aiden was really the one or not. Which he wasn't because once she kissed him she felt regret right away and imagined Herself that lost single girl again. It's relatable, anytime in life you make a life long decision. You sometimes go back to the "what if". So I'm glad they added that. And I did like no matter how many thing a they were offered in the Middle East. They all missed the freedom in America. Sometimes you want to run away from home, just to realize it's the best place to be. Oh and for the record I loved when Samantha makes that scene with the condoms when her bag dropped and broke! It was annoying they were all yelling at her for being a women! Again I love this movie and can't see why so many people hated it. Only based on a cheesy story line or how they weren't accurate about the Middle East. But it was supposed to be fun and cheesy. That's sex and the city! I always wanted a 3rd one and still hope for it.

Listen folks...if you are looking for something of substance here, look elsewhere, but I just left the theater with my husband (who's A SATC hater) and we had a really good time!! I laughed so hard at certain points of the movie and I'm still laughing! Everyone in the movie theater seemed to be having a good time. I grew up with these four girls and some of my friendships were identical...and that's what we loved about the show, and that's why we go to see the movies. As women, we do see a lot of what we've been through on screen. Are the girls still hot? I would say that they look great for their ages! We are all growing older and I think that they are still looking pretty good (wrinkles and all). I think that anybody would definitely give them all a second glance if they saw them walking by. Enjoy it for what it was and what it is, a good time out and a few great laughs. As for the situation with Aiden, who hasn't ran into an ex boyfriend/girlfriend and had those thoughts? For the serious SATC fans, you will absolutely adore this film. The wedding was hysterical and Liza was looking and moving around pretty good. I for one feel that it was definitely worth the price of admission and for my husband who I had to beg to go with me; he actually thought it was pretty good too!

reviews.review_title: Mediocre Movie and Thanks God for Gorgeous boob Gurl "Alice Eve" & Hot Ass Boi "Noah Miles" who showed something to remember!
reviews.content: SEX & THE CITY 2 – TRASH IT ( D ) I have never got the chance to watch the show though I wanted to see it very badly. Fortunately or Unfortunately I have seen the 1st movie which was O.k and now I just saw this Awful and mediocre movie sequel. Everything in the movie is just Over the Top from the Gay wedding to all these friends and their same wining about their lives and this time their Dreadful Dressing. I don't know who the hell sponsored them and tell them to wear these outfits. Especially in Abu Dhabi it looked like Hippies on loose Parole. Sarah Jessica Parker looks very old and not graceful at all & flashing her boobs in every other scene was just pretentious and painful for my eyes. Kim Cattrall, Kristin Davis and Cynthia Nixon were also dressed like Hippies especially in Abu Dhabi with over the top performances. All other boys Chris Noth, John Corbett, Jason Lewis and Max Ryan were good in their parts. Miley Cyrus and Penelope Cruz cameos were fine. Overall the whole movie looked like a Circus which is enjoyable at some point because you have accepted that it's not some thing classy it's all cheesy over here. Thanks God for Gorgeous boob Gurl "Alice Eve" & Hot Ass Boi "Noah Miles" who showed something to remember!

I saw this last night and couldn't believe my ears and eyes. You'd be hardpressed to find a more offensive piece of garbage in the last 10 years. I always thought the 4 women (with the possible exception of Miranda) were just drag queens fantasies from a (very messed up) gay man's mind - this film really confirms that. These are not real people, much less real women, but they do make sense as drag queen cartoons. What's sad is it looks like all the actresses were either told (or told themselves) that they had to have "work" done, and unfortunately, the camera does not lie. Don't get me started on the hideous idea of sending the four cartoons to Abu Dhabi so they can give the finger to everyone there and join in eternal sisterhood with local women who are more into western fashion than they are. I think SJP and Michael whatshisface - and yes, the whole cast - should be sent to hard labor for this crime against humanity. Lessons learned: Carrie should not kiss other men other than her husband. Miranda can find another job which allows her to watch her child win 1st prize at school. Samantha can continue to end each film screaming in orgasm b/c her reason for living is to have sex and scream about it. Charlotte need not fire her bra-less nanny b/c - what luck!- turns out she is lesbian so her husband will be less likely to succeed at having an affair with her. Is it any wonder we are so despised around the planet?

reviews.review_title: The actors look old and tired, just like the script.
reviews.content: What a surprise. Carrie meets up with Aidan in the Middle East and kisses him, cheating on Big. Then she calls up Big and confesses. Of course.This self absorbed, air-headed female has been the same since the beginning of this series. Everytime she gets everything she wants, it's not good enough. Why the hell would anyone want her. She disgusts me. I wouldn't do this woman with someone else's johnson. I can't believe I've been watching this stupid ignorant character destroy every relationship she's ever had, all while blaming everyone else. ENOUGH.Carrie looks old and worn out, as does Miranda. The same for Samantha. Charlotte looks okay. The characters are boorish and disgusting.This movie starts out badly and then goes straight down the toilet. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME.

Around 2000 I was quite a fan of the TV show, not a superfan, but I really liked it. Yesterday night I zapped into that movie, and I'm still angry I watched it until the end. This seriously was one of the most awful, stupid movies I ever watched. No real dialogues, a completely unrealistic non-story (what nonsense, why would a rich Sheik invite four obviously rude, crude, loud, impolite American women, middle-aged but dressed like 20 year-olds, just because some z-class action movie is launched and Samatha has somehow (how ever?) to do something with it?) And those exaggerations! Of course they get their own Maybachs, their own elevators, their own butlers bla bla. But what was most disturbing for me was the offensive and rude behaviour especially the character of Samantha showed. This was NOT funny, it was just disrespectful to let her be loud, naked and vulgar all the time, running around the streets in Abu Dhabi, screaming for sex or complaining about her hormones. And the pseudo-Danish Lawrence of Arabia-guy :D! First, this was NOT a Danish guy. They don't behave like that, and it was most unrealistic that he (of course) immediately fell for Samantha, looking like and old hag with too much make-up and making raunchy gestures. Summing it up after all that, the four women are just too old for their behaviour and it is simply embarrassing to watch. Charlotte has a hard time being a mom with a nanny and a housekeeper?? Carrie is married, has two New York luxury apartments (btw who can afford that?) and her main problem is a flat screen TV in the bedroom? Enough already! Please DON'T make another SATC movie, it is just a shame!

Sex and the City 2 has not been widely acclaimed and has received some awful reviews. Despite this i thought it was enjoyable and still had some of the original brilliance that the Sex and the City series had.Whilst struggling with busy life's, and the pressures of work, love and family life the four ladies take a trip to Abu Dhabi. Samantha is attempting to deal with menopause, Charlotte is struggling to cope with her children, Miranda hates her new boss, and Carrie thinks her marriage has lost it sparkle.The plot however is quite predictable at times. You just knew when Carrie saw Aidan that something was going to happen between them. And as for bringing Samantha to a place where showing affection publicly is illegal, you just knew how that would end up. But despite the negatives in the narrative, i still thought it was entertaining and felt that i could actually relate with Carrie's situation of the terrible "two's" of marriage.This film does have some flaws and is not as enjoyable as the first one, but Michael Patrick King should be commended for moving the ladies life's along as naturally as would happen in real life. Instead of being caught up by the woes of being single, they are caught up by the realities of the life's they have chosen to live.As usual the clothes take centre stage, and there are copious amounts of costume changes throughout. One of the highlights to the film, is the music which accompanies it. I especially like the irony behind Liza Minnelli singing 'Single Ladies.' And you can't help but become empowered when they sing 'I am Woman' at a karaoke night.This time around there isn't much sex, or much of the City, but its still good to be back with the girls.

A fun movie to add to the sex and the city series. The characters are wonderful as always and have some really great moments together. The storyline has good flow and stays true to the original series. The storylines are emotionally charged and enjoyable to watch. Though Samantha is a bit annoying throughout this movie and some of the story arcs seem to backtrack relationships.

When it comes to movies like this, I think of it as a typical Sex & the City episode, lots of innuendos and pretty clothing and the Carrie Bradshaw over voice narration. And that's what it was: just entertaining day. This movie is better than the first. I might say that just because I actually went into the theater and watched it.Then the last 20 minutes got really silly, and a bit disrespectful towards the end, outrageous and lacking the foremost entertainment. And I never like what Carrie wears it's just ugly.Overall watch it if you have love for Sex & the City the TV series, and don't expect too much from the movie and you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: A continuing of the series, fun, silly and pseudo moral to the story ")
reviews.content: I almost didn't go see this movie because the reviews were so bad and expected the worst. Well, I was pleasantly surprised that it still is the same Sex and The City I loved and own the entire DVD collection of ") Honestly I do believe the bad reviews come because of the honest portrayal of how women are treated in Islam. Politics rule Hollywood and the masses tend to follow. Wonder if all the people who voted here even actually saw it or were ever fans of the series in the first place? Sorry ya'll, this movie rocked just like the last and the series before it ") Get your heads out of your asses and learn to have fun! These gals encompass everything women are and struggle with and dream of being and do it in a fun entertaining way. The over the top outfits? Every girls dream of playing dress up! It doesn't stop after Barbie takes the backseat to boys and dating, it stays with us all of our lives! Extravagant trips? Hello? We'd all take em if we could afford em, and when not we can live vicariously through the fantasy life of movies. Men, dating, marriage, kids? We can all relate especially those of us in our 30's and 40's. For all you haters, I'd go see it again and again, oh yeah and I'll be purchasing the DVD ")

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like it but I hated it
reviews.content: I wanted to like it but I hated it. What can I say. I was hoping to be mildly entertained and be transported back to a time when the story lines of SATC made me laugh and when I felt that I could relate to the characters. Sadly, this film was a huge disappointment, and maybe I should have lowered my expectations before I saw it so that I wouldn't have been as horribly let down. There wasn't a single scene where I could relate to any of the characters. Who wears couture to watch TV at home? I am usually home in my grubby pyjamas and slippers, not Manolos. Couture on a camel? There are no words to describe how ridiculous the story is. Sad, really, as the thing that made women bond to these characters over the years was their strength and humour and there was none of this in this film. In fact, I found them all weak, humourless and tragic. (Mini-spoiler alert!) Carrie in particular was a hateful person in this film. Gorgeous rich husband, perfect designer home, great friends and still this isn't enough for the selfish cow. At the risk of repeating myself, this film is tragic. Too bad the good days of SATC are over.

According to the IMDb reports, more than half (1000+)of the raters for this movie are MEN. Just saying.I've read a lot of bad comments from people who say they're fans of the show, but I can't for the love of me understand why they dislike the movie so horribly.To me as a woman, the entire series was a learning tool for sex and relationships, each episode a different topic from cheating, anal sex, homosexuality and even funky spunk - all in the WOMAN's perspective. Every issue known to single woman in the dating world was out in the open and uncensored. This movie was just a continuation of that learning experience brought into the married life. Charlotte coping with the hardships of motherhood, Miranda making choices between work and family, Carrie adjusting to the realities of married life without children, and a little insight on the gay marriage of Stanford and Anthony. Everyone had a problem that so many women can relate to. Each character gave us completely different perspectives of the issue that is marriage and commitment.The writers of the movie have done remarkably well keeping the characters consistent throughout the series and movies. The only difference you may notice is that there may be a little less spice and a little less sex. That is because the movie is the "winding down" of the series where all the women are finally married and settled (minus Samantha because that's her character) therefore, there won't be as much drama as the series. What did you expect? Their fashionable character has also been consistent. Classic Charlotte, bold and outrageous Carrie, sexy and promiscuous Samantha and Miranda the straight-laced.I loved that the movie was set in an unfamiliar (but just as fabulous) place and out of the old New York "box." It shows that these hardcore New York ladies (who had believed that everything you could ever want is right here in New York) have really grown.I much enjoyed this movie and honestly wished it hadn't ended. I think a lot of people just wanted to see drama drama drama "Carrie cheated! They should have had sex!" But no, I found this movie to be very modest, comedic, and true to the growth of the series and the women.------- In response to "Sex and the Shitty" writer jcdugger."Big" is not a nickname after his member. If you've seen the very first show of the series, it is understood that "Big" refers to his "big shot" status as the next Donald Trump.The series is not called Sex and New York, it's called Sex and the CITY. They mentioned Abu Dahbi is rapidly growing be the next capital city of the world.

reviews.review_title: Even Flat Soda can still be sweet
reviews.content: Once upon a time four women lived in New York City. They had (we assumed) in the past battled law school, the demanding city, and were now facing a battle they may not win: finding happiness. The year was 1998 when we first heard Carrie Bradshaw write her column from an apartment that was only to be seen for one episode. In this first season, Carrie and her friends now had to fight their thirties, leading to an onslaught of emotional wreckage and failed experiments. Then the series matured and moved beyond its titular book. Suddenly, new layers were revealed, seemingly extracted between our imaginations and the lines of Candace Bushnell's prolific book. Sadly, the stories woven expertly by Micheal Patrick King came to an end in 2006,and while we would miss our favorite four women and their expert outfits, at least Carrie and Big found each other. We thought we would never hear those famous four notes again...Then, the summer of 2008 offered fans an extension. A chance to meet with our old friends. We found they were older, and not necessarily the wiser for it. Carrie was happily(unmarried) with Big (John Preston), Steve and Miranda were stuck in the terrible twos of marriage, Charlotte York-Goldenblatt and Harry were raising a daughter and Samantha was still with Smith. The thirties having been conquered, now the women had to face dealing with the forties. This journey left viewers with a heart wrenching story of love and forgiveness, a story that stood unparalleled and seemed to make this series only shine more. And even if it was now over, we had our happy ending.It was when a sequel to such a firm movie was announced and I was filled with questions, even dread: what would it be about? Where else could the series go? I am not disappointed with the latest saga to the Sex and the City. It is not a sequel so much as it is a homage to everything that made the series relevant in the first place. Where SATC 2 succeeds is that it does not rely on conventions of the rom-com genre planted thick with Meg Ryan substitutes. Instead it crafts a story that is woven with the brightest thread imaginable, and even attempts to answer the elusive question of "What happens after the guy gets the girl"? If anything, the new SATC was a pilot to a show leaving us with many questions: Will Samantha trick menopause? Can Charlotte really cope with two children and a bouncy, bra-less, and buxom twenty something? Will Miranda strike a balance between her need to work and her love for her family? All those questions however, are dwarfed by the most important question: do Carrie and Big have what it takes or was Bushnell's prolific work right in casting them as two people who will never find true happiness?The first act of the movie is a tale of domesticity. It is all about marriage. From Liza Minnelli reminding all the single ladies to put a ring on it, to the overdose of gayness in the gay wedding of Stanford and Anthony, and the struggles that each women endures in her now domestic home life. Not surprisingly, we need a movie, and all the women are not happy. It is this unhappiness which leads to a second act as the SATC girls, Danny Kaye and Bob Hope go to the Middle East. It turns out that the distraction they longed for was not completely welcome. Each woman faces her issue and finds her own way to conquer it. The montage like pace may seem like its a cheap excuse to show off the creative costumes but in the end you are left feeling like if there was a fantasy world, you've found it.That is truly where SATC 2 wins. It creates a charming fantasy in excessive overtures. With a lack of subtlety that is only a gleam in comparison to the arty violence of 300. That being said the movie is not without weaknesses. It would do better as a pilot for a new TV show rather than a full length movie and ran just touch too long. Two hours would have been fine.In conclusion, Sex and the City 2 proves that even flat soda is still sweet.

I'm really surprised that this movie even exists. Okay, it was obviously made to cash in on the popularity of "Sex And The City", but nothing happens! I was at least hoping that this movie would feature Big and Carrie having children as that would be the next big step in a relationship. They don't want to have kids and they advance practically nothing with their marriage! It seems like it was just an excuse to take the actresses on a real vacation to the United Arab Emirates. I mean, that's why Adam Sandler makes a lot of his movies.Another huge problem is that this movie is once again two and a half hours long! The story isn't complicated at all and it just goes on forever. It's just plain boring. This was completely devoid of laughs, but then again, I'm not sure if this was even supposed to be a comedy. It's a pity that this is the last installment in this franchise as I heard the show was at least good. It annoys me how these women refuse to even fly in coach. *1/2

reviews.review_title: I Really Don't Understand All The Hate...
reviews.content: Having read the many AWFUL reviews, and seeing the VERY low rating (4.9 at the time), I expected the worst.I was sitting there expecting to get insulted/bored/disappointed/outraged (amongst many of the awful things this movie has been called), but nothing of the sort ever happened.A lot of people seem to complain that the movie is "insulting" to the culture of the Middle East... I didn't see anything remotely insulting. Lots of movies, involving a foreign culture, will use stereotypes to portray it. This is something the viewers can understand and relate to. What's the point showing hidden traditions of a particular culture and portraying it in a different light than that known to your average viewer?? For God's sake, people, if you want an accurate/multi-dimensional portrayal of a culture, watch a DOCUMENTARY. This is fiction, and the movie has a purpose - to entertain the viewer, therefore - it's SUPPOSED to be exaggerated and stereotypical.Another popular complaint, is that these girls are not the same as in the sitcom. Hello?? And what exactly did you expect? It's been, what, OVER 1O YEARS?? Do you think these girls are going to be exactly the same as they were in the sitcom? How dumb is that? Their lives have changed (and so have their views), they have grown older, and some of them have kids -- the movie reflects these changes; it's only natural. The girls COULDN'T have remained the same!! Well, I have to say, I have never been too fond of Charlotte (not the character itself, but Kristen Davies's portrayal; more specifically: her constant OVER-acting), and she has really crossed the line in this one. Her acting was bad in the first movie, but, in this one, it's bordering on unbearable. And I didn't like that ridiculous "Irish bra-less lesbian babysitter" story, either. It was just stupid and totally over-the-top.Miranda's character was severely under-developed, and so was the story with Aidan. And, to be honest, the Carrie and Big story was a bit cheesy for my liking. I mean, fighting over the fact that a man wants to watch a little TV after work? Please! All in all, the movie was pretty well put together, and, in my opinion, the things people are complaining about, are absolutely irrelevant. The movie is FINE -- it's entertaining, there are some great clothes, and we get to see lots of familiar faces. Never a dull moment! I was not disappointed at all.

first of all as a middle eastern woman i gotta say stop portraying us as oppressed women ,cause seriously we arenot obliged to wear such cloth i mean the tall black thing called "abaya" or the thing that cover our face.we are actually obliged to wear descent cloth and cover our hair,i mean seriously i wear jeans and iam an Egyptian middle eastern. secondly, what a horrible attitude of Samantha,which actually prove THE STINKY AND UGLY REVIEW that u have no respect for our culture.PANTS down EVERYWHERE i mean imagine that u are inside a church would u actually do that or respect the place u are in Horrible horrible outfits, i was like i would never wear such combination of cloth even in my own home,what an awful style indeed this movie hadsorry for my long review but i have 2 other comments 1 such kinds of white horrible taxis never dare to come near such an awesome hotel,why cause its simply hotel policies everywhere to provide good service to their customers even in the cab service and they wonot just ruin the awesomeness of the service they provide with such awful dead looking cabs2 do u know that old guy that carrie bought the shoes from and refused to take money from her when she lost her passport ,THAT IS OUR ARABIAN SPIRIT ,and yes i would agree that u may meet awful people but again they exist everywhere in the whole world So plzz embrace our Arabian spirit in that man and no the movie isnot worth watching and wasting ur time on

I have been so excited about this film since it was announced that a second film was being made and wasn't in the least bit disappointed. Chris Noth has previously described this film as a "romp" and that's exactly what it was: comedy entertainment with a vein of insecurity from each of the women, as we have come to expect from the series. The uniqueness of this film as opposed to the series and the first film was the discovery of how Big feels about Carrie and marriage. His journey, I feel, makes this film fantastic. Big offers the audience a different view of Carrie - a male point of view, something not usually present in SATC - and this complements the story in Abu Dhabi, of how the women are completely muted in a strictly male dominated society. Those who criticise the film of being racist are clutching at straws and obviously have no understanding of the premise of SATC - like the series, this film invites discussion about changes in the women's lives and the barriers that they have to overcome for happiness in life and relationships. They never condone Samantha's behaviour and she is, in fact, encouraged to abide by the law of the country by the other girls. The depiction of the Abu Dhabi women is not malicious and is merely a comedic device to alleviate the strict lives that these women are obliged to live. The setting, while important to a degree, is merely a backdrop for a comfortable display of the girls' deep bond with each other, occasionally being tried and tested, but ultimately, making them untouchable. By bringing Aidan back, an alternative view of marriage and the idea that festers occasionally in a marriage that the grass may be greener on the other side, is not just felt by Carrie. While this film may not be as serious and emotional as the first, there are still emotional parts. Who wouldn't be moved by Chris Noth's depiction of a devastated man when Carrie tells him she has kissed Aidan? Chris Noth's increased presence in this film, I think, shows a possible new direction for another film. While the SATC brand is, and should always be, about the girl's and their friendship, Big's role in this movie makes it brilliant and he should be more of a fixture in the future. This movie does exactly what it says it will: it is Sex and the City as we know and love!

reviews.review_title: They are fun in Abu Dhabi!!
reviews.content: Well, I'm just back from the movies and I have to say I had a great time!But I did know what I signed up for: glamour and fun,exotic scenery and fabulous styling! So, in defense of the film, it had quite a few good laughs(and I assure you it was not just me, it had the whole theater going). As for our girls, I've got to give it to Samantha(Kim Katrall), she was the star this time, funny and so easy to relate to for lots of women. I have to admit though that I was a little disappointed by Sarah Jessica Parker. She seems like she has forgotten how to act in some scenes. All in all, it was good fun on a summer night!Don't expect performances that meet the Cannes Festival standards,just the girls,the way we know them:fun and sparkly!!And what really matters to me is that I came out smiling and I still am. So for that,it was worth my money and the two hours!!p.s.can the fashion get any better??AMAZING.really.

I'm a massive HUGE SATC fan so when I heard that a second movie was being made I was more than excited!I wasn't disappointed. I enjoyed the storyline, scenery and clothing. The acting was great and I could still feel a strong connection between the friends Carrie, Charlotte, Miranda and Samantha. This film had everything I wanted from a SATC movie. I guess it may have been more realistic if Big didn't forgive Carrie as easily as he did but that didn't ruin it for me at all. I really don't understand why it has such a low overall rating because there was literally nothing wrong with this movie. I am a big fan of BOTH SATC movies. Really hoping for a third one!

As a big fan of the show, I was really disappointed with the first movie. So why did I see the second one? Because I loved the series, and I realized just how much I miss it. I thought: Hey, at least I get to be in the company of Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte, so wouldn't it be worth it? The answer is no. HELL no!!! Watching this movie is like seeing an old friend, who now is a pathetic shadow of what she used to be. The main "plot" is Carrie, who has to get used to the fact that marriage may not be, what she expected. When she finally realizes what we - the audience - have known all the time, you want to shake her and yell: "for God's sake woman! Get a grip!" The fact that they shamelessly use Aidan for 5 minutes in the progress is unforgivable.This time the girls go to Abu Dhabi instead of Mexico, and what a horrific trip this is! Except for some shopping and sightseeing, nothing really happens. Charlotte misses Harry and is afraid that he might have an affair with the nanny, Miranda, who has read all the travel books, gives us facts about the country, while Samantha... Oh Samantha... I sat in horror and watched her drop condoms all over a street, and afterward yelling F*CK YOU and giving the finger to the angry men, who surrounded her. I really disliked the way that they traveled to this foreign country, and seemed to have no respect for it's guidelines - except for Miranda.When the movie was over I was mad. What happened the humor? What happened with the witty, funny, lovely ladies we knew? But most important of all: If you make a movie with a duration of 2½ hours, you could at least throw in a plot.My friend liked it a little bit, but as she said: "It was only because I expected less than nothing".

After the first movie, which I thought was super depressing, I was really happy that they were bringing back the comedy! These scathing reviews are rampant, so I thought this movie was going to bite the big one. I had a great time and was never bored and LOVED the Middle Eastern journey, which was ripe with comedy. People saying the movie disrespected the culture of Abu Dhabi is laughable...most of these people have never even been to that part of the world, and know nothing of their culture, or what it's like being an American woman there. And they seem to be hating on the actresses themselves, not even the characters...If Will Farell was walking around Saudi Arabia with his shirt off, people wouldn't have said anything about how inappropriate he was being in a Saudi country, but because they're women.... Anyway, don't forget this is an HBO series turned into a film. I'm glad it wasn't all complicated like the first movie, I can see a drama for that. I thought it was awesome and would see it again, two nipples up.

I am very late to see this movie as it came out years ago. I'm a big fan of the SATC series and enjoyed the first movie. But I have no idea what this was? What a disgraceful interpretation of these characters. It was on the local cable network and I tuned in. I can see why Kim Cattrell refused to do a part 3. They absolutely butchered her character. She must have walked out of the final editing of this film feeling terrible seeing herself like. In fear she may never be taken seriously again. Being sexually liberated is very different than being portrayed as a desperate easy woman.This movie was culturally offensive, like middle aged women would go to a foreign country and behave like morons... They completely undermined any kind of business savvy or smarts these characters had in the series with the exception of Miranda. In no way would 40-50 something year old women behave this way. What a disgrace of a film. Carrie's character just came across as being rude, selfish and self-centered, to her husband and to her friends. Their was nothing cute, endearing or funny about her. At the end I was hoping BIG would divorce her for being such a selfish brat. This was a writing disaster, the acting was forced trying to bring a script to life that in no way reflected these characters. The make up and acting was terrible. And that karaoke seen gave me a "Oprah you are embarrassing me" feeling. Watch if you must, but expect the ridiculous.

reviews.review_title: Those are not the women i knew.
reviews.content: There cannot be a woman out there able to hate the series. Personally, i am not your typical SATC fan. I am into doom metal, beer and psychology. Loving this show is like being in a passionate yet stabile relationship - the love lasts forever & every time you watch the re-runs you discover something new and exciting; and i've been dating it since my teen years! After all, the 90's are my most favorite thing on earth! In the series, I didn't even really LIKE Carrie's nutty outfits or Sam's costumes, but i have always been certain that that is true urban fashion. Even nowadays when i watch some old episodes i still feel the same about it. Also, I didn't agree with many highlighted moments in the show; but i always felt like it was the best thing ever made. Fun, flirty, contemplative enough, appearing as materialistic and shallow but actually quite meaningful in a classic manner. The world was changing fast, and people's private lives were in trouble.Given all that, this movie failed all SATC fans. Those creatures i saw in the movie are definitely not the women we all shared troubles with, full of envy and joy for their Manhattan lifestyle, nope. Not the cult characters that inspired ways of thinking and behaving for many generations. First of all, i could not wrap my mind around the idea that they are all so wealthy! One thing i especially loved about Carrie was her pretty much normal life: struggling with money yet carefree.Actually...you know what? I started writing this prepared to bitch slap this movie, but the following is the only thing i really wanna say. SATC is a unforgettable cult show. As such, it should have never been exploited for making freak-festish awkward no-brain movies for the sole purpose of sucking money out of the legions of lustful fans. Nothing will ever be good enough to be its sequel/prequel/whateverthef**k-quel. SO JUST LEAVE IT ALONE!

reviews.review_title: It gets 3 stars because with all its faults it is still the familiar SATC faces
reviews.content:
Big fan of the series as most that go and see the movies.Because it is Sex and the City I could never give it 1 star, although it probably deserves it.Most embarrassing performance is Samantha, followed by Carrie, followed by Charlotte. Miranda is not too bad at all, and if I'd been stuck with this group I'd cling onto her for dear life.Most embarrassing moment was the karaoke. OMG what is happening.Everything the ladies did would have almost been ok if they'd been 18, gorgeous and drunk. Unfortunately they are 50+ and not so drunk, so should know better.Outfits are outrageous. I used to love how they all strived to be fashionable in the series, it was part of the day to day fun. In this movie the fashion is way too much in your face and they all look like idiots. Worst outfit is Carrie's 'I love Dior' market outfit with those ridiculous sunglases on a stick. WHAT?Most likable:
Mr Big and MirandaMost cringeworthy:
Carrie and SamanthaCharlotte just looked like she has lost her spark. She was annoying enough but didn't come near Carrie and Samantha.

reviews.review_title: Huh...fashion and the Abu Dhabi city...
reviews.content: A moderate movie, funnier than the first one but with nothing specialIt starts really bad with a gay (ridiculous) wedding, strange (and miserable) hats(see Carrie batman-like crown at the wedding) and some scenes were the actors are all singing and dancing like at the American-teen movies. The husbands (except from Big) looked like they were only in the film because they signed a contract for all the movies. Also the 4 movie stars are looking too old and the movie is like it was made not for the story but for advertising high fashion clothes and Abu Dhabi hotelsA poem for the capitalism, the consumption, the wealth and the blindly pursuing of materialism. Unfortunately another American shallow movie

This movie was AWFUL. I was a fan of the series, and I would have given the first film maybe a 6, but this was almost unwatchable. I think I stuck through the end simply to see if there was something redeeming about it, and no, there wasn't.I won't get into specifics because the other reviews seem to cover it, but think of the most vapid, self-absorbed, arrogant and unlikeable person you know, and that's this movie. It makes no sense, and I don't know what demographic they were reaching for, but I wouldn't want to be any of these women if you paid me - if this is supposed to be "glamourous" and chic, count me out.

Basically 2.5 hours of entitled characters complaining about their problems and acting spoiled. Carrie lives in an absolutely beautiful Architectural Digest NYC apartment with an apparently upstanding husband and has the emotional maturity of a 10-year-old ('omg! why did he buy the TV when i _really_ want jewelry?' and 'hmm... is it RIGHT for a couple to spend time apart?'). Samantha is kind of disgusting (one scene has her stripping down her underwear while still at her desk and applying creme there in a glass office while in the presence of her secretary). Miranda replays the same trite old work-life balance plot. Charlotte complains about the misery of her life (the nadir being her daughter putting dirty hands on her vintage cream valentino skirt, and unable to understand how people take care of kids without full-time help and a housekeeper). The scene where they employ 4 white Maybachs to drive 4 people to the same hotel makes the environmentalist in me hurt. Also, the way this show treats gays and lesbians is incredibly simplistic, particularly the last scene where the narrator notes "Charlotte's nanny enjoyed the company of other nannies," cocker-spaniel style. Ugh. The dialogue is pretty much the dumbest thing I've ever heard in a movie, but it's not much worse than Sex and the City 1. All the jokes sound like anodynes or clichés and is accompanied by the appropriate facial expression. Some fashions are really lovely, but some are utterly ridiculous -- like Carrie wearing a ballgown to what looks like a street fair. Some scenes- -the women undressing to reveal the nyc spring collections, and a rendition of 'single ladies'-- can only be described as bizarre. The only redeeming quality is the beautiful visuals, landscapes, shots of the 'good' life ruined by these actors.

Boy, were the reviews and ratings wrong on this one. I get busy in spring and do my gardening thing so just made it to see SATC2. I'm sooo glad my daughters (baby-boomers) and I went to the theater to see the girls in their outrageous clothes, deal with their silly problems and get on that plane. What a plane - showing the individual 'pods' the upscale tickets gets you. What a dream! Then we get to that great hotel, and are given a tour along with our girls. Great! And a one day desert outing. Oh yeah! Great locations. Cinematography is wonderful! Story? Smart, rich women have the same kind of silly problems with their lives all the rest of us do. You can either make a movie and laugh; or make a tragedy and cry. We can cry just living our own lives. Carrie, Samantha et al, over the top, and making us laugh - is what this group of 'women' want. 8/10

reviews.review_title: You better read this up to my last word trust me!
reviews.content: Okay I'll be honest I'm rating this after pausing in the middle of the movie and venting out my frustration of the lack of middle eastern knowledge in this movie.So let me explain...I saw the first one because I was forced too and I guess it was not bad way too long about grown women dealing with their problems when they should know how to deal with life. So I decided to download the sequel and even before watching it I expected the same boring movie but with different problems and so far i'm right but what got me onto IMDb.com and to review it while I paused it in the middle, well it's personal...See now as soon as they mentioned the middle east in the movie and the girls going to Abu Dhabi, I wasn't surprised. That's one of the few places westerners know about in the Middle East and one of the few they know about that sounds good to their ears. Now that didn't disappoint me but I realized that in the movie so far while on the plane to Abu Dhabi, they have moments where there was a lot of nonsense spoken from the soo called Arabs on the plane, who had too dark a skin and too Indian of an accent to be Arab I would know i'm from the middle east and i'm from Kuwait and I'm right here in the great hot Middle East in Kuwait and the only thing Carrie said to the air hostess was "I like your hat" since her nose was too big.Now still for me that was tiny and I only just realized that, but what really ticked me off is, at the bar on the plane Miranda(I think thats her name) says a word that means thank you and i'm guessing in Arabic because in Hindi it means nothing but in Arabic it doesn't either! The word she said was "hanjee" or "hanji" or "hanjy" and whatever way you spell it or say it, it's still fake and irritating!!So let me tell you this, anyone who is reading this! This movie is flashy and looks good and is basically eye candy, with all the cougars and hot women and materialistic life but it has a very cheap script that just makes 2 hours of crap that used to be done way better on TV on a much shorter period of time even though I never saw the show. They throw, fashion, luxury, Miley Cyrus(who I bet is still a virgin), Liza Minnelli(who did it probably for the money) and Beyonce's annoying song just to put a good show and get the money and get out!And now I'm gonna go finish this sequel so I can see what ever else I forgot to mention.

reviews.review_title: An extraordinary journey with the ladies
reviews.content: Movie Review Sex and the city 2"Sex and the city 2" is a modern day fairytale of four wayward princesses incarcerated in a painfully real life in an island called New York. Life, however, takes on a dramatic turn when they land upon the free passes to the magical land of the Scheherazade. Reality is broken loose and fairy tale, complete with high fashion, a luxurious hotel, camel rides, eccentricities and uncalled for dramas, unravel on the screen in this sequel of HBO's famed TV series "Sex and the city". Without a penumbra of doubt it can said that this movie is made for all the die-hard fans of the TV series who have been waiting for this production to hit the box office. From the very beginning director MIchael Patrick King loads the movie with all the right spices needed to soothe the salivating tongues of hundreds of thousands of women who find a little of themselves in his four angels. And pleased the women are; there is more drama than expected, more bathetic turns than needed, more luxury than can be afforded, and ultimately "Sex and the City" comes out as a delectable dessert that has to be tasted.The fairy tale begins at the most anticipated gay wedding of this millennium: Carrie's long time gay friend, Stanford Blatch, ties the knot with Charlotte's gay pal, wedding planner, Anthony Marantino. The initial scenes of the movie give us glimpses of the lives of our beloved ladies: Charlotte is happy homemaker with two great kids, Carrie is a successful writer, Samantha is younger than ever, and Miranda has a great albeit stressful job. In a way our ladies look apparently happy in their 24 karat gilded glittering lives. Underneath this facade of happiness, however, there shroud all the dark clouds of a modern day nerve-racking life. Carrie's marriage with Mr. Big has lost its initial sparkle and she is looking for new ways to rejuvenate it, but her hip sachet life hardly allows her any opportunity to mend her married life. She is worlds away from Big and is still drifting apart. The other three ladies face their shares of quotidian pressures in their own ways: Charlotte is tired of her kids, Miranda hates her job, and Samantha spends fortunes on age renewing drugs. It is at this point when Samantha and the ladies get invited by the Sheikh himself to visit Abu Dhabi for a week. The movie, which is, by the way, an odyssey in length, is shot partly in New York and partly in Abu Dhabi, and provides the movie goers a free trip to the "New Middle East." And in our trip we get to see it all: oriental luxury, veiled women, tradition bound men, and a booming economy. The jaw-dropping luxurious hotel is as much a protagonist in this movie as the ladies are. The climax of the movie takes place at a spice market where Carrie chances upon her ex, Aiden Shaw. The adventitious meeting ultimately leads to Cinderella's kissing her former beau, and this incident, my friend, sings the denouement threnody for the plot. The haphazard events that ensue this kiss including Samantha's arrest for public display of affection, Charlotte's catharsis, Carrie's telling Big about the big-kiss, and finally her losing the passport before boarding the plane, all seemed affected. The naturalness of the plot lost its aura in the artificiality portrayed through out the film. The most outrageous scene has to be the one where burqa clad ladies shed off their outer garment to display this year's spring collection! The movie doesn't allow us a great many opportunities to get to know our ladies as they stand at the midlife juncture. The story, which is enervated and at times a little caricatured too does, nevertheless, gives us some real funny and refreshing scenes to enjoy; and it is those scenes, those natural laughs, which revamp our expectations from the plot. The plot, sadly, doesn't recuperate; neither does it emphasize the subtle touch ups on female sexuality and the subservient role of women in an apparently polished, seven-star world. The director doesn't take a lot of risks, and therefore ends up making the movie a real long "Sex and the City" TV episode. In apodosis it can be said that "Sex and the city" is "Sex and the city," and one cannot help falling in love with it. Even though the movie suffers from a lot of misgivings, it ends up being one of the most loved creations created solely for women. The innate attraction of the female species towards Manolo Blahnik shoes, Louis Vuitton goods can hardly be denied; and since fairy tales are meant to be unrealistic, a little sneak peak into the high world of unaffordable fashion and forbidden pleasures with the ladies as your hosts is certainly worth your while. So, all you ladies out there put on your best and head to the nearest theater and catch the hottest adventures of Carrie and her gang.

reviews.review_title: Bandwagon haters can't, or at least shouldn't stop the fun
reviews.content: OK - so Sex and the City 2 isn't rocket science, is this something we are just figuring out? I am only compelled to review this movie because I noticed that most of the negative reviews center around the same fundamental principles and they are: a) The movie does not take place in NYC from start to finish (boo hoo). b) The movie is not PC when it comes to women's stereotypes and the sexually-repressed Middle East (boo hoo). c) and the movie was too "over-the-top" with regards to fashion and people's living of their lives (again, boo-freaking-hoo).What has made the Sex and the City franchise so good in the past and what drives millions to watch it is essentially three major principles - friendship, sex-love-romance, and fun, and SATC2 mixes all three together again in a package that is as bizarre, over-the-top (did you SEE the gay wedding??), and tongue-and-cheek as it is funny, and it IS funny. As promised, the producers of "2" let the story follow a romp of comedy, and while some of it is so high-brow it may annoy us typical "9 to 5'ers" who scrape from paycheck to paycheck to make ends meet, most is sophomoric and flat-out blatant, especially the thousand or so gay jokes that kick-off the movie and really, never truly stop.The movie is unrealistic, shouldn't be taken seriously, is not going to uncover layers of character fortitude, and will make absolutely no push or argument for an Oscar. It's a stab at comedy through the SATC program that has relied so heavily on sex to sell, and the same holds true for the film. I do not own SATC DVD's, I've seen the show only in passing on HBO and I only watched SATC1 about a year ago on cable.In a day when romantic comedies and chick flicks fall flat on their faces and offer almost nothing of meritous value, both in production and in finished product, SATC2 takes you on a comedic journey and does it lavishly, wasting next to nothing. You'll feel as if the film dumped just as much money on production as it makes you believe it's four principals do as they cavort around their day-to-day lives. Along the way, you get just enough on each character to set you up for what has happened up until now, and where the story will go when it wraps.Again - Gone With the Wind it is not. take it for what it is, let your guard down, and enjoy the movie!

Disrespectful of the Muslim culture. To a degree where I felt it was down right racist. A vehicle to promote fashion brand Halston Heritage, Christian Louboutin, and high street favorite Zara. The characters were so far removed from their former selves they were a parody of the 'people' we had come to know so well. The film was a massive disappointment from start to finish, perhaps the shiny shoes (stilettos in the desert, in the SAND!)and flashy fashion was supposed to distract us from the lack of substance. Carrie & co sold out. I physically recoiled at Samantha's behavior in the souk. Miranda was the only saving grace. I don't know why they made it, well I do, money money money, but it has left most fans I know feeling put out, and let down by people that had become such a permanent fixture in their lives over the past decade. Needless to say I will not be purchasing the DVD when it is released!

I see that two types of people went to see this movie. Long time fans who, in spite of everything, care about these characters and want to see what's new with their lives.. and people who heard of the series, don't follow it as well, and saw the movie with friends. I am seeing that the later of this group are the ones who see nothing wrong with the movie. I feel that real loyal fans can see all the problems this movie has. While on it's own, I can see how it might be entertaining to watch with it's silly jokes, and almost child like antics. However, add this to a 10+ year story line of 4 woman maturing into middle-aged adults, and fans are left scratching our heads asking what we just saw.The series was a mix of serious issues mixed in with comedy and let's face it, some silliness. The first movie dealt more with serious. This one clearly is way more about the silliness. However After so many years, and clearly after watching the woman mature as they did in the last movie, this one felt so completely out of place and out of touch. It's hard to believe that the character I liked most was Big! (Chris Noth). Though I understand Carrie's worry about not wanting to lose her husband to the TV, the way they tried to get this problem across failed completely. Not only that, I thought him wanting to share that moment together of laying in bed and watching old movies like that, was way more personal and touching then some $20,000 necklace. The fact that Carrie still refuses to grow up about some issues is beyond annoying. They already touched on the "my love interest is an introvert and wants to stay home" plot with her already. With Aidan. And she learned her lesson then! Miranda and Charlotte were the only two who I felt, saved the movie. They did rush the plot of Miranda hating her boss, but I think it showed how much she matured as woman in a family and picked them over the job and dealing with someone who didn't respect her. At times she came across as very silly, but after leaving a job that you took so seriously for 20 years, It's understandable that she let go the way she did. Not freaking out about having the internet every two seconds. Char, well.. I understand having a 2 year old who wont stop crying and there is nothing you can do to help. Plus trying to take care of a 5 year old who acts out cause she is clearly being ignored, would cause any mother to break down. Since at that time, she was home alone without her help. (I've done that. It's hard) However, her whole issue with the bra-less nanny, was beyond ridiculous. No mother and wife would allow their nanny to dress like that around their family. All you have to do is pull them aside and tell them "You can see your boobs through your clothes. Can you please cover yourself up more while around my family" That's how an adult handles that situation. Samantha acted like a complete child.Lastly, as an American, I am completely offended by the direction and underlining insult that movie directed towards an Arab Country. After Sept 11th? Taking 4 New York woman into an Arab nation and have them be insulting and not understanding at all towards their customs (except Miranda), is just so beyond.. I don't even have words. It was beyond insulting and totally insensitive. I can't believe that point of view was allowed to even be addressed. I get that it's just a movie, and we do to watch them to get away from the real world. But that doesn't give any movie the excuse to insult another culture. I can understand that how woman are treated in Arab countries can be a real shock to this 4 very empowered woman.. but they are from New York. There is no excuse for their lack of respect and understanding. New York City is more open to people of MANY cultures more then any other city in this country. I'm half their age and I understand it. I might not respect it myself, but I would never go over there and give them the finger and shove condoms in their faces. I hate the impression this movie gave about American's. I'm honestly surprised any of the actors agreed to do this movie.

Getting dragged to a chick flick is like having your brain molested by a pelican. I'm not sure "Sex and The City 2" qualifies as a chick flick, though. Call it a menopause movie, consumer porn cosmopolitanism for free-spirited forty year old "feminists" who, oops, are totally men obsessed and can't stop fretting about finding Mr Right.If the TV series celebrates glitzy fashion, the luxuries of New York and constant accessorization - or so I'm told... I've never seen an episode in my life...honest – this movie suggests that the ultimate accessory is the male phallus. I got a business idea for Coco Chanel. Why don't you come on over and make a mould of my crotch? Less a movie than a boy band with breasts, "Sex and the City 2's" plot only gets interesting when the girls – Tiffany, Amber, Trixie and Lafanoquesha....oh wait, this is strictly a white fantasy – go to the Middle East, where their American values, chic clothing and brazen sexuality shock locals. And by "locals" I mean uptight and sexually repressed Muslims. And by "sexually repressed" I mean their religion allows them to have multiple wif...wait a second.It's not long, though, before Muslim women are dropping their hijabs and absorbing fashion tips and the hottest high street trends from our glitzy heroines. Take that Allah! The film then ends with some Ken doll hunk telling our botox injected horse faced heroine that he loves her because "You're not like anyone else". Yay, consumer individualism wins again, our hero living happily ever after, though she's conveniently forgotten that there are now a thousand copycats in Iran looking just like her. A word from Emma Goldman: "As to individualism, at no time in human history did it have less chance of expression, less opportunity to assert itself in a normal, healthy manner." Ohhh, burn.In terms of aesthetics, the film has the nondescript, anonymous look of most TV to Movie transitions. The film was directed by Michael Patrick King, whose IMDb profile picture provides good laughs (What? This review went AWOL at "pelican"). As near as I can tell, the message of King's movie is that lesbians are OK, individuality costs, penises bring happiness and the Koran isn't sexy.
