Speaking of lesbians, if a guy has a sex change and is attracted to women, is he a lesbian? And isn't that what this movie is secretly telling me to do? I don't know. Great movies inspire deep thoughts. But so does sleep, which I did throughout this film's first two acts. And by "acts" I mean pelican molestation sessions, or PMS for short. Yes, guys suffer from it too.10/10 – Masterpiece. Multiple viewings required.

reviews.review_title: Amusing, but it seems to be losing it's spark a little.
reviews.content: Two years after the first movie, and Carrie(Sarah Jessica Parker) and Big(Chris Noth) are settled in married life, but soon Carrie feels the spark that what there marriage romantic, is slowly dying, and Mirandas(Cynthia Nixon) work life is in chaos, but her family life is secure. But Charolletes(Kristen Davis) family life is in chaos, and is worried that the new nanny(She's out of my leagues, Alice Eve) is making a play for her husband(Evan Handler). And Samantha(Kim Cattral) is the only who is content with her life, and she gets an offer to travel to Moraaco, and decides to take her three friends, will this be a life changing experience? Not has good as the first, I felt that the spark that made Sex and the City fun to watch, was not there for the most part. Although there were some funny scenes. Even a scene with Kim Cattral in Moracco. Liza Minnell has a good scene, doing musical number by a famous artist, I'll give you a hint it's not Lady GaGa. And I liked the scenery in Moracco. John Corbett appearance as Adian showed interest. But other than some of the spark was missing.

A new installment in the SACT franchise, with all the elements that the fans of the series loved. The new episode focus on how our favorite four girls face the challenges of marriage and consolidated relationships, and how marriage means different things for different people.I'm surprised at the poor reviews of this movie, which I think it is not worse than the first, which has double rating. Completely senseless. The story has moments of the soul of the TV and Carrie's character. Needless to say, fashion and luxury are still gorgeous and an essential part of the look and mood of the movie, but the story makes good points and grounds the characters. Most importantly, the acting has returned to what we were used in the TV series, making us forget some of the flaws we resented in the first movie. I cannot believe that nobody noticed how terrible was in the first, and that is back to normal here.The movie has some very fun moments, many of them by the always cheeky (and hilariously vulgar) Samantha. The gay wedding at the beginning is great, with a cameo by Liza Minelli as wedding minister and wedding singer.I think the main problem of the movie is the whole trip to Abu Dhabi. Not the trip, the destination. I had the feeling that this was a long commercial about Abu Dhabi. The girls could have gone elsewhere luxurious and still face the same challenges. I thought that focusing on cultural differences and the idiosyncrasy of the Emiraties was a waste of time, and completely unnecessary for the story, which, until the trip starts, was making good points about marriage. In short, I would have eliminated the touristy part and dug deep in the part of the relationships. On the other hand, this being a show about sex, love and relationships by very liberated Western Women, the UAE were never going to be a good destination. Never ever! This is one of those chick-flicks that will entertaining women who were fans of the TV series and have all the background to understand and enjoy the characters and what is happening in this double length episode, which is what it really is.Abstain from viewing men and people who are not familiar with the series. Otherwise, don't complain!

reviews.review_title: Why oh why did i go to see this 2!
reviews.content: To say this film is awful is being understated about it. The film had no discernible plot. Carrie did my head in moaning and being selfish and the other women had little to do other then be clothes horses. And I'm sorry, but the fashion sadly missed the mark on most occasions.The men were underused AGAIN! I don't know why I thought it would be different in this film. The cameos were pointless. The first 'surpirse' was not at all surprising, you could see what was going to happen the minute the first scene had started.A lot of the good bits were in the ads and lost the punch for the film which was sadly missing any interesting things at all. Samantha was the same as she always is, Miranda didn't really do anything, Charlotte didn't really progress or change or grow and Carrie moaned so all in all nothing much different there then!I wanted and wished that this film would be so much more but I was sorely disappointed and won't be watching this again voluntarily.

To list the redeeming qualities rather than the problems of Sex and the City 2 would make a very short review. It would be one word, no matter the language: None. Zip. Nada. Null. Nolla. There is not a single good thing about it. Just isn't. I would compare it to A Serbian Film in the sense that when you think it has reached the ultimate epitome of revulsion, it gets worse. It is vomit-inducingly grotesque beyond your wildest imaginations.There's no story: the whole movie is just the main characters wandering from one extravagantly expensive set piece to the next. There are no likable characters: every single living being in this movie is despicable to the bone. If real women were like these hideous caricatures, I would have had myself castrated years ago. There's not a single group of people who won't be offended by this film: male, female, straight, gay, Christian, Muslim, doesn't matter. There's no conflict, character development or any sort of buildup whatsoever: perhaps the film's longest lasting "conflict" is that the sex-obsessed one is losing her libido because she couldn't bring her vitamins to Abu Dhabi. Oh the humanity!But the very worst thing that permeates SATC2 from beginning to end has to be its philosophy. Basically what the film says is: not having thousands of dollars to spend at your leisure is terrible and no matter how bad things are, buying expensive things will always make it better. Just a few examples of this philosophy are: -The main character actually complains that despite being married for two years, she still doesn't have a diamond ring. One of the women cries in a food closet because her child put jammy hands on her vintage skirt and stained it. In one scene (taking place in the private bar of their $22,000 a night suite no less) the aforementioned character actually says out loud: "How do the women without help do it?" and her conversation partner replies: "I have no f****ng idea". The amount of moments like these is practically irrational.One could write a series of novels about everything that is wrong with this film. But in short it's misogynist, crass, sexist, offensive, racist, repugnant, insulting, grotesque, revolting, spits in the faces of everyone who knows anything about the middle east and shamelessly objectifies both men and women. I can't remember ever having wanted to become a terrorist as much as while watching this film. Recommendation: I can give this film two recommendations: 1. If you're dreaming of becoming a film critic, watch this film and then think again. 2. If you're an extreme masochist you'll definitely enjoy this one. In any other case stay the hell away from it.

I really did like it. I am a long time watcher of the shows and absolutely loved the first movie. This movie wasn't as good as the first but it's a sequel so you can't really expect it to be. I think any mother who's gone through some of the struggles that Miranda and Charlotte face, and any woman who's married that's experienced disappointed expectations for what marriage would be like, like Carrie did, will like the fact that this movie touches on these issues but also does it within a ridiculous fantasy world so it doesn't get too serious to be depressing. It was absolutely fun and fabulous and is exactly who and where you'd expect these characters to really be two years later. It's really enjoyable once you stop trying to notice all the outlandish stuff. I've read the reviews by critics that criticized the fact that this movie lacked the heartfelt friendship content that the first had, but it absolutely had that- it was just another side of their friendship. I recommend it wholeheartedly to the SATC followers but I can see how silly it might be to people who don't know these characters.

reviews.review_title: The girls are back on top form
reviews.content: What can I say........ This film really really did impress me. It was a non stop fun filled movie, with bundles of laughs thrown in and set in some amazing locations. All the actors/actress's were on top form, especially Kim Cattrall. It was nice to see Miranda become a more bubbly and fun character too in this movie. I wont go on about this film, but if you want to see a great movie with everything in it then this is for you. I walked out with a lot of other people all smiles :) I don't think it would be right to do a 3rd movie but a 7th brand new series would be spot on. Well done to all of the cast for bringing us such a great movie. Cant wait for the Bluray to be released now

I have never been a fan of the show because I have too much testosterone, I guess. Sex And The City is played by women, for women. My wife has always been a fan of the series, so I do have seen quite some episodes. I do understand why women find it interesting: the glamorous clothes and shoes, the characters, the presence or absence of romance, etc.After seeing the first film (by my wife's initiative, of course) I still could understand if 'some' fans enjoyed it. For me it looked like an extra long episode of the show. Sex And The City 2 is something completely different to anything that relates to the previous film and the TV show... in a bad way. Even my wife could not ignore the annoyance of some scenes.An over the top wealthy, neurotic-racist, whining-like-little-children, over-aged-scary-looking and some way-too-skinny-women, horror show is what you will get in this sequel.The New York Magazine itself summed it up very good: "The most depressing thing about Sex and the City 2 is that it seems to justify every nasty thing said and written about the series and first feature film."Stop the self humiliation of something that once was adored by so many women...

Sex and the City is about women, and in order to condense the essence of the female mind into a show or movie we are presented with 4 very different women. Charlotte is the good wholesome girl. Samantha is the promiscuous, independent, A-lister. Miranda is the logical workaholic, who's sometimes a party pooper. Carrie is the successful writer and fashionista who holds this group of girls together. Though fashion, sex, and glamor are central to the franchise, the conversation is what makes Sex and the City what it is. The topic of conversation? Sex and Love. It's the unadulterated thoughts of all women funneled into just 4. Guys, if this sounds horrible, then stop watching Entourage because it's the same damn thing.We last left off with Carrie marrying Big in a label-less dress at a small wedding. 0 guests. Just a New York City officiant and other couples anxiously awaiting their turn. Sex and the City 2 flashes forward 2 years. The gang is back together for their gay friends' wedding, which is completely over the top with swans and a all-male chorus dressed in white. The gay cherry to top it off - Liza Minnelli weds them and then sings Beyoncé's Single Ladies complete with choreography. Ridiculous. While at the wedding, a fan of Carrie's writing is shocked to find out that Carrie and Big has no plans to have children. This triggers a chain reaction of thoughts until Carrie realizes that their relationship has become a bit routine. Watching TV on the couch and ordering in is just not her style. So one night, she forces a scotch on Big and drags him out for a red carpet event that Samantha has invited them to.At the after party, Samantha scores a PR job that provides all 4 of them with an all-expenses-paid trip to Abu Dhabi. Luckily Miranda had quit her high-stress job after a sexist tyrant becomes her boss. Charlotte simply needs to get away from the craziness of raising two young children. And Carrie is yearning for the adventurous lifestyle she had before marriage. So off they go into a world of glamor and decadence. They each have a private suite on the plane, a personal butler at the hotel, and a personal Maybach at their beck and call. To mix it all up, Carrie runs into Aidan (an old love interest) at a spice market in Abu Dhabi. She has to sort out what she wants while her flamboyant friends avoid trouble in a very conservative Arab nation.So how does the movie compare to the first? How does it compare to my expectations? It's pretty much what I expected. It's Sex and the City 1 times 2. Everything is much more extravagant. I can't help but wonder how much these people make at work. They live such fabulous lives. They put on expensive clothes to cook or to simply flop onto the couch. You will either be awe struck or contemptuous. I'm glad to say that it is funnier than the first as well. Hence, entertainment-wise, I'd say that Sex and the City 2 is better than its predecessor.What about substance? The primary message is that marriage requires compromise and understanding. Furthermore, it's unique to each couple. Although I've concisely extracted a moral, I don't think the movie did a wonderful job in making it clear. And does it really need to make this clear in the first place? Really? Compromise and understanding? Marriage? You don't say... What was the catalyst of Carrie's and Big's drama? Carrie feels that they're becoming a boring couple. If this was the only problem married couples encounter, then the divorce rate would be much lower.In the end, Sex and the City 2 has made a mountain out of a mole in order to sell you the same product. It's just more of the same, but with the number '2' appended to the title. I remember watching the 1st Saw and thinking it was great. Saw 2 - more of the same. Saw 3 - annoyingly repetitious. Saw 4, 5, and 6 - I didn't even try to watch them. At this rate, we should expect Sex and the City 3 in the near future. If they can make big money with the same formula, then why not? I would advise them to stop at 3, but seeing how the 2nd one played out suggests this might go on indefinitely. I wouldn't be surprised if I woke up in an empty room strapped to a chair and given a choice between watching Sex and the City 4, 5, and 6 or forfeiting my life. Jigsaw, you evil bastard.Read more of my chick flick reviews for men @ RatedChick.com

reviews.review_title: I would like those two and a half hours you took from my life back, thank you.
reviews.content: Alright, I went to this movie because my friends wanted to go. I've never seen the TV show, I haven't seen the first movie (and now know to set fire to it if I see it on sale at Big W)- I went expecting the worst. And that's exactly what I saw. The characters were flat, predictable and downright unlikeable. The jokes were all terrible innuendos aimed at those clearly not capable of intelligent thought. The costumes changes were gratuitous and ridiculous (again, I know it's about the fashion, but as another reviewer said, numerous costume changes DO NOT CONSTITUTE A PLOT). Speaking of which, what plot? The four women deal with their issues in a way that's... no hang on, they don't. Sorry. My mistake, conflict resolution is dealt with magically here. Then they arrive in a completely different culture and take the term ethnocentric to a whole new level. They insult the locals, change costumes, whine, commit adultery, change costumes again and then are sent home, where they proceed to change costumes (I didn't see that one coming). I must say the lowest point of the movie for me, personally, was when Charlotte (who was, admittedly tired and under stress) completely lost it with her daughter and yelled at her for getting icing on a skirt- in other words, for behaving like any child would. The idea that a mother should favour a vintage skirt over her own children is wrong- are we really this materialistic?? I beg you, please, you are better than this. Only if you have ten dollars in your pocket that you found on the pavement and a spare two and a half hours that you would otherwise spend sadistically torturing small animals should you see this movie. And even then, you might want to think about it.

As a SATC fan, I can't believe they have reduced
yet again the smart, quick-witted characters to these ridiculous, shallow, giggly caricatures of what they used to be. The first movie was meh, this one was borderline insulting.To me SATC finished with the series. This is something else, and something I don't really like.

reviews.review_title: Your typical Sex and the City fashion of glitz, high class and dreams of fairy tale endings.
reviews.content: Being a viewer of the TV series on HBO, I saw the first big screen movie and decided to give the second one a go. And again it's much your typical fashion of style, high class, and glitz it's just not your common everyday woman's world. Sure the sex appeal and laughs are present, but this is one film that most will find to fairy tale and dreamy.You have the four colored bra wearing females Carrie, Samantha, Miranda, and Charlotte all back together as friends waiting on another adventure this time their journey involves an Arabian desert vacation. While in my opinion turns the film to nostalgic, impatient, and to make believe. Some fun subplots are Samantha's battle with menopausal and it shows Carrie's breaking away from Big as she writes a new book. So really that's not to much of a distraction to make it take away from the overkill of high class and glitz. Yet the sexy scenes of the ladies were a treat and seeing Carrie's ex played by John Corbett was all right. Clearly this film is to big on substance and very little on taste.

I generally liked it. It may be because I was so prepared to such a bad bad movie after reading all the negative comments, that I didn't have high expectations. Of course, they could have dressed the characters a bit more like "normal" people when they were in Abu Dhabi, and there is one day (in the movie is the same day) in which they are in the desert and they change 4 times, always wearing fabulous dresses. It is true, there is not such a big story behind this movie, and true also that Carrie looks quite selfish in this movie (these are some of the comments I read about it). But the point is: 1) Carrie is a selfish character, even in the episodes, so no surprise there. I think that the fans of Sex and the City knows her that way. 2) The dresses were exaggerate for being in Abu Dhabi probably. The movie is a lot about the different outfits of each of them. But so it was the previous movie. I guess that it is more and more a characteristic of Sex and the City being something like a fashion show too. I don't find it adding something to the movie, and some of the outfits were out of place (e.g. the skirt of Carrie when she meets Aidan at the market downtown), but I guess that it was predictable that clothes would play a bit role in this movie. 3) The story behind this movie is really poor. True, there is not such a big story, but there are a lot of more daily little stories in there. I don't have kids, but I love the scene in which Miranda and Charlotte get together to talk about their frustrations. And I felt close to Carry when she got a bad review for her book (I don't write books, but I have to write a lot of articles for my work and sometimes I get very bad reviews too).I also read that the movie is kind of racist, especially because of Samantha's behavior, and shows that Americans know little about the culture of other places. Samantha is Samantha. She is very true to her character. And in fact, in a different culture, she gets in trouble for being so liberal. I didn't find it respectfulness. Of course, Samantha was there for work-reasons, but wasn't the goal of the person who invited her there to let her know and appreciate the place so that she could propose it as a fancy-luxury holidays location? She explored the place in her own way. And I don't think that the movie portraits Americans in a bad way.Conclusion: it is not a great movie, and the episodes are still better than any of the two movies, but after all I liked it, I spent some 2 nice hours with some girlfriend, we went out after it to talk about it, it made me feel very light, it made me feel I wish I could wear some of those dresses and shoes just to try them on, and it made me laugh. And Liza Minnelli is great! Really a plus to this movie!

reviews.review_title: go see it... why wouldn't you?
reviews.content: I loved this movie. The point of a movie like this is to simply see what the characters are doing now and to laugh. I laughed a lot at this movie, they did a good job of bringing out the comedy in the characters. I think people go into this movie expecting too much. I was just happy to get another glimpse into the lives of the girls. As always the girls are facing issues with life. When they get the chance for a great adventure together they take it and live life to the fullest. It isn't quite as serious as the series or the first movie but it does deal with real issues that people face everyday. I would suggest to everyone who was a fan of either the series or the first movie to go see Sex & the City 2. If nothing else you get a look at the fashion and glam of the world these girls live in and as always lots and lots of shoes.

reviews.review_title: What's all the hate for? I liked it!
reviews.content: All in all I thought it was good! A bit insensitive and rude, that surely is true, but nonetheless deserves a decent review. Not as good as the first one and not a lot of emotional depth like the first one, but worth seeing and fun to watch. One thought that might have good for the film was going in depth with carrie and the others emotional turmoil. In addition, the meeting with Aidan should have been a little more drawn out, but I was glad she didn't sleep with him. I definitely liked how bug forgave her. You could tell there was a lot of love there, because he was so forgiving. In conclusion, there should be a third one made to end the series on a more emotional note. The 2nd one is good, but for the third one, some fluff (a lot I should say) should be taken out and replaced with more personal situations.

I loved SATC2! This is a movie for women to escape reality for a bit. When your little you dream about living in castles, wearing beautiful clothes and having a handsome prince come and sweep you away! As you grow up you come to realise this never happens and reality is nothing like the stories we are told when we are little. Now i'm in my late 20's for me Sex and the City is a return to fantasy but as a grown up. I loved that I got to escape reality for two and a bit hours. The shoes, clothes, wonderful group of friends, exotic setting and handsome men.....What more could a girl dream of?Come on people Sex and the City is to women, what James Bond is to men!!

reviews.review_title: Sometimes it is time to say goodbye and the message is clear!!
reviews.content: Despite my title I did not dislike Sex and The City 2. Now a bit of a background. I am male, straight, and suddenly found myself watching the entire series with my fiancée and loved it. The first time I saw the first film I walked away feeling disappointed but maybe coming out of the series I had high expectations. When I re-watched the first film before seeing the second I enjoyed it much, much more and didn't find it as...depressing as the first time through. The biggest issue I had with the second film wasn't the cast, or their age, or the same old gags (which I actually think is a good thing), but rather nothing happens. Even in each half hour episode Sex and the City was never dull...something was always happening, something was always changing the lives of our fab four girls but with Sex and The City 2 it felt like an elongated Epilogue and I'm just not sure that was necessary. Nothing significant happens to any of them. We get a minor recap to their lives but you get no new information, very few new developments, and the only thing different to the story is the exotic location. It was just disappointing to not have something earth shattering happen which is what Sex and The City thrives on.While plenty has been said about the cast bad and good and professional critics love to poke fun at their age and their promiscuity and everything else but fans of Sex and The City love them for being them. Charlotte's neuroticism, Carrie's fashion and romantic hopelessness, Miranda's constant reality check and lack of dreaming, and of course Samantha is always Samantha. Sarah Jessica Parker, Kristin Davis, Cynthia Nixon, and Kim Cattrall still bring all we love about their characters to the table and their chemistry together is still A+ and that will always be the redeeming quality of Sex and The City. None of them deserve acting awards but at the same time they live and breath these characters. David Eigenberg, Evan Handler, Jason Lewis, and Chris Noth all return as the boys of Sex and the City. Part of the charm of the original series and the original film was the interaction between the girls and the guys but the guys took a huge back seat in this film. They have some good moments but the driving story behind this film is Carrie and 'Big's relationship falling into a rut and its just not believable. Willie Garson and Mario Cantone return to their adorable roles as the gay Romeo and Juliette, who finally tie the knot in a rather ridiculously over the top but hilarious gay wedding. Finally John Corbett also returns as many fans hoped for as Carrie's other major love interest. It was the sole saving story line to the film but they still managed to make it rather boring but it was very cool to see Corbett and Parker together again. Watch for a small role but the beautiful and sexy Alice Eve in a very amusing role as Charlotte and Harry's new nanny. Good lord that woman is smoking hot.You can't make a smarter move than taking on a writer, producer and director from the original TV Series to do the first film and the second as Michael Patrick King takes over again and does a fine job controlling the film. The scenery and cinematography is beautiful but where is that spice we all know and love. I think what has happened here is that the TV Series gave us everything we adored about the show. The first film was the perfect wrap up, the perfect reunion and gave us everything we could possibly need from this series and then there was the sequel. I love the characters, its fun and has some laughs but it just feels unnecessary. Yes the girls are getting a little old to be having the same wild times they always have and they tip toed around through the whole film so it didn't shake anything up because fans were happy with the way things are. So we have a 2 1/2 hour epilogue. As much as I adore sequels its time to say goodbye to Sex and the City and the first film would have been the perfect send off. So if you're a fan of the series watch the second one as a glorified epilogue and if you happen to watch the first film then you might be better off to skip the second. 7/10
I can understand why Kim Catrall is against doing another one! She knows a bad thing when she acts in one!

reviews.review_title: Is offensive, ignorant and disrespectful. Lacks plot and character development
reviews.content: My girlfriend and I got free tickets for the movie. She, like most girls, is a big fan of Sex and the City and being a good boyfriend I accepted to go with her. She made me watch the first one on DVD and I didn't like it but it was still somewhat entertaining, so I thought OK I'll watch this one, it's free and we got nothing to do on a rainy Wednesday night. I knew it wasn't gonna be a good movie, but after 10 minutes into it I just wanted to leave the theater. The dialogue was weak, scenes were just put together with no connections whatsoever. Then they go to the Middle East and act completely disrespectful to their culture. I'm not from the middle east but I felt offended. American movies are very ignorant and show a complete disregard for other cultures. They used cheap jokes disrespecting their culture and religion and wrongly portrays the Middle East. It's shameful, it's not even a bad movie, it is insulting to anyone with a little bit of intelligence.

reviews.review_title: Crass and crude: would we have it any other way?
reviews.content: I've always thought that the quartet of 'ladies' in Sex and the City are really meant to be four gay men played by actresses. It's harder to hold this view now that three of them are married and two of them are mothers. But Samantha, still single (and a slut) at 52, is more like several gay men I've known than any woman of my acquaintance (perhaps I move in the wrong circles).Playing to the gay audience, we have the cringe-inducing 'marriage' between Carrie's best gay friend and Charlotte's best gay friend (Martha and Martha!). Ageing icon Liza Minelli improbably officiates at this ceremony and then provides the (pardon the pun) cabaret. She talks and sings as if her mouth is full of pebbles. Joan Rivers needs to give Liza some career advice ("Liza, it's over").Half the movie takes place in Abu Dhabi on a PR junket of Samantha's. There are modesty jokes galore (and a few 'daring' burka gags) and Samantha (surprise!) has one or two immodest moments.The critics have generally dismissed this, as well they might. Yes, it's crass and crude, but when wasn't it? There's some full-on sex (guess who? no prizes), a lot of full-on smut and an endless fashion parade of silly frocks, but hey, what else do we expect? The barrel is very close to being scraped dry. Maybe they should let ten years go by and then revisit them in their 50s and 60s, perhaps living in Florida, all divorced - it could be a raunchier version of The Golden Girls. David Gee is available (and very affordable) for script-writing!

reviews.review_title: SATC 2 Is a Fun and Fabulous Flick
reviews.content: OK, now, I know that my rating will have some people raising their eyebrows, but I don't care because that's exactly why I'm writing this review. Quite frankly I'm only writing a review for this movie because most of the reviews available for this movie have been extremely negative and incorrect in my opinion. I never really got to see the original show religiously because I was, like, 12 when the show was still on, but I have seen an episode or two since then. The movie is glamorous, smart, sexy, and funny--in that order too. Fashion is obviously one of the main reasons why the show and the movies became very successful. The clothes in the movie were spectacular and the shoes even more so. Admittedly, some of their clothes weren't really appropriate for the Middle Eastern setting, but these were the Sex and the City girls!!! And anyone who knew who they were knows that they have never been one of those people that would easily compromise themselves, especially not when it comes to fashion!Some reviews argued that the characters qualms were all very petty and ridiculous. Supposedly, the girls were complaining about the most insipid things because they are selfish and insensitive to the other people around them. Sure, there is truth to that, but those qualms do not define them. Most reviewers are being hypocritical here because, let's admit it, we all can be a bit selfish and insensitive sometimes. And it's not like the girls are broadcasting their qualms to the world or telling every single person they meet about them. They are discussing these issues with their best friends and lovers which is normal and, might I add, appropriate. I mean, seriously, who doesn't talk about things like these with their best friends or lovers? Unless you're some kind of hermit or a complete loser with no friends that is. And, besides, when Charlotte and Miranda were talking about their problems, they both expressed that they felt really bad and felt like they were the worst mothers for having those feelings which pretty much captures how real mothers might feel in the same situation.There were reviews saying that this movie was racist which is absurd. I am a person of color, part Muslim, and have been fighting against all forms of discrimination from racism and color-ism to homophobia, and this movie was definitely not racist. Sure, at times, the characters become a bit irreverent especially Samantha, but that IS Samantha. She has always been the crazy and outrageous one. She's never been and never will be a girl to change who she is, no matter where in the world she is.Overall I think most of the other reviews have been misguided because they misunderstood the film and kept comparing their own lives to those of Carrie, Charlotte, Miranda, and Samantha's. Wake up call, guys, you're not them and this is just a movie. People seem to have forgotten why these girls are icons and the original show even more so. The show and characters were phenomenally successful not because they were realistic, but because they gave us relate-able escapism. The girls were beautiful, successful, promiscuous, rich, fashionable, and sexy, and that's why we love them because they were everything most people wanted to be.
This actress are horrible, where this old bitches came from. Story line is fine but actress make it worst, yaak. Unbelievable
Has the pace of a boring documentary, but less interesting.

I really understand the disappointment of the fans when this movie came out. We had the first movie where a lot of important things happen that change the characters. Carrie gets married, Samantha breaks up with Smith. Miranda gets cited on by Steve and Charlotte gets pregnant. I mean the first movie is a very nice add to the adorable and worldwide phenomenon that was the series. Saying all this in advance i must say that the critics to this film were way to harsh and way out of line. There much much worse movies that come out every year and even get awards. This movie should be seen for what it is. An escape from the real world, a vacation with " the girls" Its not the best and the story is not at all complex, but we get to Samantha in the "Middle" East. And one last thing. I don't see how this is an insult to anything even to the middle east. Lets be a little serious, there are series and movies who make jokes and comments about the middle east, this is only an experience of two majorly different world's. I only gave it 7 star's because i wanted to see more drama with Big and Carrie or with Aidan. But the movie was a great laugh and it was nice to see them all again.What i truly want in for the future of this series is a Sex and The City 3 with them ( not a god damn prequel), that will close the mouths of those critics and angry fans alike. A movie that will have an ending that will not need another movie or a prequel. A last story of the 4 girls that every guy and girl loved to see once a week.

I came to see this movie for Sarah Jessica Parker. I remember her from better roles, such as Mr. Ed or Quick Draw McGraw, and she was just incredible. I came expecting a similar movie. I must say, I'm disappointed. This movie has nothing to do with such masterpieces. The characters are all empty, the acting is terrible, and there is no story. Even worse, in other movies by this actress, they recognize that she's a horse, but she does human things, such as with her character in my little pony. But in this movie everybody acts as if she were not a horse! That's not good comedy.Advice for the die hard fines such as myself: Skip this movie and instead go watch some of her classical roles, such as Antares in Ben Hur.

reviews.review_title: What in the God's name was that?
reviews.content:
Now I feel bad for giving the first movie one star, because this one is so much worse.
I mean, I've read reviews, I thought I knew what I was getting myself in to, but boy was I wrong.
This racist, dumbing down, and no plot of any kind movie, should never be made.
Really insulting to fans of the show, and to other cultures as well.
Cringe levels so high, that I almost turned it off more than once.

reviews.review_title: Actually Sucks and very far from reality
reviews.content: I don't know why they make such a fuss about this movie, and I'm not gonna talk about the actresses and the direction... All I want to say is that: how do you talk about a community that you know nothing about and without not even filming at that community (UAE, Abu Dhabi, Dubai).Because none of this films scenes were shot in Dubai or in any part of the United Arab Emirates?!!!!!! Of course, these info are according to Mr. David Shepheard the Director of Abu Dhabi Film Commission which has the authority of giving movie filming permits in the UAE.So, how am I to believe a notion of Dubai from a person who hasn't even been there!!!??!!!

I am a single, straight, fashionable, attractive and hip San Francisco male. Somehow, (ex-girlfriend?) I managed to get hooked on this television series and probably caught, and mostly enjoyed, every episode as they aired on HBO.I didn't see the first Sex And The City movie in the theater but caught it on DVD. It was a bit long but I thought it was good and worth watching for anyone who liked the series. It was easy to skip past the few parts of the movie that were a bit much. (The closet cleaning scene?)I went to see Sex And The City 2 on a date. First off, we were given the evil eye by a 'Devil Wears Prada' look-a-like in front of us for talking too much before the movie even started. Then during the entire movie a women next to me yapped the entire time and said "My Gawd!" at least 20 times and Devil-Wears-Prada didn't turn around once for her. Go figure!I won't go into the psychology or social aspect of the film. Plenty of other reviewers of done that.This movie too was too long. It seemed like they went crazy with story, plot and scene ideas and shot every last one to the Nth degree and left absolutely nothing on the cutting room floor. This was like the Directors Cut, extended Version, times two.Many scenes were unnecessary and a bit boring with very trite and predictable jokes and dialog.Do these girls ever do anything without wearing multi-hundred dollar designer clothes? They are on vacation in sweltering United Arab Emirates and they do everything in high fashion. They even go camel riding in nothing but over-the-top looking camel riding gear.Someone needed to take an exacto knife to this script and movie design and edit out a good one-third of it. Multiple times I imagined a remote control in my hand to pretend to fast-forward the movie and to volume-down on the women next to me. Wait till the DVD and only if you were a big fan of the series.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the first
reviews.content: Sex and the City 2 (2010) is a sequel to the 2008 Sex and the City movie, all based off the popular HBO series that lasted from 1998-2004. In this movie, Carrie is now married to Big, Charlotte has now two children and a new nanny, Samantha is single and living in New York again, and Miranda's marriage is fixed and she's in a career crisis of sorts. The girls are all gonna go away on a beyond fabulous trip to Abudabi to escape some of the troubles in their New York City lives. The actresses do a good job playing their roles, just as they always have. There is some funny/witty dialogue, and some old flames such as John Corbett come into play, so the movie does have some good things going for it. The thing that's not so great though, is the fact that this film just isn't as good or entertaining overall as the first movie or the TV show. The writing is alright at best, some good parts, but more dull parts than one cares for. The costume design is of course absolutely fabulous as Sex and the City fashion always is. I wanted there to be more meat in the plot, I think they could've went further with this film to make it more interesting. 6/10 for Sex and the City 2, still entertaining, but not as much.

If you don't like or appreciate the series or SITC 1, then don't see the movie. BUT if you are a fan, you will laugh for 2 hours. Seriously!! So some of the outfits are over the top?! Did you notice they have always been that way? The acting is fine, the story lines ARE present and continue the lives of the characters. It was a nice change to see Charlotte freak out on her kids, Miranda decide not to be wound so tightly, and Carrie work on marriage with John. Some of the lines were corny, some of the Samantha antics were inappropriate, some of the circumstances were far fetched, but you get exactly what you go to this movie to see,and if you wanted more then shame on you.

reviews.review_title: Sex and the City 2 has no justification for its existence. Everything is just an excuse for a parade of stunning costumes, recycled jokes, and, above all, advertising
reviews.content: For fans, the more they become part of their lives again, the better. Everything is an excuse to see them on the scene, with new conflicts and agendas. The result of "Sex and the City 2" is that it is still wonderful to see them together, but that there was not necessarily a need for another film for this franchise. Although there are problems with the work, the fact is that, during the 146 minutes of projection, it is impossible not to laugh at the antics they go through. While the previous feature captivates with emotion and adds acid humor, this one is only in the mood. The proposal, then, is fulfilled, even though it lacks one of the spices that made the show become a reference in the world: New York.In the two cinematic episodes of Sex and the City, the action follows the same narrative line of his life on television. The only thing really expanded is the schizophrenia of luxury, whose best example is the costumes signed by Patricia Field for each of the characters. And speaking of schizophrenia, the character of Sarah Jessica Parker plays the role that best exposes this issue, either through her clothes, or through a very confused psyche, which combines extremely unconventional and conservatism in the same figure. This time, the writers used a huge gay marriage to talk about civil liberties, and also for Liza Minnelli to star in a version of Single Ladies, hit by singer Beyoncé, in one of the funniest and most embarrassing scenes in the film. Logically, a gay marriage would not be just a place to celebrate this freedom, but all the schizophrenia of consumption and interference from the pop universe even in the most traditional of events.Much more glamor, parties, charm, travel, the best brands, breathtaking scenery, dresses to leave anyone jaw-dropping and unmissable excitement is what promises Sex and the City 2. But what happens when the film fails to present just the who gave you your greatest charisma: 'sex' and 'city'? In this new reunion of the four best New York friends, there is a little bit of everything, except the essentials. First, because three of them are very well married - and perhaps that means lack of sex, since none of them appears having sex on the scene. And the fourth - Samantha, who has always been the most liberal - spends more time complaining about her age than going into action - she even stars in two 'hot' meetings, but it is still little in the face of the girl's man-eating history.The most fascinating thing about "Sex and the City" as a whole is the fact that the public, regardless of sex or sexual option, identifies a little with each character or with the conflicts they experienced in the series and in the cinema. For this to be maintained, they return carrying the essence that marked them. Carrie remains paranoid and perhaps more boring, while Samantha continues with the best comic strips and Charlotte returns to having key moments for free during the screening. The exception is Miranda, whose sarcasm is unfortunately overshadowed, but even so her presence is essential for the balance of the friendship of the four.New York is also a character in history. In the previous feature, the streets of the cosmopolitan city were stages for broken bouquets and amorous twists, even though, from half of the projection to the end, the protagonists also left the city for a renovation trip. In this feature, little is seen of New York and this mischaracterizes what has always been ingrained. The movie's theme song, "Empire State of Mind", by Jay-Z and Alicia Keys, would be perfect if the plot unfolded major conflicts in NY. The new scenario for the story is not completely displaced, not least because cultural issues are interesting to be observed, but the least that the script could do was preserve the basics. Anyway, the trip to Abu Dhabi brings priceless comic moments, but in none of them the problems of each really move the viewer. So it is worth mentioning that this film is purely for entertainment and maybe even more fun than the first, even though this is inferior when it comes to quality.Again, screenwriter, producer and director Michael Patrick King opts for the juxtaposition of extravagant scenes, each with more dazzling costumes and more elaborate situations than the previous one. However, the plot that makes the connection between the various moments of celebration of femininity and each of the "fashion show" looks could be better tied, so that the whole made more sense. As it stands, the romantic comedy falls short and all the moments created to elicit euphoria in the women in the audience seem a little free. The film seeks to deliver to the women in its audience the escapist dream of a luxurious life, in which wonderful men and free vacations can simply fall from the sky. Sex and the City 2 is the fairy tale for the consumer society, in which a fairy godmother in the form of an Arab sheikh rescues women from the hardships of being mothers and wives to take them to the enchanted world of the Middle East, full of possibilities and mysteries.Patrick King recognizes in his script that his protagonists are no longer able to hide wrinkles, even under so much makeup, and position them as true 40s (and 50s) who thought that the stability of life would be maintained when maturity arrived. The issue is not maturity, but the fact that at any point in our lives we will have problems to resolve, and many of them involve feelings and relationships. King's script also shows exhaustion of original situations and sometimes falls into the embarrassment of others. Liza Minnelli singing "Single Ladies" is torture, as well as the extensive musical number of the protagonists singing "I Am Woman". The fashion under the cloth of Arab women is also dispensable.The mood of the text is shallow, but it is within the expiration date. Among the curiosities, a super advertisement of the actress Suzanne Somers, author of a book, among other activities, and also for the singer Paula Abdul who "wins a funny character". Ah! There is also a Brazilian flag with the inscription "I Love São Paulo" (near the end when Charlotte buys t-shirts). Stars Miley Cyrus and Penélope Cruz also make points. The soundtrack is consistent with what is seen on the screen and rescues, from 1986, "True Colors" in the voice of Cindy Lauper. Sex and the City 2 plays with the cinema by inserting in the plot, again, the faux heartthrob launched by Samantha. However, more than that, he uses a classic B&W (It Happened That Night) as a reference to illustrate Carrie's psychological conflict that he thought was living in black and white, but discovers the colors of life.In the direction, King does a little of the same, since he has never been so technical in his filming, being more urban and creative precisely when capturing the soul of New York. So he remains apathetic as a director when he takes the plot to the East. However, the filmmaker's conception of maintaining the created universe, with the brands and wide-open advertisements, as well as the incredible looks bring back the feeling that we are really seeing "Sex and the City", even though it seems like a combination of three episodes in that not everything has its deserved attention, leaving aside and discarding essential characters for the feature. Anyway, only King is able to raise the protagonists with authority and does it well.However, despite all the excesses, the sequel manages to recover from the gaffes of the first film and is not just superficial. Although little tied, the script hits the emotions and dialogues - such as, for example, a great scene between Miranda and Charlotte at the hotel bar in Abu Dhabi -, delivering a result consistent with the trajectory followed by the characters in the six years of the series. Carrie, Miranda, Samantha and Charlotte are again spherical characters, who show the best of their stereotype - the sex buff or the professional superwoman, for example -, and also rich moments when we see them totally disassembled and fragile, like any woman normal. The big budget also helps and the director takes advantage of desert locations and aerial shots in New York, providing beautiful images.Sex and the City 2 has no justification - over 146 minutes - for its existence. Everything is just an excuse for a parade of stunning costumes - and absolutely unlikely - recycled jokes, and, above all, advertising. But that does not mean that the end result is bad. Quite the opposite. It is quite impressive how well they managed to disguise the absence of a more consistent story, which really took us somewhere. The four characters are more united, and look much more like the ones we get used to seeing in the television series, contrary to what was shown in the previous film. Yes, there are great moments and sequences that are a true dream. And if everything is just an excuse to run into old and well-known friends, at least the fun is guaranteed. Sex and city may be lacking, but there is plenty of laughter, lots of sparkling wine and breathtaking events for the unsuspecting.

i really liked this film. i'm not really into chick flicks, but my friend made me watch it and surprisingly i loved it. it's got great locations and real life issues of culture, making it a realistic, yet hilarious, account of holidaying in certain parts of the world. Of course, not being a chick flick kinda girl means that i didn't enjoy this movie as much as avatar or clash of the titans, but i still found myself enjoying it and getting involved in the story line. The acting is brilliant and the fashion is, as always, to die for. Personally i think it would be a great film to watch with your boyfriend or husband (whether he wants to or not) because it will make you value your relationship.

reviews.review_title: The Low Expectations I Had Made This Movie Better
reviews.content: As a heterosexual guy I have watch my share of romantic dramas and coming to see the movie "Sex and the City" I have to say that though I don't completely hate "Sex and the City 2", then again I never had the strong feelings going to see the movie and that I never cared much for the series. I was never invested by the four leading ladies who are constantly obsessed by consuming trendy luxury while talking the talk of sexual empowerment and scoping out a rich beau. Like the series itself and the first installment, they hoped they could swing it both ways. Sadly it was bombarded with vulgar undertones and unscrupulous exhibitions that took over the concept of a serious hidden underneath it.Two years later the sequel reunites the four girls and the vulgarity has elevated to a higher degree. This the consumer-happy quartet locates themselves from their American estates to the very gorgeous, but ultra-expensive Abu Dhabi in the UAE. And though the location was pure eye-candy with the beaches and resorts, I would have felt better watching an infomercial for two and a half hours and would never have known the difference. Just don't engage in tonsil hockey within the public spectrum and make sure that you have enough dough to tip the help generously. The plot is the same crap that materialized from the series. Lawyer Miranda (Cynthia Nixon) is disgruntled by her boss who constantly dismisses her. Instead of doing the sensible thing, she just calls it quits. To her it feels like a win for woman's liberation. When really it's a cop-out. Charlotte (Kristin Davis) is now married with two children wants to get away from the stress of it all even though there's help living with them. Carries (Sarah Jessica Parker) has grown over the fact that her beau is ageing and it outraged when she discovers her book was struck with negative reviews retaliates by kissing an ex-boyfriend. Her husband's reaction is priceless. And sex kitten Samantha (Kim Cattrall) wants to ward off menopause by feeding off hormones due to the restrictions of having sex in a Muslim country.And sure the film takes largely in such heavy-handed topics like menopause and culture clashes. And sure being a mother to young children can be believably overwhelming, it still feels very hokey in my mind's perspective. Sure there's some compelling jabs about declining economy and feeling heroic of child raising alone, but the fact of staying in luxurious hotels makes these ladies hypocrites especially when Carrie tips of a Hindu servant to return home to India to be with his wife.Sure I might be jabbing on the film over the characters, but in the end I'm jabbing at both of them evenly. But if I had the money like them I still wouldn't have liked the film. It just doesn't measure up in what it preaches out to be. Even the fashion looks absurd and not trendy. The women's fashion is over-the-top and scruffy. The camera-work looks jilted and very tiresome at best. Even Liza Minelli's song number looked strange like her face and body didn't match. It was quite an unorthodox experience.

reviews.review_title: Am I the only one who likes this movie?
reviews.content: Okay, I have to admit, I expected more from Sex and the City 2. I absolutely love the series, and was looking forward to the movie. The movie had it's flaws and the story line wasn't that great, but still it was a movie with 4 great girls, who all looked and were great. The fact that Carry and Big are finally happy together and that Charlotte's marriage finally has it's flaws, made it realistic and nice to watch. I assure you, if you really love SATC, you will love this movie. Samantha made me laugh the entire movie and also Miranda starts to loosen up. I hope there will be a third movie. And of course, the clothes were great! Every scene 4 different and fabulous outfits, Patricia Field has done a great job. SATC 2 is fabulous, trust me.GO WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!
Costume + Music : 6Setting and some beautiful scenes : 1Cheesy Ending : -1

This movie reminded me of Dumb and Dumber.....except that they are NOT as smart as Lloyd and Harry nor as sexy, interesting, appealing, warm, witty or forward growing. Also, Lloyd and Harry dressed MUCH better....some of the SATC clothes were HIDEOUS!!!!! If only I could rate it with a negative number.One of the single most pathetic pieces of cinematography and writing ever. Ever.It would be easy to write an essay for every 5 minutes of film describing how offensive, sub-par and annoying each segment was without even breaking a sweat.Here's a fact also - if these woman/actresses had any talent they would have never done this movie after reading the script - so much for "producer" credits and experience. At the very least they should have been able to exert some control, direction and/or changes to this train wreck.Breakdown of the women: narcissistic, whiny, dumb, ignorant, self-absorbed, classless, boring, shallow, weak, drama queens, embarrassing, old, needy and in need of mega therapy.I'm going to agree with other posters who said that SJP is Ugly...no hating here...just burned corneas from staring at the screen in disbelief and realization that there must have been some soft focus lenses getting daily use of the series set.These women need to eat also - it was very distracting to watch them move with sinewy muscle and protruding bones.I'll probably update this review further since there are many things to say but for now please listen to other low rated reviews and do not insult your intelligence. Nothing but plot holes, filler and clichés.This movie was baaaaaad - and unless you are sheep that can understand this baaaaad mess, then you should find something more worthy.

I wondered why Michael Patrick King - the writer/director of SATC 2, and overseer of most of the best episodes of the HBO series - could have fallen so flat (if the critics were to be believed). In my opinion, he didn't. It's just that the first 15-minutes, featuring Stanford and Anthony's gay wedding, was unbelievably bad. These characters would never even be dating let alone tying the knot. The Liza Minnelli cameo was beyond preposterous (her scene completely ruined the song SINGLE LADIES forever for me). Even Carrie's "hat" made me throw up a little - it looked like something a Disney villainess would wear. Grade so far: F.But after this, the movie is solid and entertaining. The characters and their story lines are all spot on. All the plot turns are believable enough - even the coincidental appearance of Aiden in Abu Dhabi. The only minor complaint I had after the initial 15-minutes was the farcical burka-draped escape from the souk toward the end of the film. But even that scene had its enjoyable moments, such as trying to identify Charlotte, who had separated from the other three, just by her shoes.The actors and actresses are all in top form. I loved Cattrall's Samantha as the embodiment of the "ugly American" in a foreign land. Davis works Charlotte's marriage-anxiety very well (although she has always been a little too muggy for my tastes), and Nixon is finally handed a very upbeat arc that really elevates her character Miranda.Sarah Jessica Parker is given a hard line to tread between nag and open-minded adventurer. I have to say she is superb. Never one to overshadow her more colorful co-stars, her humble and understated performance grounds the film.I think the culture clash aspect of the film was handled very realistically. A measure of trust combined with a measure of caution, as seen in Charlotte's introducing herself to her Arabic hosts as "York" and not Goldenblatt. Also handled well was the appropriateness of behavior that Samantha takes for granted in the USA. All in all, it would be a mistake for any fan to forego this film because of a few over-the-top moments..

If you loved the series you will love this. It's got your favourite characters behaving in their own inimitable way, wearing the loveliest outfits - perfectly accessorised - while facing the trials and tribulations of relationships and sex. If you hate chick-flics, you should know already to stay away. I don't like many of them either, but then I got the opportunity to go to a private screening and decided I should face it with an open mind and a couple of friends. No good deed goes unpunished. Unfortunately the story couldn't convince me. Perhaps die-hard SATC fans can revel in the clichés - the gay wedding just had to be fabulously over the top (kudos to Ms. Minelli, though, those are some great pegs and at her age!), Samantha gets arrested for lewd behaviour in Abu Dhabi, Miranda is stressed out at work and Charlotte can't cope with her kids without the bra-less nanny (don't worry, she's not the threat to the marriage that neurotic Charlotte fears) and Carrie and Big go through yet another crisis in their relationship, only to come out even more perfect in the end (to the point where one wonders whether a third installment is possible without culminating in the two having surgery to be joined at the hip) - but I would have preferred it if the film had been somewhat less formulaic.I'm an optimist, I believe it's possible. And there were some themes that I liked, the black- and-white versus colour, for instance - which didn't need a sappy voice-over at the end to explain it. We got it - but all in all not enough to make me love it. A fifty/fifty movie.

I've always loved this film. It's fun and easy to watch and a nice fantasy to imagine what it would be like to live life as the 4 girls do.It's relevant to the series. The people writing the bad reviews are obviously taking the movie too seriously, and that's not what the movie is about!

reviews.review_title: Not the show, not the first, but fun!
reviews.content: Many criticize the girls for being "whores" and saying they send the wrong message to females today. In the early seasons of the show, I would attest to this, but throughout the later seasons, the first movie and the second, I would argue that the girls have matured, taken responsibility for their lives - except for Samantha, who remains the wildest of the four, even after her serious relationship with Smith.The New York sequences are perfect; after all, it's where the girls belong. Even Abu Dhabi wasn't terrible, until Samantha's arrest. From that point on the plot felt convoluted and rushed. This, about half an hour from the end of the movie, however, didn't ruin the rest of the movie, which realistically deals with life after marriage, life after kids and even the tough reality of the workplace. I was thrilled to see Aidan's return, I have always been an Aidan girl. However, as with Smith's appearance,I felt it was mostly just thrown in there for some familiar old thrills from the show. If Aidan had been brought in earlier in the plot, his story line would have been much more strong and enjoyable.The movie isn't perfect, it's very different from the feel of the first, and even most of the shows. However, throw caution to the wind. Put on some heels, go with the girls. Don't think you're going to see the movie of the year (you're not) - think you're going for fun - which you are.

Ok so the film is a little culturally insensitive, it's not meant to be critiqued by Brian Cox. It's funny, it actually deals with relevant issues and more importantly, it was a feast for the eyes. From the scenery to the outfits to the men (& by men I mean Chris Noth's tanned and shirtless scenes and the delightful Max Ryan in his final scene! Oi veh!!), it was sumptuous for the eyes.
I really appreciated the film tackling with issues ranging from Samantha's ageing woes and Miranda's sexual discrimination at work to Charlotte's insecurities about her marriage. Carrie was always my least favourite character in this so the one minor annoyance was Big's (I'm sorry, I still can't call him 'John') reaction to her relentlessly spoiled, selfish behaviour. But other than that, I laughed at a film that doesn't take itself too seriously. Maybe some of the other reviewers could do the same.
This movie is only one time watch and time pass i think movie is so amazing but not its little comedy and little nude in this

reviews.review_title: it wasn't too bad of a movie but could have been better.
reviews.content: I think if they would have put Richard Wright and Samantha back together again it would have been a 10 out of 10...they were such a awesome couple and he showed a side of Samantha that her vulnerability as a women and a softness that I have never seen her with anyone else that she has been with in any of the Sex And The City's..I hope they do a Sex And The City 3 and they add these two lovers back together again...I would love to see them finally together just like Big and Carrie...By putting these two together again is the only way I can even see a Sex And The City 3 ever happening...and that is just my opinion...

reviews.review_title: Waiting for the DVD might not even be worth it.
reviews.content: I will come out and say this first: I do not closely follow the Sex and the City series and have never been a huge fan of the show. But after living with sorority girls and having a girlfriend who loves the show, I've been exposed to it enough to tell you that Sex and the City 2 is far under par for what the franchise is capable of. The film is just empty; what little plot there is seems to be very loose and inconsequential. I just can't say the film went anywhere, and I gained little, if anything, from it. Everyone I went with--all avid fans--were just as disappointed as I. Save your money now and rent it later.

I loved the series, absolutely adore it. I loved the first movie, I thought it was fantastic and it really felt like closure for me. This movie was terrible, undeniably offensive, and advanced nothing in the story line at all! Honestly, how did anyone enjoy it all? I was cringing most of the time, as soon as they started poking fun at the burkhas I knew it was going down hill. The entire undertone was "fuck this backwards country!" although by the end, Samantha certainly wasn't hinting it subtly. Apart from the entire cringe that was these girls in the Middle East, what story line was there?! Honestly, what was there? Oh Charlotte is stressed out. Okay? Carrie got a bad book review. Okay? This movie couldn't have more honestly been a desperate grab for cash, because nothing else like a real plot seemed to be even been considered. I'd even be willing to overlook the absurdity of Carrie meeting Aiden in the market, if the rest of the movie just wasn't so terrible. The only part I really enjoyed was a two second clip of the 'gay' servant holding the bags and twinkling his eyes. I will never watch this movie again, pretend it doesn't exist, and go back to having the first movie (which I watched three times over 2 days) by my closure for the series. What a way to taint something I love so much.

reviews.review_title: Looking for a funny movie without an ounce of reality?
reviews.content: First of all, the Sex and The City franchise has ALWAYS been known not to be realistic ~ four wealthy NYC women who are always in each other's lives who never have a boring moment for a nanosecond. If they're not sleeping with a gorgeous guy, they're sipping cosmopolitans, eating at a high-end restaurant, shopping at Gucci, or doing SOMETHING that is flat-out entertaining. Every single TV episode was like that, as was the first film. Obviously, this movie sequel is just that, and then some.This movie is pure escapism; nothing more, nothing less. It's not meant to be taken seriously!The 4 characters who lead ultra-extravagant lives get an all-expense paid trip to a middle- eastern country and are treated like royalty, complete with their own floor at a 5-star hotel, their own butler (who can only leave when dismissed) and their own chauffeur. That's pure fantasy, every girl's dream to be a princess.Samantha's character, as always, delivers the funniest lines/situations in the film. When she's caught having sex on the beach, gets arrested, and the girls eventually have to leave for the airport, a woman dressed in middle-eastern attire shoos the girls into a secret room, where other middle-eastern women are hiding. And what do they reveal? The latest fashion from the USA.Many people didn't like this movie because it's not the least bit realistic. Again I say: the Sex & The City TV show and BOTH the first movie are simply the daydreams of every American girl.If you want a movie that will make you laugh and take you away from your everyday life for 2 hours, then this is the movie for you.

reviews.review_title: Les Demoiselles d' Abu Dabi? Non!
reviews.content: When I saw the first installment of the two films I was transfixed by the discovery of a new spin in film-making: in order to "stay young against nature" as one critic put it, the four characters, to put it that way, resorted to a new kind of make-up that I would call cubist make-up; and as far as I know, this really, really is a first.Two years later the new film also establishes, albeit in a minor scale, the flash style, not so much as flashy or flashing style, but as a flash back and style-of-the-times combo, as the opening credits dumb us.Whether the films stay in tune with the series in spirit depends largely on matters of taste, and I mean that as more important than the ideological import many people depend their critique upon, for the taste exemplified by the series was, despite the occasional witticisms, largely dependent on a privileged and smug and confused sexual/economic impulse; the economic crisis, as at the only point it is referred to by the Samantha character with a yelling voice carrying a stupid, dismissing comment as if the economic crisis was some personal offense, seems to collapse into their "midlife crisis" Carrie later refers to, once more impersonating the endearing, humanely preoccupied other side of the coin, while obfuscating the fact she is on that coin. And the collapse is total, midlife and economic crisis falling the one into the other (watch how bizarre the scene between Charlotte and Miranda is, when they exchange luxurious motherly problems while sipping their cocktails like Russian roulette).Now, let's get back to the aesthetic heart of the matter. To cut a long story short, the film risks to earn the title of "Les Demoiselles d' Abu Dabi - non!" echoing Picasso's defining masterpiece "Les Demoiselles d' Avignon" with its cubist, deconstructed facades (the painting's original title, as Picasso always referred to, was "The Brothel"). Here the cubist, deconstructed facades run from the horse-mouthed make-up, to the ludicrous opening credits, to the beyond-the-grave Liza Minelli, to the gay marriage as redeeming alibi (all alibis in the series are gay alibis), to Samantha's Michael Jackson epaulets, the bi-dimensional hotel-and-desert poor, poor depiction of Abu Dabi (which actually is a cheaper country, production-wise) and the more self-castigating actually rather than racist jokes. It's some ass-mind-kiss-numb vortex. Why is that is answered in the end by the unabashed moral, striping the whole series from any witty past: Tradition needs its own decorating. This is one hell of a senseless line. In a tradition-as-decoration universe, you may find yourself expecting that when you squeeze a pimple, instead of pus, some wedding-cake will spurt out. And that may quite easily and cosmetically happen to you.

reviews.review_title: A Garbage, Extremely Cringey Movie That Ruins A Franchise.
reviews.content: Wow. Just wow. What an awful movie. This movie made me hate every character and throw up in my mouth with every bit of lame, contrived dialogue and forced stupid scenarios. Please. Do not watch this. I wish someone would have warned me. AND NOW I CAN NEVER UNSEE IT.

The first film was OK, easy watching for fans of the TV show. The sequel is even more lacking. The plot is poor at best as is script. Many aspects of the film simply make you wonder if the film makers remember the joy of the original TV show. Ladies, watch it once to follow the story in case there is a third one and it's brilliant, or watch it because it's easy watching and requires no brain power, but don't watch it and expect anything amazing. There is one truly agonising scene in the film by the pool in the hotel where I would suggest there is a certain level of racism involving Muslim women in veil. I was uncomfortable watching the scene, and I think it's a miracle it wasn't cut out.

Carrie, honey, you need to fire your personal make-up artist, Judy Chin. And the cinematographer, John Thomas, needs to go, too. In the first Sex & the City it was hard to look at Sarah Jessica Parker because of the big mole on her chin that was so prominent, the Lighting Director (unnamed) must have shown a spotlight on it -- it filled the screen and distracted from the dialog. In Sex and the City 2, the mole was gone, but the make-up was so obviously caked on, Sarah and Miranda and Charlotte, too, looked 10 years older than their real ages. Only Samantha -- the oldest in real life -- looked stunning in every shot. Director King, don't you check how the make-up looks in the early rushes before you blow millions on a movie that's supposed to make these fashionistas look their best so we will envy them? I, too, read the reviews before I went and decided no matter how bad it might be I would enjoy a couple hours with my screen "girlfriends". I was pleasantly surprised that what was touted as "Outstanding!" (dance number at wedding) was only so-so; and what was rated as "Horrible!' was amusing. i can't understand why the ladies would show so much cleavage and wear shorts in a country where covering up head to toe is the law for native females. Overall, 7 stars, but it could have been a 10.

What was the point of making this movie? (And I'm using the term "movie" very loosely here!) It's about absolutely nothing! Four spoilt cows whose biggest problem in life is which shoes to wear get spoilt even further in Abu Dhabi, experiencing luxury no human being deserves to be in, and this is it. That's the film. I couldn't believe my eyes, I was waiting for something more, some reason why all this money was spent to make this piece of rubbish, and it never happened. Next time just donate this money to charity. 95 million dollars could have changed a lot of lives for the better. Instead, you put it down this hideous pointless drain.

reviews.review_title: It was WAY better than all the bad reviews said
reviews.content: Despite all the horrendous reviews, I decided to see the movie because a friend of mine said it was good. Still, my expectations were very low. So I was surprised by how much I liked it--- even my husband admitted it was fun. One of the biggest complaints about the movie was where Charlotte and Miranda ask each other how they could possibly raise children without help-- and then they give a toast to women that manage to do it without nannies/maids. It wasn't condescending-- it seemed very real. And, something most women who have help never consider. And while the plot was a little far-fetched-- it was nothing compared to your average James Bond movie where the whole thing is more made up than any fairy tale.Overall, I am glad I went. If you're a fan--go with a group of friends, knock back some cosmos before hand, and enjoy it for what it is-- a fun summer movie.

reviews.review_title: First part OK, last 45 minutes unwatchable
reviews.content: When I started this movie, I was thinking "hey, this isn't so bad -- why all the hate?" It was nice seeing the ladies again, and even though the dialogue was pretty cheesy, I was actually enjoying it. BUT by the last 45 minutes, I was ready to just turn it off. Around the time that Samantha got arrested, the plot just got so absurd that I wasn't sure if I could make it through the end. It became too stupid and NOTHING like the actual show. Granted, it wasn't a great movie before that point, just mediocre, but it was certainly watchable, especially if you were a fan of and miss SATC.I think it's time to say good-bye to the girls. There's no reason another movie needs to be made.
As in the first film, there are also extremely empty scenes in this film. They took a half-hour movie closer to two and a half hours with empty scenes.

reviews.review_title: Please tell me it is a joke...
reviews.content: I do not care, I really don't, how much SJP got paid to participate and crawl into this pool of refuse neck-deep. She did not even try to swim in it. And she took others along for a dip in the muck.The opening ceremony is gratuitous, the heck, every scene is gratuitous. The characters have no character, the plot has no story, the outfits have no stylist and the movie apparently had no director either.Everything is so outlandishly disjointed I beg to differ it is an alternative, science fiction picture set in a post-modern surrealist fantasy. It isn't. I tried not to cringe through it and even started drinking half-way through, didn't help either.It is dumber than EU directives. Do yourself a favour and avoid at all cost. It is astonishingly bad.

reviews.review_title: Me and the movie just us 2
reviews.content: In two years amazing things did not happen. It was great at the beginning to have a quick tour of Manhattan and knowing how the company of four had met and what they were like(the audience just loved it). After relaxing for a while I felt like I was in rush hour. The scenes were very fast and had no connection that would give the time to enjoy the movie. Too much time spent in Antony's and Stanford's wedding which main theme was the excess, no time given to the audience to enjoy such event (such as laughs, good jokes)-best performance Mrs. Liza Minnelli. During the reference to the lives of four, such as their family, I was not satisfied by the fact that Carrie and Mr.Big did not keep their apartment and chose another one less big at which the scenes were not bright compared with Carrie's old apartment and had no special decoration as the other apartments. (I mean the ambiance was not good). And then there is the trip to the Middle East (thanking Jerry – the audience did not have the chance to enjoy his presence at the movie). Amazed by the fact that the transportation of the company of four was made by four Maybachs (excellent choice of car)we arrived at the luxury hotel. The movie from that point started to get a social aptitude. We were overwhelmed by the social comme il- faut arabian law(which OK it is true but we want to see some funny action and no restraints) and we did not have the chance to see all the outfit of the company of four. Furthermore, the scenes were very quick, some were funny enough but in overall I think the audience was disappointed. The movie's main ambiance was a little depressing. The only story I enjoyed was Miranda's (which during their trip was very amusing) because she had something to give. The camera "had a fight" with Carrie and Charlotte. They looked tired and old. Miranda was great. I do not know much about the filters that they use in cameras but they were somebad takes. My opinion about this movie is that it was sloppy. The movie was big but they chose to give to the audience many stories in quick scenes and did not concentrate to some that needed more time to develop. They could skip some parts. I guess this movie would be great in episodes. As part of the audience in the end of the movie I was tired, emotionally and physically. Emotionally because I was drifted from funny jokes to malign, from optimistic views to the opposite and physically because my eyes were tired from the quick scenes and the alternation dark/bright scenes(indoors,outdoors,night,day). Conclusion: the movie was OK and could have been great.

Not many movies achieve this level of awfulness. This movie should never have been made, the production money would have been better spent on anything else. I like most movies at some level and rarely walk out on a movie. I am so thankful that I did not pay to purchase a theater ticket to see this atrocious mess. As a rental, I my money loss was small; unfortunately the time lost can never be regained. I kept hoping for something redeeming, something worthwhile, something that would provide a bit of worth.
