It's bad soap opera, and every time it comes close to addressing an interesting issue - such as how the reality of a marriage differs from the idealized preconception of one - it quickly backtracks, apologizing along the way for getting serious. Fans will bathe in this sewer of materialistic excess because they appreciate any opportunity to spend time with their favorite characters. Everyone else will stare at the screen in a state of enhanced boredom if the sheer tedium of watching this production doesn't shut down the brain altogether. The first Sex and the City movie was marginally watchable. There was a narrative line, the characters weren't consistently reprehensible, and the humor wasn't quite as forced. Sex and the City 2 has taken all that was bad about its predecessor and amplified it.

reviews.review_title: No Sex... made in Middle East!!!!
reviews.content: Two days ago I got my best friend and went to see Sex and the City. And us, as so many others before us were not impressed. When I got out of the theater my notion was that the production team had no script what-so-ever in mind, and they just scribbled down 4 little plots that could (and were resolved)in a five minute radius. The rest of the film is summed up to easy jokes and lavish (but not so fine) fashion. That was not a film, it was project runway with continuity issues. Don't get me wrong,it was fine for an all-girls night out but it was not the Sex and the City that we all know and love (I still watch the series in re-runs). 1st issue: Where is the City? I mean 80% of the movie is set in the Middle-East (and filmed in Marocco actually). It should be called Sex and the City on vacation. For me it should have been half the movie in NYC and the other half in M.E. 2nd issue: It was too long. For a film that was so sloppy written and had little to no plot, it should have ended sooner. 3rd issue: Camera angles people, editing room, filters. The ladies are growing and some shots were really unflattering especially for Carrie and Sharlotte (oh God the close-up when SJP puts the eyeliner! If I was SJP I would cut that scene).Samantha was OK and Miranda for me was gorgeous.(her style has really evolved from the series). 4th issue: What happened to the characters? We're used to Carrie being whiny, selfish and messing it up but she sure did a number this time. For a girl who spend 6 years chasing Mr. Big (Chris Noth was great by the way) she surely messed it up with the guy she "allegedly" loves. I liked Sharlotte's storyline (though she went a bit overboard)and I liked Miranda's too. Actually I liked Miranda more than the other three. And Samantha, oh God Samantha. We know she's over the top, but man that was too much. Aside the sex-drive, Sam Jones is also a PR Pro. Let me tell you something; she didn't act like one, not in the very least. Also it was no wonder the Emirates didn't allow them to shoot the movie there. Some part were really disrespectful to the culture there. I'm not a fan of romantic comedies. I always prefer a good shoot-out that a tear fest. But Sex and the City is my guilty pleasure because is more comedy with a spice of Love. I couldn't find that spice, not in this movie. If they are to make a third, they should pay very close attention to the script. Otherwise leave a fine franchise at rest. Peace.

This movie was a total disappointment. And the worst part of it is, is that I didn't even get to see the ending because the theater I saw it at kept shutting off. After waiting in line for an hour with my sister and friend to see the 12:01 premier, something I was planning on since the first film, I was very upset with where they took the movie. It was nothing like the series that I fell in love with. In the show they were women to look up to and to respect and you couldn't wait to see what they did next. But in this film they just made you want to stop them from whatever they might do next. I was disappointed with the first film and this one took it to a whole different level.

I was shocked when I saw this movie. When it opened and you saw the girls in their 80s garb I really thought there would have been more to it, not 30 second flashes of them looking just how you thought they would look. The general disregard Samantha had for Middle Eastern customs is just disgusting, from her skin-baring outfits to groping the foreign business man at the hookah bar, I was embarrassed to even watch her behave in that manner. Miranda was almost as bad with her attempts to speak the language. And Charlotte being afraid to use her last name Goldenblatt because they were in the UAE was the most offensive. I am very upset with the portrayal of Aiden, they turned him into a better-looking version of Big. I was excited at first when I heard he was in this movie, but after seeing how his character was written, had I known it would have worked out the way it did I wouldn't have bothered seeing it.The "fight" scene with Big (if you can even call it a fight) was poorly done and his way of accepting Carrie's apology I felt was lame. Heaven forbid a married woman should wear a wedding ring! Oh my what a punishment. All in all I am super disappointed in the whole thing. The Liza cameo was so painful to watch, even though it was at the start of the movie I was tempted to leave after that scene. Don't waste your money, it's not worth the $10 you're going to spend, rent it one night and save yourself the money of seeing it in theaters.

I am a big fan of SATC. I started watching the show when season 1 was on HBO, and I bought every single season on DVD. Although I did not love the first movie, I thought it was watchable.SATC 2 is something should never been made. I just don't know what happened (or not have happened) to the girls, so many years after the end of the TV series. It seemed like there is just nothing left to be told about them anymore. The girls are older, and yet seeming even more immature than before. The jokes are nowhere near what the TV series offered. This movie was just trying to milk on everything.And the fifth major character of SATC! OMG the CITY! The writer dared moved the story out of NYC and immediately the charm has turned way down. The fish out of water formula was not played well. Things turn a little bit offensive at times.True fans of SATC, it's OK to stay away from this one to save your fond memories of the show. It's a nightmare. A good example of illustrating when something good should be left that way. SATC is ruined by this movie.

reviews.review_title: Not good, definitely overdone but still fun to watch
reviews.content: I get the reviews. I too was disappointed. But honestly, if you once enjoyed Sex and the City - the series, you will want to see it. To say it is a waste of money? Yes and No. Yes, the actors seem to have forgotten how to act. The shouts and screams seem over the top and the girls lost their fun interaction. But is seeing the actors of your once favorite show again worth a couple of bucks? Yes.Let's be fair. Was it worse than the first movie? Not really. At least now there is a story to tell, even if it is a bad one. Let's not forget that the first movie only had a story line because of mr Big's two minute pre wedding jitters. What story would we have had if Carrie had not exploded and made a big deal out of nothing. After all Big turned around almost instantly. For Carrie to act this way when he is the love of her life, seemed like a desperate attempt from the writers to get a story line.So.. with this new one, at least it makes more sense. And yes, the oversexed attitude of Samantha lost its appeal. And yes, Charlotte and Miranda looked old. And yes, Carrie became a whining wife. So one is right to dispute that the original characters just aren't what they used to be.But despite that, it is still Sex and the City and they are still Carrie, Miranda, Charlotte and Samantha. If anything the writers tried too hard to make them into their fun characters. Maybe they forgot that having these women on the screen is enough to please the millions of fans. We really did not need the writers to exhaust themselves over a script that is clearly overdone.If I were to say anything about this movie, it would be that it is overdone. But in some way I still enjoyed it, just because I got a glimpse of my favorite TV series and because of the vow I took to watch any movie,show or series that features these women together. Whether it is a disappointment or not. I will choose to forget the bad parts and remember the good parts. Even though that is a slight challenge here for Sex and the City 2.

I am, like most the review writers, is a fan of the HBO series, so of course, the earliest time I could see the movie, I rented the DVD and with a great expectation, I watched. This movie just made me want to cry. I guess the time really does not pass on any and really leave marks. I guess the edited pictures of the move made me think that after all these years, the girls still got it. I watched the last movie 2 years ago and the foursome still looked OK. But this time, I was really startled, scared, ambushed by screen after screen of each actor's fading face. Big, he is still charming but his face is starting to look like a senior citizen. Carrie, I don't know why she is still into big bushy hair and big skirts at her age, she really looks like a witch. With her skinny face, it looks even more gruesome with her eyes look smaller ever and cheek bones sticking out. Charlotte, she is still graceful but with her aging face, she should not dress like 35 anymore to make her look don't fit with her dress. Miranda, she is still put together but when at one scene when she turned around with a frowning face, her cheek looks like it was going so down it was going to fall out of her chin. The only actor in there that does not show as much sign of aging is Aidan, boy when he appeared, it was such a cool air in a hot sticky day, he still looks the same, maybe a bit darker, face - a little wider, but at least it does not look like it is falling apart or looking like a skull with rotten skin on it. Finally Samantha, she is losing her face definition and she looks like a grandma at best but she still acts like a crazy woman. I couldn't resist to check on their ages and found that they are not so old yet, 45, or 55. Aidan is 49 but he looks the best. I really think these actors should take the responsibility in taking care of their appearance, 45 looking so old and 55 looking like a senior already is crazy. Isn't 45 the new 35 and 55 the new 45? Their face look like the their wax sculpture is melting and their face is rapidly melting away and they are still walking around.Overall, the style is still the same, glamorous, women issues with great hair and great outfit, but that really need some great face and great attitude to carry that, or it is just one big disgusting stinking act. I saw there are already a lot of bad reviews but I just cannot stay quiet and not say how disappointed I am with the movie.I really hope this movie does not come out the III and these characters can rest in peace to leave us the nice memories.

reviews.review_title: Michael Patrick King has turned into an amateur.
reviews.content: So, it seemed like some airhead sat down one day and wrote a script complete with predictable clichés and barely-funny jokes, oh and some lame slapstick, all set in the Middle East(!). Why not Paris? How about Rome? Athens is nice. But no: the misogynist capital of the world, this is the fun fun place The Girls are taking us this time around. Eventually the writer ran out of dialogue so he got everybody on stage to sing I Am Woman to kill a little time. It was embarrassing to watch so I fast-forwarded. My boyfriend didn't even like this movie and he's a total chick.Hey, just a thought: what if we got a *positive* message about growing older as women (for a change)? I'm menopausal and I love it. Its not anywhere NEAR as bad as Samantha makes it out to be. In fact, its not bad at all. This movie, however, IS. Better luck next time, Mr.King.

even with 2 margaritas this movie was still too stupid. I am so thankful I read early reviews, so I didn't pay good money out of pocket to watch these 50 plus women (btw, I am 52) trying to be 25 again. I waited for it to be shown on my premium movie channel. Seriously, I am so glad it did this. There are too few redeeming moments. Not enough to override the corny nonsense.Please! As an addict of the original sex and the city -what a disappointment. Please, please movie people: No sex and the city 3!! It would be too sad to watch more of these 50+ women pretend to be in their 20s. Sad sad sad.Katherine

reviews.review_title: Sex and Luxury and Drugs (and not much City)
reviews.content: I was taken along to watch this movie with my wife; not being particularly au fait with the series, nor having watched the first movie. I therefore felt I could look at the movie somewhat more objectively than my wife or her friends did. I have to say that the film surprised me in that there wasn't much of the 'city' in Sex and the City. It pretty much went from a wedding in a countryside retreat to the Middle East; and New York itself, despite featuring over and over as the place of wonder and aspiration in the soundtrack ("....n' Noooooooooo Yauuuuuk..."), featured very little. Otherwise than this my overarching feeling was that the film was completely preoccupied with three themes; sex, luxury and drugs (in the broad, stimulants, sense). It was as if the script writers put these things on a huge cork-board and then set to writing every scene looking only at these three words. Firstly the sex. Now this title-element did not suffer a lack of presence in the film in the way the City did. Yes, sex was omnipresent throughout the film. Not just the physical, graphic sex or nudity, although that was in plentiful supply. No, there was also a constant drip-feed of innuendo, sex-talk, body parts (the nanny's breasts, the man's erection, the Rugby-player's bodies, the exposed legs...), gay cheating, straight cheating, kissing, touching and sexual frustration in general. Secondly was the luxury. Now again, this featuring heavily in itself comes as no surprise, but I think I was just shocked at the sheer relentlessness of the theme in the film. Luxury fashion of course; but also luxury rural retreats, restaurants, apartments, furniture, Rolexs, diamond rings, cars, TVs, airline seats, servants, drivers, trips, food, animals, drinks... I read some time ago that this would be a recession- film, where Big would lose his job and we would see another side of the city, but I guess like a pre-election government they eventually thought that's not what the voters (viewers) really wanted to hear about. Instead they went square opposite, going all out on the luxury, but throwing in a couple of occasional - and therefore completely incongruous - references to "this awful recession". I guess the risk of making a very boom-time-riches film, set in recession-ridden NY is what made them change the location. Instead deciding to set most of the film in the permanently oil-rich Middle East, and have almost all the antics funded by an oil-rich sheikh with an endless stream of money. Whilst this perhaps made more sense, it did in my opinion take the film to a sickening level of luxury. Like being force-fed ten portions of your favourite desert, the unending and unearned, undeserved continual opulence and grandeur were laid on so thick that I think after half an hour most people will become either immune to it or nauseated by it.Finally, there were the drugs. As noted above I mean in the stimulant sense, as in caffeine, alcohol and similar substances (although there were hashish pipes and boxes/mouthfuls of pills as well). Admittedly I consume both caffeine and alcohol and have nothing against either, but I was amazed by the amount of both in the film; it was as if one or other had to be in every single scene, as a sort of visual liquid-stimulant for the audience. Filter Coffee, Tea, Middle-Eastern Tea from little golden cups, Tea from Silver Teapots, Espresso, Tea from China Cups, Warm Milk with Cinammon (perhaps to break the chain of alcohol, caffeine, alcohol, caffeine), Champange, Champagne Cocktails, White Wine, Red Wine, Pink cocktails, Orange cocktails, Other cocktails, Whiskey... the list goes on. All in all I would say that as far as sheer escapism goes the film did tick a lot of boxes, but personally it left me with a very hollow feeling.

I was so excited to see this movie and I couldn't wait for it to come out! I was very disappointed when I read the reviews of the movie. I hesitated dragging my husband on our night out to see it, but we were in for a treat! Sex and the City 2 was made with a different outlook than the series and the first movie and that is why a lot of people didn't like it. It focuses on the married lives of 3 of the 4 friends and it has no longer that cool-single-new york city lifestyle happening, where we constantly watched Carrie dragging herself around the city looking for love and looking to be loved. The single crowd could no longer identify with the characters since they were all married and Samantha, who is the only one with the crazy fun single lifestyle has menopause and gets comments on being old for her fashion style. If I was single, after seeing this movie, I would have also hated it and found it repulsive to watch, since its focusing on married people and the ones who are not married or getting married are old and menopausal. Nevertheless, as for married people I find it a very good entertaining film, easy and fun to watch, with problems that married couples can related to. The middle-eastern experience was fun, since they have played too much the new york city lifestyle and it was very refreshing to have them in a different scenery, and it gave the movie a funny twist. I expected it to be a lot worse. Not bad for Carrie and her learning experience on love and marriage! If you like this kind of movies and shows, don't hesitate to watch it!!!

Well, I went to see this one with my wife. I don't know anything about this series, but I was expecting a girl's comedy (that's OK, fashion, funny situations, not bad). And it began as expected, with funny situations and presenting four well educated, professionally successful, wealthy and independent women in their 30s to 50s (at least seemed to be the idea). Then it came the Middle East and the women started to act like teenagers from a poor neighborhood that just hit the lotto and the film became superficial, absurd and worst of all Boring. At the end went so bad that I started to think in films like "The Naked Gun" and "Scary Movie". I never understood any character; the "lawyer" looked like the intern of the firm and it seems she didn't gave a penny for his son and husband; the "mother" (who uses and expensive skirt to do pastry?) was just a flat character and not even funny ; the "publicist" was taken from a low budget x-rated film, vulgar, brainless, over the top superficial with a sex appetite that never was explained or even interesting; and finally the "writer" (because all girls movies should have one) was a cheesy, predictable and teen character. The end was beyond ridiculous with the Muslim women using "expensive garments" (the leader looked like a parrot) and hiding in a cheap market, I would guess wealthy women in the Middle East may have better places to be and may use more comfortable clothes for that weather (which can be expensive of course). Finally I will talk about men. They basically could be changed for clothes, accessories or even a pet and the history will be the same, but lets be fair, women in boys films are also for show up. SATC is a long, most of the time boring, superficial and silly comedy, if your girl like it, I would think twice to continue dating her.

reviews.review_title: We're off to see the cheik the wonder cheik of Abu Dhabi
reviews.content: As a Middle Easterner who left the highly conservative country of Saudi Arabia seeking freedom, I really hoped that this film would tastefully draw attention on some important issues like human law violations when it comes to freedom of speech not freedom to F**K. I thought maybe Carrie will get in some trouble for writing a piece on some of the outdated traditions of the Arabian Gulf. King, however preferred to give the platform to Samantha to do all of the 'oh no they didn't' for them.I love the series and I liked the first film because we needed real closure. However, they seem to have ran out of idea's and decided to turn to fiction rather than what the show has always been about which was reality and human relations. This film lacks a lot of research when it comes to UAE and the Arabian Gulf. Facts are misrepresented and although they did reveal some realities, the film reminded me of Aladdin the animated film where they embark on their riffraff journey. Forced adventure and negligence to find the line between provocative and distasteful. **SPOILER**One thing that really disturbed me was the scene where Charlotte tells Carrie that she's using her Christian name York as opposed to her Jewish name Goldenblatt. Carrie asks her why and she quickly replies repetitively "we're in the Middle East" but then Carrie reaffirms that UAE is the "New Middle East".Now this would've been a wonderful message to send out if it wasn't for the ignorance of the writers. The UAE and most gulf countries do not object to the entry of Jews in their countries but they do object to the entry of Israelis due the political problems between Israel and most Arab countries. Carrie's response to Charlotte would've been an ever greater one if Samantha did not end the trip by saying "new Middle East my a$$" . I ponder as to what was the intention of the whole new ME thing to begin with? If the four sexy new yorkers are there to break stereotypes or reinforce them ?This film lacked a sense of reality and lacked a lot of research.I give it a 4/10. I loved seeing my girls again but I'm afraid my girls have gone too fictional for my taste.

As I sat in the almost empty theatre I realised fifteen long minutes had gone by while watching the poorly conceived Sex and the City sequel. Glitzy, glamorous and geriatric, I couldn't help but wonderwas this the best they could do? The reaction to the second film has been mixed at best, but still I was curious as to how this new instalment in the SATC franchise would unfold, so I bit the bullet and sat through the whole film. All ill-judged 146 minutes of it. The wry wit and passion of the television series has long burnt out and now we watch 4 privileged, wealthy, middle aged women, moan and whine about the dull and difficult role of being a career woman, a mother, a semi-newlywed and a menopausal cougar.These women live in the most exciting city in the world, they have amazing opportunities and for the most part they have everything they could ever have wished for. But of course, it's just not enough for them. Whilst the television series was thought provoking and risqué, this insipid sequel lacks any of the shine and pep of the original incarnation. At least when we watched the show weekly we had time in 40 minutes to laugh, cry, cringe and marvel at the antics of the fiery foursome. Now we are subjected to a mid-life crisis of four older women with a dynamic that has gone stale. There is no sympathy anymore for these women when their lives falter at the slightest hurdle. They are in the minority of women who do have it all and their lives are far and away more glamorous than the likes of us, so to witness them wallow in self pity and despair for no good reason leaves a sour taste in the mouth. We don't even have the typical backdrop of New York City for most of the film. The absence of this iconic character is felt even before our intrepid seniors venture to the (unnecessary) location of Abu Dhabi for business and pleasure.Speaking of which, for a show that is famous for using sex as a major theme, there was very little to be had in this film, which added to the lack of sparkle that the series and first film offered in spades. Instead we have personal journeys and oestrogen talk that really fails to light a fire in the hearts of die-hard fans. By the time the "action" moves to the desert we are sucker punched with more designer looks than a head to head between Amir Kahn and Karl Lagerfeld. Unfortunately, the most glaringly obvious must-have found in this film is a life time supply of botox.Perhaps the reason why the film didn't work (or one of many) is because in the beginning, every twenty something girl to every forty plus woman watched these friends like they were our own. We related to them, we wanted to be like them but in the end - even with the fairytale – their problems turn out to be the same as us mere mortals.In spite of a script devoid of laughs and sentiment, I am sure the cash will roll in, making the third instalment a likely outcome. If that means Gucci Zimmer frames and Swarovski encrusted Rascals roaming the streets of New York (or wherever), count me out.

.....This film was like an extension of the scene in series 6 with Geri Halliwell - awkward, confusing, embarrassing and leaving you scratching your head wondering why anyone thought THAT would be a good idea? I was disappointed then and was equally disappointed after seeing this flick. The saving grace for the cringeworthy Spice Girl scene was that it was only a minute long. This, on the other hand, lasts for 2 hours+!Thank god I paid for a Premier seat as there was lots of squirming to be done! Wheeling Liza Minnelli on to do a number at the start (since she struggled to even get the shortest of lines out) sets the tone for what's in store.....a jaw-droppingly mortifying piece of clichéd, 'chick flick' (yuk), over-the-top cinema.As well as seeing Samantha act like a drunken auntie at Christmas (pelvic thrusts, racial slurs and drunken karaoke included), you have cheap puns and unbelievable characters with even less believable motivations. To then set this charade anywhere other than NYC would be mystifying but to set it in Abu-Dhabi truly boggles the mind. Especially when it's clear the writer knows little more about the United Arab Emirates than the rest of us living in cities in the Western world.Now...I'm not daft and I know that even the most casual SATC fan is going to head along to the pictures with their girlfriends (or a very unfortunate boyfriend / husband) no matter what the reviews say. So all I can do is say this...do NOT expect anything more from this film other than 147 minutes of ridiculousness. If you're prepared, you may even have a giggle or two. If you're a huge fan of the series and are expecting more of the same (which, in my opinion, wasn't even delivered in the first film), just stay home, watch the boxset again and pretend this movie doesn't exist because - if you do put yourself through it - you'll be doing that at the end anyway.On a positive note though....at least they're weren't any bleedin' montages in this one!Now, that's fabulous!
A brilliant movie, great story line and a must see movie!

I just saw the movie 'Sex and the city 2', and I was completely impressed with it! It is worth watching, so I want to recommend this movie to all of woman. Anyway, SATC2 is simply awesome. I really love this movie. I think every woman has each spot to sympathize with each character; I mean Carrie, Miranda, Samantha, Charlotte is. Their individual style of concern is just reflecting our woman's way of life! Every woman is particular about something, but actually most of them are keeping. See Carrie and the girls are quite open! Their modern life makes me impressive.And, there are a lot of funny moments that they do strange or fantastic actions, or many great things to look at (beautiful clothes, gorgeous resort, and hot men). So if you haven't seen this movie, please check it out! This is totally amazing.

reviews.review_title: Sarah or Carrie or Whatever "U Blew it", Doesn't matter anymore
reviews.content: My God, Have U seen this movie?, this is one of the worst...no not worst, this is one of the most movies that has nothing to do with the S.A.T.C glamor. seriously, this movie is all about showing The New Middle-East and all the fancy stuff over there combined with a teeny tiny bit of four friends each having a problem that doesn't even matter, i mean who cares if the nanny wears a bra or not and what happened to Mr.Big and his macho ego and appearance, Even Samantha, the S.A.T.C Sexy treat, like she slapped me in the face and told never to see her again, i mean What the F*** is wrong, she does nothing in the movie except complain about her damn hormones, where's the real Sam that doesn't give a damn about anything and just enjoys her sexy ride, Miranda and her shouldn't do this and that, who pointed you the police of manners, i mean seriously... And we come now to the big disappointment... Miss Carrie Bradshaw or Preston or whatever, what's gotten into you? okay, the Aidan project resurfacing, the whole KISS thing, but where's the spark of Carrie that makes everyone interested and into the movie...They shouldn't have done this disgraceful movie and just should have stopped the franchise with the first one as it relates to the series not this waste of time movie...Doesn't even deserve a THREE

Maybe it was my low expectations to begin with after reading so many poor reviews that excelled this movie well past any expectations i had.If you a real fan of SATC and you would expect some over the top fashion, some complaining where you cant see the problem, and some crazy plots then this movie will deliver in true SATC fashion.It is completely true to form, evening skirts and stilettos shopping at a market in Abu Dhabi, stilettos by the pool, and wearing an evening gown watching TV on the lounge - i would be severely disappointed if Carrie went shopping in shorts and flip flops....Open your mind, don't take this so seriously, Abu Dhabi accepted this movie to be made on their grounds, why cant you accept how the middle east was portrayed?? Its a movie! Enjoy this for what it is, I did. Loved it!

reviews.review_title: That one star was for disrespect!
reviews.content: What is up with you guys? wasn't this movie great? honestly i haven't seen whole the series but when i saw the first movie i loved it, there was nothing wrong with it and then i was desperately looking for the second one. when the trailer for the second movie came out i was thrilled but i was also sad because i was not going to be able to see this movie in my country! when i saw the critics i thought that what may have happened? did they really mess up? Until i saw the movie and i changed my idea. it was great, totally. four girls face problems that are common for everyone so they try to fix it their own way. Then the movie gets more exciting when they get a trip to the middle east, the new middle east and they face the problems with the tradition. i am living in middle east and everything in this movie was true but they have gone too far this time that it may be offending for me a little. but still there are lots of fun in this movie, the nanny,The return of Aiden,hormones and the problem with TV. So if you are desperate to see a third movie go and watch it in the cinema and make it a high grossing movie!

reviews.review_title: Sex and the city 2 – a review of character development
reviews.content: Sex And The City 2 is a visually appealing movie, but in terms of character development, it is a huge disappointment. Carrie Bradshaw/Preston - it is difficult to interpret how she is written. On the outside, she looks like a happily married, rich, successful writer, with a cool gang of girl friends. But on closer inspection, she has complaints with everything going on in her life. As a wife, she is simply oblivious to Big's needs. She tells him that she doesn't like the gift he gives her for their anniversary on his face. (That is quite alright, except that she does it so blatantly.) So much being angry with Miranda for saying something to Big before the wedding, which Miranda assumes might have been the reason for Big dumping Carrie at the altar, which is not altogether true. As a writer, Carrie cannot take criticism. When she gets bad reviews for her book on marriage while in Abu Dhabi, she gets worked up and goes out to dine with her ex- boyfriend, purely because she is frustrated, and dining with him is her way of dealing with it. After the dinner, she ends up kissing him. This makes us wonder how Carrie survived in New York all these years without being able to cook, and how she can be a famous writer without being able to handle the slightest bit of negativity. The most lovable character gone awry is this film is Samantha. There are three things she does in this film – 1.obsess about looking young, 2.crib about menopause and her creams being confiscated by the airport authorities at Abu Dhabi, and 3.fling herself at every man she sees. And then, there is the sex itself. While there is nothing wrong in ogling men and having a healthy sex life at fifty, it is painful to watch Samantha trying so hard to land every man she meets. Despite Miranda's repeated warnings about behaviour considered sexually inappropriate in the U.A.E., Samantha ends up making highly suggestive gestures to Rikard on a date in front of a conservative Arab couple, much to their obvious displeasure. While the sheik's behaviour on learning of Samantha's arrest for kissing/making out on the beach is quite inappropriate and so is the behaviour of the men in the souk, who start berating her when her bag gets ripped open and condoms fall out, Samantha makes it worse by thrusting her pelvis at them and shouting. Samantha seems to have no respect, whatsoever, for the Middle-Eastern etiquette, as far as sexual behaviour in public is concerned. She acts like she cannot go through even a single day without having sex. It makes ardent fans wonder whatever happened to the super-successful, in control and classy Samantha, who even ogled in style. (Remember the scene in SATC: The Movie, where she raises her hat half an inch to check out her new neighbour while sipping her drink? That was the Samantha audiences loved). Charlotte's character is quite realistic, she is shown struggling to deal with her two children, a toddler and an infant, and comes across as natural and believable. Her obsession with the nanny tends to get a little annoying at times, though. Miranda is the happy lady in the film. She is the in-control element. She quits her job when her boss who is uncomfortable with women being successful, intimidates her. She is the only girl who thoroughly enjoys the trip to Abu Dhabi. She gets some books and tries to acquaint herself with the culture of Abu Dhabi, and even makes an effort to learn a little Arabic. The scene where she helps Charlotte unwind and talk about difficulties in raising her children is quite endearing, since it not only portrays Miranda as a wonderful friend, but also shows that even mothers need to unwind at times. It is easy to relate to Miranda. But the one character who audiences cannot relate to is Mr. Big/Mr. John Preston. To begin with, he puts up with everything Carrie puts him through, and after Carrie confesses to him on an international phone call that she kissed her ex-boyfriend, his reaction seems inadequate, till the end of the movie. Moreover, he gifts her a black diamond ring when she returns from her trip. (Ironically, Carrie mentions earlier in the film that she would have been happier with a piece of jewellery, rather than the flat screen television, that Big gifted her on their anniversary.) It seems that Big has been written this way just because we need a happy ending here, which cannot be possible if Big is angry with Carrie for kissing Aidan. In conclusion, it does not make for as interesting watching as SATC: The Movie.

reviews.review_title: Loved Sex and City Movie 2. You cannot always rely on reviews!
reviews.content: Sex and The City Movie 2 was a delightful display of all the characters that made the series so great The story line was interesting, and seeing another area of the world was not bad but good. The movie made you laugh,and put forth great memories of the series. Sex and the City Movie 2 explored fantasy, intrigue, and restated each of the characters. The clothes worn by all the girls were relevant to each of the four, and were just as bizarre in some scenes as the previous movie, and the series. Everyone played their part well. I just don't understand why the reviews were so negative.I do hope there is a third movie. Maybe the series should be reunited!
Not the best way to promote Abu Dhabi and a total disrespect to the culture

Ugh. This movie was abysmal. I was a fan of the series, it was cleverly written and because of it's popularity , the writers had years to develop the characters and layer experiences that created depth to each one . Well, p*ss on all of that work. This movie managed to turn these well loved characters into hideous caricatures. Prepare yourself for two long hours of cringing.I'm embarrassed for poor Kim Catrell. She proved her worth as an actress for years through the Samantha character, but here they have taken the fag-hag trope, over painted it and smeared it with gaudy cheap glitter. The bag of flamboyant one liners they gave her to dish out added a whole new cheapness to the "cheap laugh" category. Prepare yourself for juvenile fashion montages in the desert? and with the heaviness of hearts I must say ..the fashion didn't make up for the absurdity. Oh sorrows!! What's the point then? The Carrie and Big storyline was such a snore, I decided to mop my floor while watching the rest - I'm not kidding. I didn't rent a SATC movie to trudge through the daily monotony of someone else's marriage- I've got my own. It's not that it wasn't a worthy subject but certainly not one to base an entire feature length movie upon.I agree with a previous reviewer's opinion that the Charlotte storyline was a bit insulting considering they gave her a full time nanny. Yes, mothering is hard, harder than we all knew before we signed up. Sometimes we snap from exhaustion no matter what our income level, but I'll tell you, peeking into that window through the eyes of someone with full time help isn't going to earn you any points with the majority of women who are paying to see this movie because I'm willing to bet the majority are doing it without help. They should have perhaps written the nanny as having to go out of town or something- and Charlotte then has to handle mothering alone. I could have then maybe accepted her "How do mothers do it without help?" as more of a compliment than an eye roll. Miranda's character lacked depth but I suppose they let her exhibit the full range of emotion in the last movie so was just a prop in this one. Steve, once again, just like the first movie, lacked so much depth that they could have substituted a broomstick with a plaid shirt and a smiley face on it. And at some point between this and the first movie, the Big character had his balls removed. I will pretend this movie never happened.

As I search for the words to describe this film, the only image that comes to mind is the migratory mating pattern of the Medusa Jellyfish. That's to say, this thing is a slimy, sexually-frustrated, formless blob of viscera, slowly meandering across an ocean of ineptitude and disappointment.When discussing the plot of this film, it would be more appropriate to say that the presence of a plot would be a welcome addition. However, when the writers of "SATC2" were tasked with deciding on what the message of the film would be, they seem to have landed on a portrayal of the comings-and-goings of four corpses that can't seem to find the politeness of being actually deceased."Production quality" is a term that should be forbidden when discussing this movie, as "quality" suggests the existence of any discernable effort to making the piece enjoyable in any way. Unfortunately, it seems as though the lighting crew decided that a better use for the burning cigarettes used to light the first act were better-utilized by being jammed into their own eyeballs. At least, this would save them from having to witness the betrayal of cinema unfolding before them.Character development is...In summation, the viewing of this picture could be considered as a torture method for the most radical of global terrorists, were it not for requirements for humane methods of the Geneva convention. After viewing this piece, I am thankful that I am not imbued with the ability to will myself out of existence, as I can't say with certainty that I would be alive otherwise to write this review.

reviews.review_title: Abudabi the movie! and 4 STRANGERS come to visit!... Nightmare and Im the BIGGEST FAN!!
reviews.content: I would like to make it clear that i am one of the biggest fans of this show since it began, i waited a day in Leicester square to see the premiere and i have never stopped loving it until now. i have been urged to write this review after seeing a few "so called" fans saying they enjoyed this film.The film started really good the marriage between Anthony and Stamford was such a shock but a good shock. i expected to see how this marriage would go.but none of that happened.they got married then nothing. smith comes back and you think maybe he could get back with Samantha. he never shows his face again. I don't even remember seeing Steve or harry in the film.i felt that the film began with a few interesting stories like Charlotte's nanny which could have developed. but no you see her breast twice and then 2 hours later it just turns out shes a lesbian.The main problem was that if they had stayed in new york which is the "city" of sex and the "city", then maybe the film would have been good but instead the majority of the film is an Abu Dhabi. and the whole time I'm just waiting for this holiday to finish so they get back to the story.except they come back 10 minutes before the end of the film.So what happened to Aidan, they kiss then thats the end of him!! so many little stories were started but never completed!! And who have these girls turned into! Samantha get fired from her job thing for breaking the Abu Dhabi kissing law, i always thought she was professional. they are all racist talking about the face scarfs and Samantha giving the finger!.Carrie stupidly causes the problems for her marriage when shes the one always trying to make things perfect! and is mean to Charlotte in the elevator for no reason. it just feels like nothing happened they began a film then filmed the whole core of the film with Abu Dhabi.. they could have developed the idea of Miranda having problems with her boss, but instead she just quits in the first 5 minutes. and they don't even show that scene, just Miranda telling Steve about it! It did have some funny bits.but what good are a few jokes at a funeral. and the camel toe just isn't that funny compared to Charlotte shitting her pants!! I hope that a 3rd film is made that makes this all better!!

This probably takes the spot for number one most awful film away from Tango and Cash. I feel like I was robbed of 3 hours. Carrie is a whiny, unsatisfied, typical Jewish princess when her husband gets a TV for their anniversary and she tells him she would rather have jewelry. She is looking old and stupid in the fashions. The black hat she wore to the wedding made her look like Cruella from 101 Dalmatians. And the blue hat on the plane made her look like a revolving appetizer plate from a Mexican Restaurant. Samantha is just disgusting. She needed to be douched with Lysol years ago but now she is just an old "whore". Miranda and Steve were great and Charlotte, burdened with two kids, had the best and only good line in the film. When she thought her husband may take off with the Nanny, she thought, "Oh no, I can't loose the Nanny." There was a very thin story line filled with ridiculous situations that were so over the top suspension of disbelief was impossible. It was pitiful and the old ABC after school playhouse movies were written and executed better. It reminded me of the plot-less series called the Monkees back in the 60's. Mindless, gratuitous, convoluted,idiocy.It was just on TV. If I paid money to watch it I would demand a refund. Terrible movie. Just terrible. Boring. Ridiculous. And if you ever liked Carrie or Samantha you might hate them after watching this.

They get what they want only to be insecure......and their spoiled...only Miranda is real, Samantha is disgusting Charlotte and Mr Big should know better..Carrie is sad and selfish.I wish they had better writers.. And watching TV is not the end of world.

reviews.review_title: Awful way to end a fantastic series!
reviews.content: Wow. What a disappointment. Most all of the intelligent dialogue and interesting, adult problems from the series are gone. Basically, they just all run away from their problems and act stupid in a foreign country. Who on earth thought it would be a good idea to get away from New York?! The whole point was that they were set in "the city." I didn't care to see Abu Dhabi -- that was totally pointless. There are a few real problems that are touched on, but mostly the four of them are just running around acting dumb. And the wedding at the beginning as well as the karaoke scene later on are overdone and painful to watch.Samantha used to be funny, but here she's just a total whore (worse than the series if you can believe that) and embarrasses herself all through the Middle East. Her only serious issue is that she's aging -- they could have made some interesting dialogue about that, but it's all stupid jokes about hormones. Carrie's problem involving seeing her ex could have led to really interesting dialogue. Miranda and Charlotte's issues also COULD have led to interesting dialogue. But that's all left out. Where is the introspection that made the series so fascinating? Leave out all the Abu Dhabi crap and get back to the women dealing with their problems there in the city. They used to have real character. This leaves out all of those moments of grappling with real dilemmas that made the series so fascinating. Stupid jokes, dumb outfits and people acting like whores used to be minor comedic extras in a series that was introspective and about adults dealing smartly with problems (divorce, infertility, breakups, extramarital affairs) in their fast-paced New York lives. It used to be so fascinating to watch. I hope to forget this awful ending.

Sex and the City 2 is all set-up with no pay-off. It's bad soap opera, and every time it comes close to addressing an interesting issue - such as how the reality of a marriage differs from the idealized preconception of one - it quickly backtracks, apologizing along the way for getting serious. Fans will bathe in this sewer of materialistic excess because they appreciate any opportunity to spend time with their favorite characters. Everyone else will stare at the screen in a state of enhanced boredom if the sheer tedium of watching this production doesn't shut down the brain altogether. The first Sex and the City movie was marginally watchable. There was a narrative line, the characters weren't consistently reprehensible, and the humor wasn't quite as forced. Sex and the City 2 has taken all that was bad about its predecessor and amplified it.(Materialism, consumption and nothing more: Avoid with a capital A).

I'll probably get a lot of thumbs down but I'm a SATC fan! I think this is only something that Sex and the City fans will enjoy and understand. Guys steer clear and if you don't like SATC don't watch. It's just good seeing the girls reunite on screen again. The film is about the Sex and the City girls, well duh; Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker), Miranda (Cynthia Nixon), Samantha (Kim Cattrall) and Charlotte (Kristin Davies) coming together again and discussing their relationship and family problems. To get away from all their troubles they go on a girlie holiday to Abu Dhabi where Samantha struggles to stick to the strict no sex laws, Carrie bumps into an ex, Miranda enjoys learning about the culture and Charlotte gets some well needed away time from the demands of motherhood. It's really like a longer and more adventurous SATC episode; as a fan I was satisfied. SATC always deal with problems that are real and like a lot of Hollywood films doesn't portray the perfect relationships and marriages and that they need working at. SATC is a lof of fun and something to watch with your mum and your girl pals. I found the film entertaining and sincere and it's nice to catch up with the SATC girls and see where they are after the series finished. I hope they make a third film. This film isn't for everyone, but its something SATC fans will appreciate only.

Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker), Samantha (Kim Cattrall), Charlotte (Kristin Davis) and Miranda (Cynthia Nixon) come together to take another bite out of The Big Apple - and beyond.. What happens after you say "I do?" Life is everything the ladies ever wished it would be, but it wouldn't be Sex in the City if life didn't hold a few more surprises. After all, sometimes you just have to get away with the girls.

also stars Chris Noth, John Corbett, David Eigenberg, Evan Handler and Jason Lewis.

Not as good as first one for sure. Beat the series to a pulp by the end of this. Lots of cheesy bad jokes and lacks the series witty and smart humor. The 2 gay guy getting married thAt hate eachother, big wanting his own place, the braless jokes etc... Seriously what were they thinking?

Definitely a film to be watched with only the girliest of your friends, preferably with a cocktail or two at hand. I'm not sure that I would have tolerated this movie if I had not followed the tv series. It does not measure up in wit or substance, and seems far more concerned with product placement and flashing its ridiculously large budget around than actually delivering a quality movie. Carrie, whose likability had been questionable in the series, is incredibly frustrating, though still an improvement on the first movie. Aidan makes a bizarre appearance, despite the film being set on the other side of the world, whether to add some adulterous conflict or to simply make Carrie's marriage to Big even less satisfying it is unclear. The film flirts with racism throughout, crossing over completely at the end with the insulting display of Islamic women drawing their garments to reveal haute couture. Correct me if I am wrong, but I am sure there aren't many Muslim women smuggling Prada underneath their hijabs around Abu Dhabi. The only redeeming factor was that the film did not shy away from the fact that the ladies have aged: Samantha hits menopause head on, something that the folks responsible for airbrushing the promotional posters into oblivion apparently missed. I don't think this movie should be discounted completely, it just would have been so much more pleasant cut down to one of the 25 minute segments that the writers once excelled at.

OH. MY. GOD. This sequel is even WORSE than it's horrible predecessor! Like I've mentioned in a few other reviews of films I despise, this is one those cases where I wish I could give zero stars, but the rating system won't let me, so I have to award this cinematic abortion a half-star, even though that is being far too generous. Not since Gigli have I witnessed a comedy so utterly horrific and insanely unfunny, and while this film isn't quite as bad, it's not very far behind. This film takes everything that made the first film suck horribly and accenuates all those problems to a near-apocalyptic level of badness. This film was so awful, it felt like it raped and crushed my soul right from the get-go because everything about this film is beyond horrible. The storyline is even shittier than before, the acting is annoying and dull once again, the humor is even worse, nothing happens in this film like the first film, the characters are even bigger bitches than before, it's chock-full of stereotypes about women and gay people that are utterly offensive and horrifying, and it's even more boring despite being only a little bit longer. Now, I know there might be women who think that this film is all about women empowerment, but this film is a total insult to women because unless you prefer the depiction of women to be selfish, fashion-obsessed, air-headed whores who talk about nothing interesting whatsoever, then this is not empowerment. If you want to see a good film about women empowerement that features female friends going on a trip together, then I suggest you watch Thelma & Louise, which is a wonderful film that has everything the film doesn't have like a good story, characters you grow to care about, actual humor, genuine heartfelt moments, and it's also a film guys can get into as well. Watch that instead.

For a guy who has never watched a full episode of Sex and the City, the second film based on one of HBO's most famous comedy series is one of the most putrid and excruciating pieces of cinematic pigswill ever made. In a time of a continuing economic collapse, inequality and racial controversies, Sex and the City 2 is the completely wrong movie at the wrong time. Its water-thin narrative about four female travesties traveling to Abu Dhabi to basically do nothing but eat exotic food and spend money on worthless trash celebrates consumerism while creating abhorrent depictions of motherhood, marriages and womanhood in general. These women shriek, complain, consume, shriek, complain, shriek, complain some more, consume and consume and complain... WHILE EVERYTHING IS FINE. They have mountains of money, fancy clothes, extravagant apartments full of trendy furniture, giant televisions, irritating children, and loving husbands, but who must be a little empty-headed since one of them (who has to be an arms dealer or at least a crooked fundraiser for important politicians) buys a TV the size of a football field for an anniversary gift, while the wife had hoped some more jewelry. Oh, but she learns not to care about that little vexation, since in the magical consumption land of Abu Dhabi she has a spiritual awakening as she learns that everyone really can't afford that jewelry, because they just don't make enough money. This is two and a half hours of absolute torture. The only glimpse of light is the hope that this is meant to be just a really bad satire. But even if so, Sex and the City 2 is still cinematic consumption porn completely disconnected from real societal issuses, such as gender roles, motherhood and inequality, that it hopes to touch upon even slightly. Instead it wants its audience to sympathize with and relate to the most contemptible bunch of hysterical and materialistic imbeciles, and realize that money actually doesn't define everything, as long as you have an extravagant apartment, a TV the size of a football field, fancy clothes, jewelry, and a loving, if sometimes lazy, husband. This is a film that will make you both mentally and physically sick. It is a film to be burned at stake and buried deep into the ground, so its evil forces can never rise again.

As a fan of the series, I enjoyed having the girls back. Sadly, I have to be objective and as a film... it failed. Far worse than the first. This does not mean I don't advocate grabbing a cosmo and revisiting the girls when you're feeling down. It simply means that in stead of putting the extra effort in and making it good, MP King decided to rather just sit back and ride the wave, opting to not really even try. A weak script, lacking a central plot and any real drama, shallow and with acting that could only come from lazy directing. It's also rather loose, and loses itself most of the time. There are, however, isolated moments where you'll flashback in your head and relish in the splendour of a typical Mirandism or Samanthaism, and the wedding scene featuring Liza Minnelli is divine to say the least - reason alone to watch the film! Sadly, it's downhill from there. MPK also unfortunately tries to tie in a recession-focused plot - an idea that seems more like a last minute attempt to make the film appealing on a broader scale than a well-though through plot. Too many stories, too many loose ends, too little substance and no real weight. I hate to say it, but the naysayers were right.

This is basically all of the things that were bad about the first film. I'll admit, I found it hard to watch this without Mark Kermode's famous ranty-review ringing in my ears. While he was outraged by the class, gender and race politics of Sex and the City 2 I simply found it to be a tired retread of material that this franchise has already 'explored' in the show and in the first film, in short it is boring. There's nothing new other than the setting, only this time the four leads are playing caricatures of their character, particularly Kim Catrall as Samantha. There is one scene towards the end in which she announces to the proverbial Arab world that she, simply put, 'has sex' whilst flailing her arms in the air grasping condoms. For me its a scene that sums up just how tired this franchise has become and really how lazy it is. What other conclusion could one reach when the great denouement is that the repressed women of Abu Dhabi are in fact as driven by consumerism as our four protagonists. Much like the first film this is way too long but really it's just tremendously insignificant.

They're back! The sparkling Sex and the City sequel sees Carrie, Samantha, Charlotte and Miranda take another bite out of the Big Apple - and beyond. It's been two years and just as the friends are getting a little too settled into marriage and motherhood, they are whisked away to one of the most exotic places on earth for a sun-drenched adventure. Get ready for the ultimate weekend away with the girls. So I've seen Sex and the City: The Movie and I thought it was below average (4/10) but does the second one improve from the first movie's flaws? No, it doesn't! If anything, it's added more flaws. The story was very basic and not in a good way, it was boring and not interesting in the slightest. The girls basically moaned about their lives so Samantha manages to bag the women a holiday to Abu Dhabi where they moaned even more about their lives (except for a couple of scenes). The characters were poorly written this time round as all of them did nothing but nag, moan and bitch about everything in their lives. If they weren't bitching to their families, the women would get together over lunch and have a good bitch about themselves.

The acting was so-so, there were a couple of okay moments when the actresses didn't do a bad job but there were a lot of moments when it was bad. The direction is rubbish, the writing is a joke and the script isn't fun at all. Sex and the City 2 tries to be something it's not: Fun, sexy and smart. The worst thing about the movie is, yet again, the runtime. Two and a half hours is simply too long for this movie and the plot was very thin. I could have very easily cut sixty minutes out of the movie and you wouldn't miss anything. The only reason why I saw this was because I saw the first and I very stupidly thought that it could improve, but it didn't. Another thing that bugged me was the stuff they were wearing. This movie is supposed to be all about glamorous fashion and things but half the stuff they were wearing looked horrible, I couldn't see any woman with a sane mind wearing half the stuff they displayed in the movie.

The characters were yet again stereotypical but this time, it was more blatant and in-your-face.  The acting wasn't very good at all, they did a better job in the first movie. The 'funny' scenes aren't funny at all, except for the parts with Erin the Irish Nanny who made Samantha jealous. Overall, one of the worst movies this year and possibly one of the worst chick flicks I have ever seen and in even worse news, if the rumours are true, it's possible that it could be a trilogy! God help the world of cinema! There were a couple of funny scenes but apart from that, Sex and the City 2 has no sparkle and it has to be one of the worst movies of 2010. It didn't improve from its flaws, it just made more. I still can't see why women love this...

I think viewers who have traveled and lived abroad, or have been to some other far away place, whether mental or physical, can relate more to this movie. As a fan of Sex & the City, the television series, it was difficult for me at first to remove myself from that bind, of having the expectation that punch lines, life lessons, and themes were going to be packed neatly in a 40 minute segment. However, the script, for the most part, achieves the goals for this full-length movie format. The characters are who we expect them to be, we are taken on an adventure that's fun, and reflective. My only complaints, though, is that elements in the screenplay could have definitely been fine tuned. That Carrie-voiceover that fans of the TV series are so accustomed to hearing, where she neatly packages her lessons into a few words, doesn't function quite right in the movie. Also, the relationship the characters have with each other, what impact they make on each other, and how they urk/comfort each other and under what circumstances, could have been tighter. With that said, though, this movie is a fun adventure with no shortage of dramatic moments that encourage viewers to see that no matter how far away we look, how hard we look, sometimes, what we needed was right in front of us all along. Further, this movie (not unlike the television show), really pushed the envelope! I mean, it pushes the boundaries by including a gay wedding, signifying the transformation of the meaning of weddings and commitment in our modern society, and unlike most, no, ALL romantic comedies, it really makes a powerful commentary on modern marriage--the juggling the hustle and bustle of work, friends, and lovers.

FREE MOVIE WEEK REVIEW #2:  "Sex in the City 2" is the "The Godfather: Part III" of  "Sex in the City" movies.  It looks great, it entirely lacks substance, and it's all but betrayed it's core characters that made it so damn appealing in the first place.

I love these girls.  But they are kind of grotesque and cartoonish here.  Especially Carrie Bradshaw.  I am used to ROOTING for Carrie... not wishing her ill will.  Samantha smears a lot of hummus on her face and porks a lot, as usual, and Miranda remains as affable as ever.  But what they've done to Charlotte is has to be (by now, and far and away) considered a sin.  In the first movie, Charlotte hardly-enjoyed a severe case of the shits.  In this one, they gave her a camel toe.  Nobody involved seems to really care much about these characters any more.  Burkas are even slapped upon them.  Michael Patrick King is almost like the mad surgeon in "The Human Centipede: First Sequence" to his once-beloved New York babes.  He cruelly sews them ass-to-mouth, ridding them of their once-appealing humanity.  They are now 4 annoying Betty Whites with orange-y spray tans.  Strutting obnoxiously in the Arab Emirates.

With all this money at stake, HBO coulda made a slammin' "Sopranos" epic.  Oh, well.  There's always "Not Necessarily the News: The Motion Picture", coming soon NEVER.

Had to see this as an avid Sex and the City fan of the series and the first movie, but everyone was trying too hard in this second movie. Except for the script, which was shallow and truly disappointing.

Not nearly as bad as I'd heard it would be.  However, I did have the advantage of watching it in 15 to 30 minute chunks over 3 or 4 days; if I'd watched the whole, long thing in the theater, I may have been bored and frustrated, too.

Anyway, it's no different than any episode of the series, full of horrible puns (Charlotte's lingerie-challenged Irish nanny being referred to as "Erin Go-Bra-less" was just BAD.), fabulous fashions, pointless cameos, and glamorous scenery.  Before they leave for Abu Dhabi, all the "girls" have interesting problems:  Charlotte is frustrated with motherhood; Miranda has a stressful job and a sexist boss (Ron White!); Samantha is waging a futile battle against menopause, with a variety of pills and potions; Carrie is afraid Big just wants to lie on the couch, order in, watch tv, and never go out again.  When they get to the UAE, things get a little ridiculous (including a flimsy excuse to get them all in burkas, when really, Samantha probably would have been arrested and/or stoned), but the appearance of Aidan is interesting.

In conclusion, I didn't hate it, and I would watch another one if they made it.  What can I say?

As a fan of the Sex and the City franchise and seeing that both the series and the first movie were so well crafted, expectations were high for Sex and the City 2.  But writers Michael Patrick King and Candace Bushnell dropped their martini glasses and the end result was a borish flop that insulted legions of SATC fans and did no justice to the charactetrs.

The story begins two years after Carrie wed Mr. Big, Charlotte has two children to take care of, Miranda is having trouble with her boss, and Samantha is doing what she does best.  None of these plot lines were interesting nor expanded on the major players' lives.  There was no growth and it seems that the sole purpose of the movie was to remind us of how fabulous these four women are.  The problem is that we already know they are fabulous and don't need that fact rammed down our throats.  

But the major insult was that these characters came across as stupid which is something they never were portrayed as in the past.  They may have done stupid things from time to time but never did we the audience think them frivolous.  For example, Charlotte (Kristin Davis) bakes cupcakes with two small daughters wearing a Valentino skirt and heels? Miranda (Cynthia Nixon) can't handle her chauvinistic male boss?  Samantha (Kim Cattrall) blows a very lucrative international PR deal?  Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker) has trouble being faithful to Mr. Big (Chris Noth)?  No.  No.  No.  And no.  None of these plots lines are believable given the context into which these characters have previously been placed.

Shame on the writers for doing such a disservice to loyal fans and to the beloved characters!  We can only hope that if the producers deign to do a SATC3 they think long and hard about returning the franchise to its rightful place of intelligent comedy.

As I watched this torturous epilogue to ironically successful television series, I kept asking myself one question: Is this OVER yet? At more than two and a half hours, I couldn't help but feel pain for real movie critics who were forced to watch this. To begin with, no movie needs 40 minutes of exposition, and they certainly don't need as many subplots, which by the way, only doubled the damage of the already thin and dull script. This film could have been half the time and told the same story, but instead, it had to be dragged on, and on, and on,...
Gone are the days of the hilarious HBO series, instead, we open at a gay wedding hosted by Liza Minelli, and eventually we progress to Samantha meeting with an old client of hers, and is invited by one of his friends to visit his new resort in Dubai, in hopes she can make it huge in the USA, drawing thousands to it. As an added incentive, he pays for her and the gal pals to go visit for a week. Things get complicated when both old and new faces show up, and Samantha predictably sleeps with every guy at the resort.
This film was a nightmare to watch, and I feel pity for everyone who suffered with me. You wanna see the girls at their best? Rent some of the TV show, and save yourself two and a half hours of cheesy, filthy, thin story I cannot get back.

And you get to see how disfunctional Carrie Bradshaw really is.

All I can say is that it is a funny movie and it can show how some people are and how some people, even when they have all that they want, truly aren't happy still.  But in the end I think she grows up at least a little bit more.
I love both the HBO series and the first movie - this steaming pile of garbage partially defaces their legacy. So I hate it on multiple levels.

It shoulda been retitled 'The Boring Housewives of a Formerly Brilliant TV show',  as SATC2 plays like an R rated cartoon of the series. The characters 'sorta' act like themselves, however, 'a- nothing new-watered down, over the top version' of who we thought we knew. MPK writes and directs (for SATC3, let's allow him to direct only) a mostly flashy, substanceless, meaningless and hence, no care for what happens at all to Carrie and the gals. Whoever said opulence has to be superficial ONLY is wrong. There could be an understanding of the importance of glamour in this post (?) recession world and elevate these characters to a new place without sacrificing their inner core. This film does neither. Other than the ridiculous costumes and 'what will they do next' curiosity, what kept me going was my anger at the offensive lack of story (most scenes are stretched out 'set pieces' meant to entertain at the lowest level), and trying to figure out why this film was made other than a guaranteed paycheck. I'm shocked that Sarah Jessica Parker and Kim Cattrall would agree to this script. Except for a few good lines, and an ending that picked up 'a bit' (if not enough) of steam, SATC2 makes the girls look like one of the Housewives on Bravo with very little impulse control. Having loved the first movie and been a fan of the series for years i was initially very excited to see Sex and the City 2, i had high hopes and even higher expectations but unfortunately the characters id learned to love took a turn for the worst.
First off the movie starts in a paralell universe where Stanford marries his nemises Anthony. I found this to be a horribly stupid unrealistic idea, oh sure the two token gay guys get married even though they cant stand eachother. How convenient.
Carrie (whom ive always loathed) is more unrealisticly self obsessed than ever, she finally married the man of her dreams and he is a wonderful husband to her, but she obviously hates being married and acts as if the whole thing was a horrible mistake. I honestly thought they would have a baby and be happy but they pride themselves in chosing to never start a family, which i understand because someone as self obsessed as Carrie could never care for a baby.
Charolette's dreams of getting married and having babies is crushed when motherhood becomes too hard for her as her parenting skills deteriorate and her focus is 100% on the nannies boobs and her husbands interest in a woman who isnt crying in the closet hiding from her children all day. 
Miranda finally decides that she likes her son enough to acknowlege he exists and quits her job to take responsibility for her kid. (SNORE) Samantha (now officially an elderly spinster) is more sexualy reckless than ever, and here i was hoping she would find and marry Mr.Right and grow up like the rest of us. 
i honestly think this movie is insulting and outrageously offensive to wealthy middle aged new york women. I mean the series made women look bad from the start but this movie is the climactic trainwreck of idiotic rich women with no real problems. 
The climax of the movie being Aiden kissing Carrie (which never would have happened in the series after he got married and had kids) and Big's reaction to Carries childish shameful behavior is buying her a huge amazing diamond ring. But of coarse he was already in trouble with Carrie for buying her a flat screen for the bed room, which makes sense if you abandon all thought and logic.
This movie takes the cake for cinematic disasters, and from now on will be the refference for disappointing women everywhere, sorry men with small penises, your role has been stolen.

Is it going too far to call a movie a hate crime? Yes? Okay, fair enough.

Sex and the City 2 is a hate crime. It's a film which hates women. It features four shrieking, over privileged banshees who whine and complain that they have such horrific inconveniences as two apartments, a full time nanny or a high paying career job. And I'm meant to feel sorry for these people? I don't think so.

Perhaps, though, the awful indulgences mean that they will learn to find solace in little things? Oh no. Wrong again. The Sex and the City women get solace from the following things: first class flying, luxury cars, butler service, sex with strangers and shoe shopping. And that's it.

The message of Sex and the City 2, therefore, is that to be a woman is to acquire enough status to buy things or people. And if you cannot buy things or people; you must find what peace you can in watching other women doing the same thing to remove yourself from the destitute life you are currently living. Sounds pretty gross, right? Yes, thats right. Sex and the City 2 is a hate crime. Its a crime against you. If you have the misfortune to watch it; please report it to the police.
